Дженкс, у нас труп, возможно криминал, по коням!


Несмотря на маленький бюджет, игра довольно интересная. Большинству любителей детективов понравится. Но игра не без минусов:
-Главный герой, как-то слишком сильно кривляется, в первые разы конечно смешно, но потом начинает надоедать.
-Звуковые дорожки. Бюджет, конечно не большой, но все-равно раздражает, когда в середине диалога слышно постороние шумы.
-Нельзя сопоставить показания одного человека с другими. То-есть если вы спрашиваете одного человека о каком-либо предмете, а другой говорит совсем другое, то нельзя сравнить это как противоречие.

Из плюсов стоит отметить:
+Довольно хороший и продуманный сюжет. Лично меня зацепило до самого конца.
+Актеры, хоть иногда и переигрывают, но в целом очень хороши. 
+Отличная шлюпа детектива-инспектора Дженкса! (Она замечательна!)

8/10

38721703.review:
Best Christmas gift I have received in a very long time! 

This was easily one of the most enjoyable games I have played in 2017 and that is saying a lot. I thoroughly enjoyed the story and was fairly challenged by the clues and suspects. It was the perfect little gem of a game to while away some holiday time off with. The scenes were well acted (and they should be with talent like Paul Darrow). The plot was intriguing and twisty. The end was suprising. There was a smattering of tongue and cheek humor. Everything you like in a good mystery!

Even Inspector Jenks acknowledged his odd lack of a cell phone. Use of the phone box was a nice touch that added a little old fashioned and timeless feel. 

While I did feel, at times, that I was harassing suspects, banging on their doors all all hours and asking questions all the time - it was also an integral part of uncovering constradictions - and that is the whole point. I played this game solo, but easily this could be a great party game to play with friends. 

I sincerely hope I have not seen the last of Inspector Jenks - please make another one and take my money!

38650945.review:
I was really ify about this game, because it kinda seemed a little amateurish to me. As soon as I saw the acting in the game, especially the main character's (Jenkins or Jenks), I had a gut feeling that this game is going to be a huge cheese ball. Just straight up I didn't like the acting in this game. Everytime, Jenks asks a questions he makes weird overly acted facial expressions which can be okay sometimes but he just does it everytime when the camera cuts to him. Second negative thing for me was the sound. I'm not talking about the soundtrack, actually I kinda liked the soundtrack to be honest, but the audio recording of the scenes and actors are poorly done. I don't really know about how they record it some of the scenes, but they should have been more careful about it. Its just annoying to me when you hear ambient sounds in the middle of the scene. Lastly, you only find contradictions when you examine the suspects. For instance, once you done examining Emma, you could also examine Simon about the same topic, however the game doesn't let you put what has Emma told you when you are examining Simon on the contradiction boxes. Meaning that you can't really use what other people have told you about the same topic to find out who's lying or not. For me, this paved the way to a negative review. 

Although, I have to say this is not a bad game. If you don't agree or don't care about these issues, you can enjoy this game a lot. 

5/10

37920022.review:
I played this game with my spouse, and we really enjoyed the first 3/4 or so. Unfortunately, the last 1/4 of it (and especially the absolutely terrible ending) left us irritated and disappointed. Many of the interesting aspects of the story end up being red herrings, and the solution to the mystery comes out of nowhere. We actually both sat back and said "that's it?!". It felt very rushed. It's like the developer wanted to leave room for a sequel, but went too far and made the ending just plain unsatisfying.

Other minor annoyances: some contradictions are obvious, but for whatever reason the main character won't point them out. Also, it can be finicky with what it accepts, even when there ought to be various possible choices, so sometimes you wind up playing "guess exactly what the developer was thinking". This isn't a dealbreaker though... that awful ending is.

I genuinely feel bad giving this game a negative review. I do love the concept and the atmosphere. I'd like to see more games like this, but more skillfully written.

In summary: an otherwise fine and pleasantly unusual adventure game, ruined by an incredibly abrupt and disappointing end.

37831672.review: Contradiction is a throwback to the days of FMV games. You play as a detective investigating a death in a little English village with a lot of secrets. The game is relatively short: you'll probably finish it within 5 to 6 hours, but don't let that discourage you from buying this, there's really nothing else like it available on Steam. The village is populated by several memorable suspects, with Paul Darrow of Blake's 7 fame putting in a stellar performance as the growling Paul Rand. Jenks is a likeable hero & you'll find yourself sucked into the story as more clues emerge & the truth behind what really happened slowly becomes clearer. I really hope Tim Follin decides to make a sequel one day, I'd pick it up like a shot

36423635.review:
The game starts off great with it's cast of characters. None of them are stereotypical, they are all related with eachother and the actors do a great job of acting them out. They do a convincing job of portraying discomfort and anxiety when you're asking them questions they'd rather you didn't, anger and resentment when you ask a presumptuous question, etc. 


The locations are mostly interesting, but some of them you'll only visit once and very briefly. The only strange part about the map is how the forrest is divided into several parts, which are mostly empty, save for pre-defined moments in the game. 

The game is long enough to justify the price tag. 

However, the game does suffer from some technical problems. I've got a good computer, and I don't think it should have any trouble with an FMV game. The interactions with the environment and the video itself are very smooth, and I've not had any crashes, but I've found that the game froze many times while in the interrogation screen. 

This is a big shame, since that's one of the places you'll spend the most time in. The freezes only last for about 10 seconds, but it's enough to be frustrating and kills immersion. At one point it got perticularly bad, and I had to restart the game. 

The freezes appeared to be at their worst whilst scrolling trough all the topics that you've recived a statement on. Some interrogations went quite smoothly, others froze multiple times. This really should be fixed. 

However, I don't think it detracts from the game enough for me not to recommend it. In pretty much everything else - the game does a great job and that makes me willing to forgive it for it's technical problems. 

Overall it's very interesting, I think people who are into murder mystery should check this one out. The studio did a good job.

36151914.review: Really loved this game.  I've been playing these sorts of point-and-click adventure games for as long as they've been made, but Contradiction is the first one in a very long time to really try something new.  Sure, FMV has been done, but not like this.  Truly a great story and the gameplay itself is quite good.  There are a couple of UI quirks, but they're just that...quirks.  Nothing deal-breaking or that would ruin the experience.  The acting is wonderful, the characters diverse and pretty deep, considering how long you have to get to know them.  All-in-all, I would recommend this one for a high slot on any adventure lover's wishlist.  It's definitely not Myst, but if you're tired of everyone trying to be Myst, then by all means, give Contradiction a chance.

36082829.review:
As somebody who plays a lot of point-n-clicks and mystery games - I would say this is some of the better content out there!

Some mystery games have a great storyline but excessively far fetched puzzles or leads and conclusions that don't necessarily make a whole lot of sense. Contradiction's storyline kept me engaged throughout the whole thing, and the conclusions you have to draw weren't outlandish or illogical - it all felt very streamlined and made sense. Had a flow to it. It very much felt like an interactive episode of Midsomer Murders (a great british mystery tv show), which I can only expect is how an FMV game SHOULD feel. No action buttons, no strange mini games, just story. *

Mystery games all have varying degrees of success in mechanical aspects, the story aside, and to compare Contradiction's interface to other mystery games doesn't really achieve much - it's a bit clunky, could use some polishing, yeah. That is however what I've come to expect in this genre and doesn't at all affect the score I would give it. Not even close to game breaking, just a bit disorienting a few times.

The production value of it is also really great? It's nicely shot, the acting is pretty great (engaging and entertaining!), the sound is beautiful. As good as graphics have gotten these days, as an animator, I'm still disappointed in face-focused acting in 3D games. Obviously didn't have that problem here. :) The actors may have overacted a bit sometimes, but they were by no means bad.

So if you're looking for that good, good interactive mystery content - yes this game is for you. I played with a friend and we had a really good time.
Into that but get hung up on details? Dunno how you survive this genre.

*I will say, did leave some loose ends. But they at least adressed them instead of ignoring them, and as far as I understand they were loose because of the budget. Tough break.
I would personally back the heck out of a sequel!

34924976.review:
[h1]The Short:[/h1]
Well worth the $10 price tag.

[h1]The Long:[/h1]
Contradiction: The Interactive Murder Mystery Movie is a well written murder mystery. The only issue I have with this type of game is the fact that you really don't feel so much as a detective as you do as someone trying to figure out what the author wants you to see. This issue plagued LA Noir as well but in this instance, it is saved by very strong writing and convincing acting. While there are a couple of contradictions that really don't make any sense and other contradictions that are not noted these do not take away from the overall thrill of playing through this game. Even if you only play through it once you will be satisfied with the time you spend with this game. For the first game of its type that I even played it sets the bar very high. I hope that they make a sequel.

Contradiction was a lot of fun. Reminds me a bit of Phoenix Wright in its use of logic in its mechanics. Rupert Booth's acting (Frederick Jenks) was hands down the highlight of this game and I wish to see more in the future.

34818538.review:
Contradiction è un giallo ben cogegnato.
Indosserete i panni di Jenks, un detective di periferia dalla personalità bizzarra, impegnato nell'indagine di un presunto suicidio in un piccolo villaggio nei pressi di un college inglese.
Il gioco non è propriamente un filmato interattivo, ma sfrutta materiale girato di alta qualità per mostrarci gli interrogatori e gli spostamenti del detective. Le iterazioni avvengono tramite punta e clicca.

L'interfaccia è intuitiva e ben curata, e sfrutta un sistema davvero intrigante per individuare le menzogne dei sospettati: le contraddizioni. Durante gli interrogatori che Jenks effettua sui residenti del villaggio, è possibile individuare delle contraddizioni, alcune semplici, altre difficili da cogliere, che rivelano menzogne grandi o piccole. Ad ogni contraddizione, la matassa del giallo si dipana, consentendoci di arrivare sempre più vicino al colpevole.
Non ci sono solo gli interrogatori: è anche possibile trovare indizi e utilizzare gli oggetti trovati (o presi "in prestito" eh eh...) per proseguire nella storia.

La recitazione è quasi sempre in sintonia con i personaggi e le situazioni (Jenks è davvero uno spettacolo, dato che non rappresenta il solito detective serio e burbero).

Alla fine del gioco c'à spazio per un caso ancor più difficile. Diamo un contributo a questo gioco e potremo goderci una trama ancor più bella in un possibile sequel.

Consigliato al 100%

Great game, loved the novelty of live-action. The abilities to call the chief, see tips, and even "cheat" if you get too stuck, made the game very user-friendly and mitigated the frustration that is commonly felt with these games. The acting was perfectly well done, really overdone for comedic effect which kept the game lively and entertaining. There are a few criticisms: several areas in the game are only useful to visit a few times, and I would have liked to have every space utilized more effectively. In fact, the game noticeably is missing any extras, which it should have been possible to film; just a few groups havin dinner in the pub perhaps to justify the murmur of conversation. One character, in fact, you only have a single conversation with and then disappears. This is toward the end of the game, and it makes me think that the conclusion was very rushed. You continue finding contradictions, and then suddenly you more or less stumble into the end of the game. I'd like to have had to use more of a detective method to drive home the climax. Maybe there could have been a kind of lightning round where you have to ask about the right things quickly enough to arrive at the necessary solution. I don't know, but there should have been something different to signify an exciting ending. 
The game is a real trailblazer, and I hope that more of these are produced. Its few flaws can be overlooked for the originality of the medium. Fantastic game. If there is a sequel, I will look forward to it.

34301899.review:
Contradiction is a promising game, and an intriguing one especially considering the director's massive legacy in VGM composition. The integration of video clips into overworld movement, combined with the relatively high quality FMV cutscenes and GODLY TIM FOLLIN SOUNDTRACK make the whole experience much more immersive and cinematic. The actors are decent-to-great and the dialogue works almost all of the time, although the lead character's expressiveness borders on immersion-breaking at points. The fast travel system is a nice QOL feature that makes visiting the different suspects far more painless but still retains a level of cinematic flair, with the map changing appearance depending on the direction from which you entered it and other various nice touches. The story, being the main focus of the game, is simple but relatively strong for the majority of its run, only suffering towards the end (I will discuss this later).

However, despite the strong FMV qualities of the game, UI and general control issues make me hesitant to recommend this game wholeheartedly.  There are a couple game-breaking glitches (luckily quitting and re-entering the game is quick and painless) and some very inconvenient UI decisions regarding information display, making for annoying and unecessary amounts of scrolling or clicking just to keep track of all the clues or items at your disposal. Some contradictions/clues are clear from the beginning and cannot be selected due to the progression of the plot, and many of the items you use to progress further are not unlocked through clever puzzle-solving or ingenuity--they just appear in various areas as you get to different stages of the story.

Map design was another sore point for me, and an aspect of the game that I think could have been handled a lot better. Certain areas, like the Restaurant or the End of West Street, are used only once in the entire game, making them really a waste of resources and time as players are encouraged to check all areas of the map repeatedly for new clues or hints. These areas will be completely empty otherwise and cannot be fast-travelled too either. On the other hand the three clearings in the woods are unmarked and verynondistinct from one another, making their various story significances seem pointless...why isnt there just one clearing? It all seems very inconvenient to have to travel all the way through the forest checking every clearing each time one suspects someone will be there. It's all very arbitrary to the player, especially considering some locations are so barren they could have been combined into one scene, like the Jetty and the Site of Death. Clearly  this was done due to requiring real onsite filming locations but the Site of Death is used only 1 time regardless for investigation and all the cutscenes taking place there could all easily have taken place on the Jetty if the camera was simply a bit more zoomed out there. To me this simply shows off more of how underutilized much of this game is due to its limited budget and perhaps overambitious writing/design.

Now, obviously the above two paragraphs, while taking up a bulk of the review, do not really mean much since this is an FMV mystery game. However, its story as well is limited by its small budget and scale. Despite the strong character/story progression within the admittedly very linear story, all our investment in said story is revealed to be for naught at the end of the game. A huge amount of setups, sideplots, useless clues, weird qualities of characters, and the like are left completely unaddressed as the game abruptly ends and baits a sequel. This was one of the most frustrating aspects of playing this game, and although I understand the constraints put on the game by its nature as a Kickstarter-backed small-scale FMV, I still wish Tim and his crew had instead reigned back the writing so the story could have remained tighter while not having all these loose ends. Several aspects of Simon's character in particular are brought up only to never be mentioned again, not even in the epilogue.

In conclusion, this game is an interesting and promising purchase but not in my opinion a worthwhile one, especially considering its short playtime and blue-balls story. I enjoyed my time with the game, but still believe it could have been streamlined a lot more and would recommend waiting until a sequel or sequels are released that better tie up the many loose ends left behind by this game.

Just finished the game, and I am absolutely amazed. The game is a FMV type of game, where you solve the murder of Kate Vine by looking for evidence, interviewing people, and finding contradictions in the answers. It takes roughly 5-6 hours to complete if you're as stupid as I am, and it's quite enjoyable. It's constantly changing your view of the situation and who you think the murderer is. Only downsides I have with the game are the controls (at times) and the rare very vague contradictions. Definitely worth the 10 euros. .....sequel, please?

Edit: Forgot to mention the acting. The acting generally is quite good, and the emotional part (no spoilers) is not in any way "cheesy" or such. There is some over-acting (mainly the faces that Jenks makes at times), but it does have its charm. The acting generally adds to the value of the game.

剧情：很有新意。在侦破杀人案的过程中一个邪教机构的阴谋逐渐浮出水面，有一些《天使与魔鬼》的感觉。 但是游戏结尾只是简单的结束了杀人案，并没有把这个邪教组织完全弄清楚。根据结尾来看，游戏很有可能会出续作，非常期待！

总体评分：8/10

Excellent game. I generally don't like crime novels or games but I loved this one.

There were none of the overly complicated, clunky interfaces you might see in crime solving games. Everything was simple and where it should be. Maybe that was a result of the budget being small but I certainly hope it will be the same in the sequel, if there is one.

Another thing I really liked was that there were no nonsensical connections meant to throw you off or evidences in unreasonable places. If there is something to find, you find it without pixel hunting. The connections you have to make to solve the case are very logical. I felt great after finding something out without tips or the chief's suggestions. And don't expect everything you learn in the game to be significant to the puzzle. Suspects tell you a lot of thing, very little of which will help you make progress. I loved this aspect of the game because it was very realistic.

So, if you like a crime solving game that actually respects your intelligence and manages challenging you without working against you, definitely give this a try.

I'm an avid video game player, my husband is not. We are, however, both big fans of deduction games - we've played through the Sherlock Holmes: Consulting Detective board game together and have solved every case.  

When I told my husband about Contradiction and how it looked to be a video game version of the Sherlock game we loved so much, he was initially skeptical. It took no time at all for him to get into it. We streamed it from my laptop to our tv and played almost 13 hours together over the course of a couple weeks, finally solving the case without using any cheats. It was so much fun to play this cooperatively. The acting, full motion video graphics, and script are all top notch, the atmosphere is eery, and the mystery is great - it's extremely satisfying to catch a suspect lying using the contradiction mechanic.

Highly recommended! Please pick this one up, at 10 dollars with over 10 hours of gameplay, you're paying a buck an hour. It's totally worth it. Support small game developers - especially this one so we can see a sequel!

33116843.review:
Man there are so many things about this game that are quite good.

For the most part the gameplay is great - it's purely based on logical deduction & most of the contradictions aren't that hard to find; there's one or two based exclusively on gameplay footage much earlier from the game that you probably wouldn't remember or rewatch to see, which is a bit unfortunate, and one or two that only vaguely tie together nicely, but the majority make sense and it makes the gameplay experience feel really organic, there's not really a lot of handholding (unless you want it, as the game does provide a system to give you hints should you need it. My only other gripe is that there is the occasional moment where you just have to wander around until you trigger a cutscene & the game gives you no indication you can't progress until doing so but it is kind of predictive of player actions, not knowing what to do leads to wandering and inevitably to finding the solution you need, so, fair enough there.

The story itself is really engaging too, dealing with some... weird stuff for sure, though unfortunately leaves a few too many loose ends dangling for my liking - the game ends just with solving the mystery of the murder while many other plot points go unresolved. I know the developer plans for a sequel but I don't feel it's reasonable to leave these plot points hanging, at least a few of them felt pretty major. But in general the atmosphere is great and the story keeps you interested.

Presentation wise... okay maybe this is on me but the video was very glitchy the whole way through, though other than being a bit distracting at times it didn't really have a major impact on the gameplay itself. And the acting is all pretty solid, though one characters' audio quality felt really off. The UIs are all pretty basic but work well enough too and the music keeps the atmosphere feeling tense.

For the price the story is fairly reasonable in length too - I spent around 10 hours though a bit of that was spent idling doing other things, and someone picking up on the clues a bit faster could cut that down even more so, something like 8-12 hours depening on the type of player you are I guess (and if you don't use cheats which I never did). Replayability is fairly low though.

All around a great package though & I'd definitely be looking forward to a sequel, if one of those ever gets made.

This game was an incredible surprise for me. Really amazing. Story had me pulled in. I expected over-the-top campy cheesy acting, and although the acting was a bit campy, it wasn't like "so bad it doesn't know it's campy."

The characters totally work in the context of the game. Everything feels great -- not too dry, not too "animated". The writing and acting really surprised me.

"But have you seen.... THIS?!"

Gameplay-wise, it is an FMV game and the gameplay itself is pretty simple, but it delivers a solid experience.

I'm a /huge/ fan of murder mystery games and VNs. This game managed to scratch my Phoenix Wright itch really well.

You go around exploring the town, talking to people, collecting evidence and keywords, and you use those to question other people, call them out on their lies and back it with evidence, etc.

I've nothing but fond memories of this game.

32793810.review:
This is my first FMV game, and I had a blast with it.

You take control of Inspector Jenks who is called out to discover what happened in the death of a young woman named Kate. 

The game's map is fairly small, and there's a quick travel option so you don't have to click too much. 

As you progress through the game, you'll meet new people, question them, find new evidence and try to figure out the mystery.

The main point of the game involved you finding contradictions (hence the title) that each character may or may not say. This requires you to match up one clue with another that contradicts it, leading to their admitting of a lie. 

The acting is quite good, a bit cheesy at time but in a fun way. There's a nice ambience and interesting enough story to keep you going as well. 

The FMV never brings down the game, and I always felt like I was the one in control. It's a very cool title, and even not on sale, $10 is still a great price! I spent almost 8 hours playing through once, and for that much you would see a movie for 2 hours, so why not put that towards this? 

If you get stuck, there are guides online, but I definitely encourage players to figure as much out as they can on their own, it's much more rewarding. 

Anyway, if any of that sounds interesting, give this little gem a try, you'll love it if you enjoy murder mysteries!

32772026.review: Contradiction is a charming Detective Sim/Interactive Drama. Every aspect of gameplay is comprised of well shot live action video which, rather than make the game feel stiff and camp, actually feels very fluid and immersive. To progress through the game, players must assume the role of Police Inspector Frederick Jenks and spot contradictions in the testimonies of the colorful denizens of an unassuming, quaint village, in order to discover if the recent, supicious drowning of a young student is suicide or something more sinister. While I found the story to be well written, and quite well acted, near the end of the game it did come a bit off of the rails on both counts. However, the story did wrap itself up nicely, and even left itself enough in the way of story to provide a possible sequel, which I will certainly play should it come to fruition.

32764009.review: the hammy acting only makes it better

32738142.review:
I really liked the game. I know it had a really small budget, but the entire game looked very professional. I do prefer real actors and real video over animated games, because real people have so many micro expressions that it is simply impossible to take all of them into account and make animated game look "real". The actors were all good and I think all characters had some depth in them and you could notice some personality traits just by looking at the way they said their lines! Spotting contradictions wasn't too hard but not too easy either. Game has a cheat system which you could use to find out what to do if you got really stuck, but the right way was most of the time deducible from the in-game futage.

Game worked very well, although sometimes it got stuck and you couldn't click something, but I was always able to get around it without having to forcibly shut the game. It was very smooth and simple, and moving around worked well.

I really don't have much negative to say about the game and I really recommend it! It's a very British detective show type of game, with relatively slow pacing and calm manner, which allows you to slowly unravel the secrets. It worked very well for me but I guess some people could get frustrated by that kind of approach.

32712647.review:
So, this took me 7 hours, for NZ$11.99. I don't think it was worth it, maybe $4.99...
Actual gameplay time (unravelling the story, exploring new content etc.) I would estimate at only 3 hours - I will explain below.

Gameplay is repetitive and time-wasting, a lot of travelling around just to see if anything has changed. To go and talk to one character to the next, takes 4/5 clicks of just moving there, seeing nothing new along the way just places on loop. I guess they do this to add a feeling of additional content/time to the game, but it just felt cumbersome and clunky to me. 

The majority of the contradictions are not intuitive. I used a walkthrough for about a 1/4 of the contradictions, or to know what to do in order to progress to the next hour/chapter, because I would get stuck. The resolution was always a contradiction that made little sense.  Other combinations which made more sense as obvious contradictions, didn't work.

You CANNOT CROSS INTEROGATE SUSPECTS!? The most ridiculous part of the game, even if you ignore everything else. You can only highlight contradictions made by each person, not things that don't add up from other people's statements. 

Visually it is pleasant, but very limited (you cannot look around at all - it is like watching a movie clip at all times).

The acting was neither bad, nor good.  Pretty cheesy most of the time...

The story itself is engaging and leaves you wondering "what next?" a lot - this is what made me play to the end. Unfortunately the story had so many holes and unanswered aspects, that it just left me feeling underwhelmed and rather frustrated.

The ending did not allow you to see the reactions of any of the other suspects/townspeople.

2.5/10.

32527503.review:
OH MY GOLLY

Great engaging gameplay system, excellent mood soundtrack, fluid and snappy interface, fun acting and dialogue, logical puzzles and sensible resolutions, twists, turns and a sense of urgency, and fantastically fun to play with friends.

Downsides would be that the game was woefully underfunded from the start and Baggy Cat didn't get to flesh out the game to their own expectations, so some storylines were cut and the end might be mildly anticlimactic depending on your preference, but even so they polished everything they had to a smooth veneer. 

It's a truly worthy gem for $10, and extra valuable on sale when you can find it. If you're not sure if it's worth your money, go and find a let's play somewhere to get a sense of the first hour or two (levels) in the game.

Baggy Cat can count on my support for a sequel if they announce it!

32515236.review:
Contradiction is a game as charming as it is hilarious.
An FMV murder mystery, you follow Detective Frederic Jenks who has traveled to the small English village known as Edenton to investigate the death of a young student.

The meat of the game consists of moving from location to location in this small village and interviewing its residents about the death. When you someone tells you new information or you find some new piece of evidence, these are added as topics that you can ask the other residents about. Eventually, someone will give you an answer which contradicts something they've said previously and it's up to you to catch them doing it.

The writing and performances in this game elicited more than a few laughs out of me, while still providing a interesting mystery to solve. It toes that line pretty well. I really look forward to any potential follow ups to this.

32339082.review:
I don't understand why this game received so much positive ratings... I mean, it's not bad, but not as good as other said. There's lot of things that doesn't work.

1) Acting is really bad.
Some of the actors act quite well but the others are so bad, especially the main character who over-act each sentence. You can't believe in him one second...

2) You can't talk about everything
If someone said something about another person, you can't ask her/him if she/he doesn't speak about it first. That's the basis of an investigation and make nonsense to me.

3) All contradictions are not recognized
I don't want to spoil but, when someone says "I've never heard of him before he died" and later "I sold him some stuff", there is a contradiction here, but the game doesn't want it. Why ?

4) The story is so cliché
Think about an investigation that take place in a lost small village with a sect-like institute, what do you imagine ? Yes, secret society with some black magic, that kind of stuff. And we're not that far here. So predictable...

5) The investigation is not even legal...
The detective enters back doors, pick up some stuff without a warrant and noone cares about it. He's not a PI, he's a policeman. He can't do that...

But, the game is not that bad neither. The filmmaking is good, the logic behind subjects and evidences works well (most of the time) and, even if it's cliché, the story is well driven.

This is clearly a game with small budget, made by thriller fans, with a good atmosphere. And it deserves to be encouraged. But... it's not the AMAZING game others said here. It is a small, honnest, amateur game with its imperfection and it should be taken as it. That's why I don't recommend it, to warn you about its true value (but buy it still, Baggy Cat deserves to be known and a sequel deserves to exist ;) )

1、到中后期，基本掌握游戏玩法，所有的“矛盾”都是集中在某个人前后矛盾的证言，无法证人之间证言的互相对峙，这样好处是，限定了整个游戏流程，体验集中。但是熟悉之后也降低了游戏的难度，哪怕你记不清楚之前的证言，通过关键词检索和调查回放，你依然能够发现矛盾。

32070938.review: The case presents many interesting threads, developed with care, and the characters are all pretty unique and well characterized (Jenks is amazing), brought to the screen with good, over the top acting. The filming is appropriate and the locales chosen are all beautiful and cozy. The story has a few loose threads in the end, but it's clear the devs are trying to get out a sequel where they'll explain what's missing. The gameplay itself revolves mainly around the titular contradictions, while the exploration and use of items is kept to a minimum and is very simple, as far as the investigative parts go, though, everything works flawlessly and you never feel cheated by the game (aside from the place you have to use the torchlight in: that was bullshit). A nice throwback to the FMV games of yore, with an innovative indie after-taste.

Questo non è un punta e clicca: è più simile ai primi 3 giochi della saga di Phoenix Wright, con la differenza che le contraddizioni le devi trovare proprio nella fase investigativa, così da poter far avanzare la storia.

Per il resto è figo, specie se consideriamo che è stato parzialmente finanziato tramite kickstarter:
- buona la recitazione della maggior parte dei (pochi) personaggi
- l'interfaccia del gioco in è intuitiva e funzionale -- anche se ogni tanto mi è capitato le icone non rispondessero al passaggio del mouse. Consiglio di salvare spesso. proprio il metodo di salvataggio purtroppo è poco curato e il menu iniziale lascia a desiderare.
- quanto a difficoltà , è difficile quanto serve. è comunque possibile ricorrere ad un buon sistema di aiuto che è possibile ignorare nel tutto, ma che in caso di bisogno ti offre un'altra possibilità facendoti avvicinare alla soluzione per gradi invece di sbolognartela subito.

In paio di punti è strettamente necessaria un'ottima conoscenza dell'inglese, perchè altrimenti il rischio è di rimanere bloccati.

Piccola pecca: il finale è lievemente aperto. C'è, ma non è roboante, si capisce che ad un certo punto erano finiti i soldi.

31549384.review:
Contradiction is a fun game.  If you remember the FMV of the 90s you'll be amazed at how far it's come. It really had me thinking of Gabriel Knight -The Beast Within, when 20 years ago  I used the amenities PC (when I could get on it) to complete the adventure - it was a genuine Proustian moment playing this game.  This is essentially a point and click adventure with actors and it seems obvious that they are enjoying it, some real hamming it up at times, it isnt taking itself too seriously but it wants you to have fun - a few real laugh out loud moments.

I started to play it on my own and I had solved the case afer 5 minutes, but the option to ask the question I wanted didnt appear until the end of the game (trying to avoid spoilers here).  If you've played LA Noire you'll see all the blatent lie-tells, but until you've got the evidence you cannot do anything and thats a bit frustrating but it makes the game last longer.  There were only 2 occasions I was a bit stumped and looked at a walkthrough and only of one of those did i think - well thats a bit tenuous. Another bonus was seeing Avon from the cult 70s sci-fi show Blakes 7 (now really showing my age)  - really giving it his all.  Though Rupert Booth, who plays the lead - is really comical at times, it seems apparent that he's really about enjoying himself and pasing it on - taking the mickey out of himself. The best bitch slap ever later in the game - I know Police brutality. There are more than a few red-herrings which were very much left open for a follow on I hope, the ending was a bit scooby-doo.

BUT - this is a great fun game to play and for 7 quid you are going to get at least a few hours entertainment - again it's an Indy game and there is a lot of ambition in this.  It is apparent that a sequel is in the offing - and if its a kickstarter I'll put my money in, because things like this deserve support. I would really recommend you give it a shot - and i'd seriously recommend playing it with  your non-gaming significant other to demontsrate that PC gaming isnt just about blowing peoples heads off -it's an ideal 'gateway' game.

31055774.review:
One of the most well written and well acted mysteries in existence. It took me back to playing Gabriel Knight 2 (but with better acting) in so many ways.  This game actually managed to make FMV good and not tedious. I found myself incredibly drawn to the story and characters.  Janks, the main character, seemed at first to be a bit of an overactor, but he grew on me too. I can't recommend this enough.

I want to warn that this game does dabble in politics. As a center-left with libertarian sympathies, I could easily see the narrative offending some people who are strongly libertarian. In particular, it takes a lot of stabs at Ayn Rand and her philosophy of objectivism. There's literally a cult-like group called Atlas run by a guy named Rand. I was not personally offended, but I know people who could be and I think it is fair to add some warning to this review.

It's a great game. If the politics don't bother you and you like to investigate mysteries, pick it up.

31027431.review:
Cons

[list]
    [*] Strict and linear story detracts from theme of the game
    [*] Core gameplay mechanic boils down to finding very simple "contradictions"
    [*] Mediocre acting and poor audio quality in speech throughout the game
    [*] Several instances of progression being halted by mandatory events which the player has to find by travelling to seemingly useless locations. This results in the player becoming aware of these events as a narrative tool, meaning actual detective work may not advance the story in any way.
    [*] Several instances where the player feels hamstrung by the core gameplay e.g not being able to press for information or use information learned from one character in conversation with another. The options available to the player can be controlled in a very obvious way.
    [*] Annoying lack of continuity with nouns e.g Atlas and 3rd Eye

[/list]

Pros

[list]
    [*] The game does feature a hint button which will tell the player when and where they need to go to advance in the aforementioned unintuitive and somewhat random ways
    [*] Lead character is entertaining
    [*] Good use of red herrings in conversations 

[/list]

[spoiler] Ending is very disappointing. Barely any lead up or drama to final reveal. The use of the tape as the final piece of evidence is very frustrating, any player with a pair of eyes would have seen the tape immediately, and would proceed to wonder why it was being deliberately obfuscated as a piece of evidence or line of questioning. The fact that the player would immediately suspect the correct character is frustrating and ultimately unfulfilling. 

The final "contradiction" to Paul Rand is a frustrating neglect of the rules the game had set a precedent to e.g two statements being very clearly written in juxtaposition to one another. For this one moment only, the player must actually recall an event in the game, after being repeatedly and deliberately denied the opportunity to use their deductive powers. The only time I became stuck in this game was due to the low expectations I had developed over the course of playing this game. [/spoiler]


The game is not terrible and it may not be expensive, [b] but [/b] the amount of time to progress through this repetitive and linear story is simply not worth it.

31022931.review:
Contradiction is a special FMV game that has come out during a time when many games aim for graphical perfection, long epic stories, and interesting combat rather than a shorter more concise story with puzzle based game play. The story is great always keeping the player interested as the story unravels before them as the characters keep telling them well placed lies that can be difficult at times to spot. Detective Inspector Jenks is intriguing and has an aptitude for making me laugh; his interactions with Paul Rand are by far the best part of the whole game. The in game help system is fantastic helping give the player enough information to continue with the game without giving too much away. The cinimatography was professional making it feel natural when viewing the character interations and the movement of Jenks from place to place. The music was subtle creating the right atmosphere for the game.
In all the game was thoughly enjoyable and highly recommended.

30851347.review:
Amazing game.  It's FMV, but it's well done.  The puzzles are almost all conversation based, and involve paying attention to what people are saying.  Of course the game gives you quite detailed notes about the major points that each person you interview says, which makes finding their contradictions a reasonable task instead of an impossible one. 

More importantly, the puzzles almost all make sense.  Only maybe one of them, I think, was kind of out there.  For a game like this, only one is a pretty big achievement. 

I absolutely loved the acting, as well.  The main character is goofy in the best possible way.  The character himself is serious, but the acting is just . . . perfectly goofy.  I don't know how to describe it.  Watch the intro sequence and you'll see what I mean.  

Overall for a game developed on a budget, it's extremely well done.  Probably the best FMV game I've played outside of the Tex Murphy series, and a lot of the reason I'd put them above this one is just because there's more to them.  This is an 8-10 hour experience at most, probably, and it left me wanting a lot more at the end.  If this were the first chapter in a series of games, I'd buy the rest in a second.

Highly recommended.

30434463.review:
It's the rare case of a good modern FMV game. Takes between 5-10 hours to complete and see everything (depends if you are stuck or not and if your are compulsive enough to talk to every characters about every clues). Charming and memorable characters with good acting, mostly serious but there is some hamming to it. A good balance I would say. The main character, the detective Jenks, is like a cross between the 10th Doctor and Columbo. You need to find clues and interrogate people to find contradictions (lies) in their statements, because of course it's a murder case and you have until the end of the day to find the culprit(s)! Would rate this a 7.5/10 (consider it a 6.5/10 if you can't stand FMVs and a 8/10 if you are a massive fan of the genre).

Cons: 
- the interface is a little bit clunky with some bugs that are not game-breaking (if you can't click on a statement or exit an interview, you need to view again any video, it will debug your cursor). I recommend the mouse interface and not the keyboard one. Don't bother with a controller.
- the save function is not well implemented (no auto-save and when you save it is not always apparent that it worked, but for me it worked 100% of the time). Don't forget to save manually. You only have 2 slots to save though.
- the game windows launch offscreen and you don't have settings about it, but the fullscreen works, so it's more of a nitpick really.
For a very small budget title, these flaws are understandable.

Pros:
- No moon logic. For the most part, it's easy to advance in the game and it's probably impossible to get permanently stuck. The game is generous with the tips.
- the main gameplay element, finding the contradictions, is really satisfying. You will feel like a badass when you will find the less obvious ones. There is a way to "cheat" if you are stuck or, well, you could always check a guide on the Internet but it's really not necessary.
- the intrigue is good enough, you won't get bore.
- gorgeous and real visuals (it's full FMV, no distracting computer rendered backgrounds and effects)
- the acting is definitively top notch for an FMV game, just don't expect any Oscar-worthy performances. 
- my computer is old and it runs very smoothly on it. Loading time is minimal and transitions between locations are shorts and realistic (it's a rare occurence in FMV). The map system is also a great way to navigate more quickly between locations.

Neutrals:
- the ending. It feels rushed but at the same time it's a great setting for a sequel. A lot of red herrings and loose ends could be explored, but the lore is interesting enough on its own even for a sequel  with minimal ties with the first game.
- we have a good chance to get a sequel (neutral because expectations will be way higher for the sequel)
- the music: it is good enough but lacks variety and it is a tad too loud compare to the voice acting for my taste.
- there is no cross-examination between multiple characters' statements, only between two statements of the same character. It makes for a simple and focused game, but a lot of waste potential too. Should definitively be a part of a sequel.
- the game don't overstay its welcome but at the same time can feel a bit too short especially because of the ending. IMO, it feels like the production runs out of time/money to make the ending they wanted to initially. It's still great though.

30342695.review: After the credits, the game's developers write that it was an "experiment".  And it clearly shows.  Some aspects of this game (writing, acting, atmosphere, the mystery until the very end where it just falls apart) are superb.  However, other aspects are very poor.  Setting aside some technical matters with the game (I view this game more as an interactive movie than a game per se so I give it a pass on the simplistic interface), I feel that this game had severe problems in the development of the plot.  The writers often seem to have trouble in finding ways to move the plot forward naturally - often the inspector just something on the ground (I can recall three keychains or fobs that people just seem to drop for no reason for the inspector to find).  Then are moments that pull you out of the game, when the main character's behavior is simply bizarre and unnatural.  This was particularly the case in matters involving police investigation methods (he frequently behaves more like a burgler than an investigator) or in how he responds to threats of violence to himself or others (shrugging and acting exasperated instead of calling in armed backup to arrest everyone in sight). And the conclusion was very disappointing.  It might have been meant as a twist, but you spend 90% of the game investigating strands in direction X and it turns out in the last interview that actually it was direction Y and the guilty party just confesses for no apparent reason.  Still, for the price I enjoyed my time with the game and have no regrets in purchasing it.  The acting and writing were frequently very good.  I hope the developers try again and that their next experiment goes better.  I would definitely like to see what they can do with a bit more experience!

30325805.review:
I will admit before I start that this game plucks a couple of nostalgia strings for me. First. I really loved the old point and click adventure games and Contradiction has some elements of them in its mechanics. Second, I have a soft spot for FMV games, as flawed as they can be. 

Pros:
-The cast of Contradiction is really fascinating to watch. Even though Inspector Jenks (played by Rupert Booth) gives off weird reactions and skirts the edge of acting hammy, I couldn't help but laugh and enjoy him. The Rands were so sinister in their own ways that I couldn't wait for the next moment I had to talk to them. Heck, even some of the side characters had their own moments that made me laugh. Sure most of these performances are wacky, but they're done in a way that let's you know they know what they're doing and they're not breaking your immersion like a bad FMV game would've done.

- The main mechanic, going through interviews and spotting contradictions (well, most are, but a few aren't really contradictions by definition), does something I really appreciate: it makes you think. Some of these contradictions can be hard to pick out, you'll have alot of clues and pieces of conversation to go through, so there's more work you'll have to do before you reach your conclusion. However, once you do you feel good about yourself and say "ha, got you you lying SOB!" 

- The narrative as well is interesting. There are multiple threads that come up that could lead you think you know what's really going on and they all are legit. Even when I got to the ending I still enjoyed how it transpired and how the game's creators played with your expectations. 

Cons:

-This doesn't bother me as much, but this is a short game. If you're perceptive and/or using the tip system, you could probably beat this game within 3-4 hours. If you're hoping for a long game, this isn't for you.

-Not replayable; there isn't no new game plus or extra material after you beat the game. Again, this does not bother me as much, but this will be a turn-off for some.

-I will not get into spoilers, but...there are going to be alot of open plot threads that it might irritate you when you reach the end. I'll admit, I thought they'd close some of these plot threads in the end. Unfortunately, that is not so. It is true most of this was because the developer hit their budget limits and that they want to return to this story in the future to jump from those plot points. However, that is just an explanation, not an excuse.

Nevertheless, I think most that enjoy narrative focused mystery games will enjoy this one. There's enough elements in here to keep you engaged in solving the mystery and chuckle while you're doing it. 30061380.review:
Contradiction is an FMV adventure/murder mystery game that originally released on the iPad in January 2015 before launching on PC six months later. Thankfully, the interface for the PC version was changed to acknowledge the different input schemes between the two; while it's not the most visually appealing interface, it's functional.

You play as Detective Inspector Frederick Jenks, tasked with looking into the supposed suicide of one Kate Vine, a PhD student found by the lake in the small village of Edenton, having drowned. You go about this task by exploring Edenton looking for clues, bumping into people, and asking people questions about evidence found or given by others. The people you interview aren't always telling the truth, however, meaning you have to pick out when characters make two statements that are at odds with each other—these namesake contradictions—and Detective Jenks will give them a chance to explain themselves. These mechanics work decently well, although it can be frustrating when statements that logically should be at odds with each other aren't considered contradictions, and having to explore all of the areas of the village to find the one area that has a scene that will advance the plot can be annoying, especially due to the fact that the transitions between areas are completely unskippable.

The entire game is shot rather well, but has a few spots of less-than-stellar audio quality—excusable, given the rather tight budget constraints the game was made on. It's never bad enough to be an actual problem.

Speaking of audio, the soundtrack (and indeed, most (all?) of the game) was made by Tim Follin, well known for pushing the hardware of '80s and '90s consoles and computers to the limit to produce some amazing soundtracks. While Contradiction's soundtrack isn't as recognizable as much of Tim Follin's earlier work, it manages to set the mood perfectly.

The acting and writing is fantastic. Jenks is goofy and exaggerated, which can feel a bit at odds with the more naturalistic tone of the rest of the actors, but I find the contrast between Jenks and the others amusing, especially when up against some of the "obvious bad guys" of the cast. My only real complaint with regards to the writing is that the mystery is solved before many of the other questionable things you find along the way are resolved, setting up for a sequel that might not happen, unfortunately.

It's not perfect, but I have no doubt in my mind that it [i]is[/i] worth your time, if you're interested in it. Just cross your fingers that a sequel gets announced at some point. I want to know how the rest of the story ends.

29850491.review:
If you like adventure games and classic "who-dun-it's", then Contradiction is up your alley. You are Inspector Jenks and have seven hours to solve a murder in a secluded English village. As you may suspect, there is more to the town and its inhabitants than it seems. 

Simular to LA Noire, you interview various people in town and try to spot the liar. How? By finding the contradictions. The more they talk, the more likely they will slip up and contradict themselves. Challenge their contradictions to learn more and progress the story. The game starts you off easy, but ramps up the difficulty gradually throughout the game as you collect more conversations and more information about a wide variety of inquiry. 

Don't worry. If you ever get stuck, you can always phone the chief to hash out what you've learned so far. I did this several times. By listening to him and Jenks talk it out in a new way, it was always enough to put a new perspective on what I had learned and push me in the right direction. This is different than a "cheat" which actually gives you the answer. Try not to use those. There are several achievements to be won by not using them. There is something else...

It's live action!

FMV games of old, like Wing Commander 3 & 4, used FMV for part of the game play, but Contradiction does so 100% of the time. Navigating the town and knowing what to ineract with are made obvious through text and picture overlays on screen. Remember, the "game" is solving contradictions, not a pixel hunt. And to this games credit, the narrative never felt "jumpy", like in other story driven games, like Telltale's Walking Dead. In that game, there are obvious jumps in the script depending on the choices you have made with odd camera cuts and disjointed dialogue. That was not so here.

Clean, crisp and enjoyable. Time to get moving Jenks. The game is afoot.

29623368.review:
tl;dr ->

if you like detective stories mainly because you of "you said X but here i have Y and that means Z - explain this to me!", this game is made for you. get it now.

for the more patient ones ->

i + my wife finished this game in 2 sessions. we did get stuck a few times for a while, but never had to google for answers or use the cheat option. if you pay attention to the details, you can get to all the answers you need, which is a big plus for the game. its exactly how it should be. there are no weird leaps of logic that you need to do to find solutions.

the plot itself has lots of threads, and you can tell the developers wanted to make a bigger game because at the end, many questions are still open (but those only belong to "side quests" so that's ok) and some things are hinted at, but never explored. ti doesn't harm the overall game, though.

the "investigation style" is quite idealized, that is to say the detective steals every object he can get his hands on if he needs it for something, goes through other peoples private stuff (and gets away with it) and nobody ever refuses to explain a contadiction once you pointed it out so it's not realistic in that aspect. the detective seems to enjoy his job a little too much, and everybody has a few unnecessarily hidden secrets that you can uncover, so in the end, you will encounter situations like "ok i admit i knew this and i had no reason to hide this other than to give you the possibility to find my contradiction"

on the less bright side, there is a ui bug that makes it impossible to click on most things and you have to randomly click around to fix it.

28821764.review:
Contradiction is a very nice murder mystery game. 

The video-adventure is a genre that has already been tried (and mostly failed at) in the 90s but in this game it works and keeps you immersed.

Just like a good mystery book once you start it you won't be able to lay it down. 
There's lots of red herrings that keep you guessing and the ending screams for a sequel.

For an adventure game Contradiction is rather easy. There are few items in this game to be found, if there is anything where you're at a magnifying glass will pop up. Most of the time it will be very obvious where to use an item you get. Sometimes you'll even be able to anticipate certain items because it's obvious you'll need them to progress at a certain point.

This game is mostly focused on the conversations. And that's both good and bad. Good is that you'll learn a lot about the different characters and their relationships like this, it keeps them interesting. Bad is that most of the gameplay is made very repetitive:
You find a clue. You talk to everyone about it. With a certain person you'll discover a contradiction and get another clue. Rinse and repeat. Most of the time is spent running around town talking to everyone about everything, even if it will most probably lead to nothing. Except when it does.

Even if the gameplay is repetitive I absolutely encourage everyone to buy and play this game for its interesting story so the creators decide to produce more.

28791814.review:
For parental guidance, this game has no foul language or blasphemy. No gore with one graphic-ish scene. It does however focus a lot on occult themes and philosophy and has adult themes. 

I bought this as a party game to play with family thinking it would be like an interactive film however you will not complete it in one sitting. This game could be a lot shorter. Much of the information that one uncovers has little relevance to the overall narration. 

The menu system to find contradictions was a bit clunky and difficult to navigate at times. I’d hope to see this improved in a future game.

Found it virtually impossible to progress without using the cheat features in two particular instances. Some of the contradictions were too obscure with no real way to figure out without doing copious reading and guessing. 

Despite the issues, it was an enjoyable game and interesting concept.

28649318.review:
I would definitely recommend this game to a casual gamer who likes murder mystery. It was a surprise when I started playing, not exactly what I had expected.

Purposefully avoiding reading reviews, summaries and clips of the game I dove right in without knowing a single thing about it. It's kind of like playing along with a Murder, She Wrote episode.

The filming is surprisingly crisp quality, so detailed you can see facial hair pores and dandruff on shirts. The acting was good too - my favorite characters were probably James and Ryan. James just because he reminds me of a friend and seems cool (though quirky odd), Ryan because he was a very entertaining, mysterious character - the actor did a really good job interpreting the personality of Ryan. Over all, the characters had a very real feel and as this was filmed in an actual place in actual locations, the scenery of course has a real feel as well. Which really helps to bring it together.

If you are expecting a super interactive game, where you control the walk down the paths, have 360 degree views and such, you will be disappointed. This is a very linear, static game, which is understandable since you are actually playing a movie more so than a game. To put it simply, imagine you are watching a movie and it can't continue until YOU make the next decision (where to go, who to see, what question to ask), the detective in the movie can't piece things together until YOU point out the 'contradictions' in suspects' stories.

Overall, a very simple idea when you break it down to the bare bones, but the execution and presentation of the idea is what matters. And the team at Pneuma Films did a very good job. I hope to see a sequel at some point.


Now all of that being said, the game does have some negative points. Already the linear/static quality of the gameplay will turn off a large portion of people, but I still implore anyone looking for a VERY casual, yet interesting, game to play in between their rounds of CSGO or Fruit Ninja to try it out. It's a short game, only about 6-8 hours if you keep good track of things along with the game system.

The saving system is very frustrating. As far as I can tell, the only time you can save is when you are planning on quitting the whole game (Save and Exit in the Menu). From personal experience, this is a very, very hindersome quality. I... accidentally knocked my tower over while I was playing and that of course caused my computer to shut down. Well, when I got  back into the game, I went from 48% completion to 4%, because I never saved between those two points.

Granted this is my own fault, but I really didn't want to keep quitting the game just to save.

When you are selecting contradictions in peoples' stories, you can't unselect. So, if you accidentally picked the wrong option, you HAVE to pick a second option to get it to clear the first so you can select the appropriate one. Since this doesn't affect the events in game, it really isn't that bad. Just a personal frustration.

This is the first game of it's style that I have played and I highly enjoyed it. 

One 'disappointment' I did have is that I thought it would be more like a Choose Your Own Adventure book than a static mystery. It didn't detract from my enjoyment of the game, but it was a thought that popped up a few times while playing. It would be fun to have multiple endings where you could arrest the wrong person or something.

The second disappointment is a bittersweet one. It was the ending. So as not to spoil it for everyone else, to put it simply I was expecting one thing but got the other. While it really wasn't a bad ending, it just was in comparison to what I was expecting. Which I suppose is something real detectives sometimes suffer in their line of work, lol. But still, it felt good to solve the problem no matter what the out come!

Anyway - if you get the chance to play this game, I recommend it.

Also - You can get all achievements on one play through so long as you don't cheat. I looked up the cheating method just because I was curious how you could even cheat in this game. It probably would make more sense if I tried it, but after reading how to do it, I don't see the point as it would completely ruin the game and the whole point of even playing.

28602509.review:
I spent 5 hours on this game, and got 47% of the way through (to 9pm).  I found the super linear aspect of this game to be quite frustrating.  While the story is good, and the acting is fun, the gameplay killed it for me.  It boils down to:
Foreach Hour
  Systematically visit every location, and ask each suspect every question available.
  Each time that this reveals some new information, repeat this process, until the hour advances.

While some smart gameplay can cause you to skip perhaps 20-30% of suspects, I really don't see advancing much faster with better game play.

The gameplay also stalls out sometimes when trying to find a contradiction.  That requires quite a bit more thinking / searching through already seen dialog.

Ultimately, I chose to abandon this game, not because of how hard it was, but simply based on how linear the gameplay was.  Might as well just watch a play-through on youtube, which is exactly what I did.

I would like to see more interactive fiction like this, but please, improve the gameplay to be much less linear, and reward smart gameplay, versus requiring a brute force to find the solution that the developers wanted.  I think the game designers could have acomplished a 2x or 4x better game, with about the same investment of their time and art assets, just by being smart about the actual gameplay.

Ultimately, I can NOT recommend this game.

26619023.review:
Great game. A delicious mix of Agatha Christie, Midsommer Murders, and contemporary thrillers. You play the part of Jenks, a policeman investigating the death of Kate Vine. As Jenks investigates the case in a quaint little English village, he learns that it may not be quite so quaint and cute after all. Secrets, lies, hidden agendas abound as Jenks learns that there was more to Kate’s demise than meets the eye. 

Harkening back to the golden years of FMV adventure gaming, Contradiction goes some way to recapturing the highlights of that time. FMV adventure games went the way of the dodo in the late ‘90s, due to the rising costs involved and the twilight of the adventure game genre. So, it’s great to see it’s emergence here. 

Now that is not to say that Contradiction has the same level of sophistication of the old favourites of the genre, such as The Pandora Directive or Phantasmagoria, as Baggy Cat was working within a very tight budget. The mechanic is therefore much simplified, but this does add some degree to nuance to the game’s primary mechanic. As the title suggests, the main method of progressing the plot is to spot contradictions and inconsistences in the responses of the people Jenks questions. Catching a character in a lie will usually prompt them to give Jenks a new piece of information to further the case. Some of these contradictions are easy to spot; others call for you to have been paying close attention to cut scenes and the story. As I say, this is a deceptively simple game mechanic, and it gets you to look deep into the story and nut-out who has been telling ‘porky-pies.’  

The acting is quite good, overall. One of the old beefs with FMV games was horrendous actors, but Contradiction—while hammy at certain points—comprises believable and relatable acting. You come to feel like you know the characters, how they think, and what they might be concealing from you. Filmed on location in an English town, the overall atmosphere is great. The music is another high point and perfectly suited to the mystery setting.

I have few gripes with the game, most of which can be attributed to its limited budget. The games UI can glitch out from time to time, but this can usually be solved by performing an action to reset the UI—replaying an answer or moving to a new location. The character of Jenks is also somewhat incongruous. A cop with a sort of wing-bat demeanour, a stickler for the rules and yet he performs several searches without a warrant. Also, he is investigating the murder all by himself. Aside from being able to the call the police chief, there are no supporting officers…in a murder investigation! This is probably a budget issue, to keep the cast list low, but it still strikes one as ‘off.’ It may have been easier to swallow if he were a PI, rather than a cop? My last niggle is that there were occasions where it does seem that characters make contradictions, but the game does not recognize them as such. In the interests of keeping this review spoiler free, I will not go into details. It only happened a handful of times, but it can be quite vexing. 

On the whole, I loved the game. The engaging story and nicely developed atmosphere made for a highly immersive experience. If you like a good mystery, I would recommend you try Contradiction.

26618111.review: I like the idea of revisiting the FMV adventure game genre but the plot for this game just isn't gripping enough. The setting is quite atmospheric (recognisably a damp, creepy English village), and the acting isn't bad, but the story itself lets the whole thing down.  I want to like this game more but it just didn't entertain me enough.

26595412.review:
First of all this FMV game is made by this company http://baggycat.com/#

They claim that this was a low budget production, but how can it be when it has someone famous in it like Paul Darrow? For those that don't know Paul Darrow was Avon in the classic Scifi series known as 'Blakes 7'. Blakes 7 on the other hand was definitely low budget. So with that in mind where is the esky in the game? The cardboard computers with flashing lights? The paper Mache houses? Seriously if this was low budget then they spent every penny the best way they knew how. Sound, music, effects and acting was all pretty much top notch and quickly teleports the gamer into the world of murder.

The biggest appeal to this game is its use of storytelling. You take control of a private investigator known as 'Jenks' who appears to be more a wannabe detective than a real one with his over the top acting, catch phrases like 'Have you seen THIS!' and his careless sloppy police work like handling forensic items instead of using evidence bags. Whatever evidence he does discover would be thrown out of court in the real world because of this. ANYWAY...

As you stroll around the sleepy town of Edenton questioning the members of the town regarding the death of a local girl known as Kate Vine, your task is to interrogate everyone you come across, gain more and more snippets of information and look for contradictions in the statements of each person you interview. Only then can you progress the story further by accusing the aforementioned of a contradiction and watching them squirm out of trouble by revealing more.

Why the death of Kate Vine is even warranted for further investigation in the beginning is beyond me as the questionable evidence regarding her drowning involving narcotics and alcohol seems highly plausible, but what seems to be only as a unwarranted gut hunch is enough for Jenks to knock on everyones door bothering them every single millisecond like he is some type of Jehovah's Witness hyped up on speed. 

Seriously! Every time you find an item, you have to go back and knock on everyone’s door again asking them, 'have you seen this!' Stranger than that, is the fact that everyone seems okay with this and none of them try to take out a restraining order on you. You start knocking on everyone's door at 5pm and you continue to do so every hour until you get to 12pm and the murderer confesses.

While the game has a great use of gradual story telling in a superb delivery deserving of a standing ovation at the Oscars, there are a number of things I thought could have been improved. For one thing there are a lot of loose ends which go nowhere, but only hints towards maybe a future sequel if donations are ever acquired. Secondly the murderer simply only tells you what really happened in the end instead of the gamer getting treated to a cinematic flashback. This seemed disappointing in comparison to many other movie treats you get rewarded with as you progress through the secret society known as 'Atlas'. Thirdly there seemed to be a rather low use of Easter eggs in the background, this surprised me since there were so many opportunities of placement that any crime/gumshoe/sci-fi fans with a keen eye could have been rewarded with. Fourthly there is nowhere i can see where one can buy merchandise from this game like T-shirts, coffee mugs, masks and freedom necklaces which so many have hinted their pleasure towards and finally there is no multiple endings or choice decisions which change outcomes as the game plays out entirely the same way for everybody making the whole journey more play out like a visual novel than an adventure game.

With the above grunts placed aside I would highly recommend this game for everyone, especially if you are looking for a game which you can play with a few around the lounge as it was intentionally designed for that purpose. Regardless of the ending provided in the game I am still personally convinced that Servalan was behind it all, with her new mind control weapon. What really happened well you will just have to buy it for yourself to find out aren't you? As Jenks would say,

"Have you seen THIS!!!" (Holds up a copy of the contradiction game)...

Below is me playing the first chapter there should be enough of an example for you to work out if this is a game for you...
https://youtu.be/rnPD5RJ9MXs

26521568.review:
It's been a while since I played a point and click FMV game. These things were huge back when Myst came out and popularized the genre. This was a nice throw-back to those games, with an interesting mystery to explore.

The premise is simple, you are a detective tasked with investigating a questionable suicide in a small town. Your job is to talk to the victims friends and piece together what happened by finding contradictions within their statements. Without spoiling too much, you soon uncover a deeper mystery, and its up to you to get to the bottom of it all.

The gameplay is pretty straightforward, talk to everyone you can about any evidence you've found, then find out who's lying by catching them in a contradiction. Unlike with most point and click games, you don't have to scan enviornments with your mouse, instead you're given a magnifying glass icon when something relevant is on screen. Another staple of the genre is using items on objects to advance, and again this is made simple. Objects will have a fairly obvious use outside of dialogue, you will never get to the point of trying every item on every thing to try and advance.

If I have one complaint about the game, its that it's a little too easy. With the exception of contradictions, the tip menu directs your investigation very obviously if you ever get stuck. If you have people to talk to, or evidence to find, the tip menu will tell you exactly where to go. Another thing, is there is no way to lose. With no branching story paths, there is no way you can dead end your investigation or get it wrong in the end. As long as you can find evidence and contradictions, you will advance the plot.

All in all I enjoyed the game, though it is more a visual novel than a game. There are no puzzles, no way to lose, and no branching story paths. I will say I thoroughly enjoyed the story, but I do wish there were more paths to take story wise. When the game ends, you feel like theres a ton more to investigate, and it leaves you feeling like the ending was a bit rushed.

In conclusion, its a point and click throwback, with a pretty interesting story to explore, but there is room for a lot of improvement if the game ever gets a sequel.

26124623.review:
3 Stars out of 5 from me. Just finished the game and thought I'd comment.

Contradiction has you playing the role of a police inspector (not a very good one who doesn't carry around evidence bags, but hey). The game consists of you questioning people about a death to determine whether it was suicide or murder. The game part comes with trying to find areas where a witness contradicts *themselves.* 

First, I love that the old FMV style has been updated. The acting was pretty good (a little over the top with some, but not horrible). It's nice to see what can be done with modern day technology.

The story wasn't bad. I read a ton of mysteries and am always very critical when it comes to them. There are two cardinal rules: 1) Checkov's smoking gun and 2) you play fair with your reader.

I found it frustrating that I couldn't learn something from one witness, discover it contradicted what another witness said and then go back and re-question the original witness. (i.e., like you could do if it were a real investigation). You can only find descrepancies in individual statements. I think the game could have been greatly improved had the player been allowed to better simulate an actual investigation. 

#2 is the reason why I cannot give this game full marks. In the very first hour you come across something you should be able to question a couple people about. However, even if you select the questionable statements, the game does not indicate the contradiction. [i]But[/i] that contradiction exists. The game just won't allow you to do anything about it until the end. That's ridiculous. I have watched two let-s plays on this game. Both times the players also picked up on this clue.

So basically, the developers decided they were going to hinge their entire mystery on something people will probably notice right off but [b]not allow players[/b] to follow-through with it. This is not how you should write a mystery. If they need to rely on not playing fair with their readers/players then they need to rewrite until the story works. Make it a red herring. Give them a plausible reason that you only discredit as you continue to investigate.

I found that last big incredibly disappointing in an otherwise fun game. And it was fun. I would consider purchasing a sequel. I just hope they learn how to write mysteries properly by then.
