25955481.review:
FMV games got a bum rap during the 90s, with the advent of CD media, but they have kind of made a resurgence lately, with games like Her Story, the Tex Murphy revival, and now Contradiction. 

In Contradiction, you play the part of a police detective investigating the mysterious circumstances behind the death of a young girl in a nondescript English village. Contradiction plays more or less like a point and click adventure game of old, you move about a location, talking to people, solving puzzles, figuring things out, and advancing the storyline. However, in this case, the puzzles are about finding 'contradictions' in the stories of the characters you question. The main game loop is questioning suspects and finding cracks in what they're feeding to you.

Everything each character says is aggregated into your trusty little notebook, and you have to figure out which pieces of information contradict with each other. 

Once you find a contradiction, you put together the two bits of information that are odds with each other and present it to the suspect. It feels extremely natural and engaging. As the game progresses, you get more and more information, making it harder to figure out exactly where the contradictions lie. Instead of the brainless pixel crawling of old, trying to randomly mixing up items in your inventory to what comes out, or using every item on everything, I believe this game's system actually requires more thought than other games in the genre, and it doesn't fall into the usual pitfalls of "cheapness" of the genre. Even if you're stumped, the game uses a supremely clever "tips" system, in which you call your police department chief, who after being appraised of the current situation will more or less point you in the right direction without giving you the answer.

The game uses entirely real locations, and is professionally, beautifully shot.

An FMV game pretty much lives and dies by its cast, and I think the people here are fantastic. Inspector Jenks (you) brings about the perfect amount of slightly over the top acting, with at times a tinge of modest self-awareness, such as when you ask something entirely ridiculous that your subject would obviously know nothing about. The tone is just right for the game, it doesn't take itself 100% seriously and yet doesn't feel like outright cheese either.

As an aside, Contradiction was developed by famed 8bit/16bit composer Tim Follin, known for Silver Surfer, Plok and Solstice, among others. He has been working in the advertising/film industry for several years, so he knows what he's doing. Like I said, everything is shot professionally and looks very classy. It's almost like an interactive TV show.

Anyway, to any fans of old PC adventure games, I can't recommend this game enough. It has charm to last for days.

25948648.review: We play a lot of adventure games as a family (e.g. Telltale Games, Double Fine, etc...) and this is a great throwback game. The contradiction investigation mechanic works well, but wish there'd have been a way to take contradictory interview points between the suspects. That said, it was really enjoyable and hope they are able to get the support they need to do a sequel.

English review to follow

"Contradiction - Spot the liar", ein FMV Spiel aus dem Hause Baggy Cat.

Ohne große Erwartungen ging ich an "Contradiction - Spot the liar" ran, doch nach ca. 6 Stunden (die größtenteils wie im Flug vergingen) kann ich sagen, dass ich sehr positiv überrascht wurde.

Eine durchwegs spannend erzählte Kriminalgeschichte mit - wie ich finde - größtenteils guten (obgleich oft übertriebenen/zeichneten) schauspielerischen Leistungen und interessanten Figuren. Dabei muss ich allerdings festhalten, dass das Spiel bzw. die Charaktere immer irgendwo zwischen cheesy (wohl sogar bewusst, wie es sich für ein FVM gehört ;)) und richtig gut/überzeugend agierten! Eine Mischung, die stets zu gefallen wusste. Davon ausgenommen war eigentlich lediglich der Hauptdarsteller, welcher für meinen Geschmack etwas ZU  "überzeichnet" rüberkam. Vielleicht war dies aber auch nur der englischen Natur geschuldet, das vermag ich nicht zu beurteilen. In jedem Fall war es bzw. er stets charmant genug, um darüber hinwegzusehen bzw. mit einem Schumzeln abzutun.

Spielerisch bleibt Contradiction - natürlich - dezent zurückhaltend. Abgesehen von einigen Gegenständen und einer Karte bzw. diverser Orte, die man ablaufen kann, beschränkt sich das Spiel im Wesentlichen auf das Finden von Widersprüchen (wer hätte es gedacht?) in den diversen Aussagen etwaiger Personen. Bis auf 1-2 kleinere Logiklücken war dies auch sehr flüssig und spannend zu bewerkstelligen. Schön hätte ich es noch gefunden, hätte man Widersprüche auch überkreuzt finden können, sprich Person A würde Person B z.B. widersprechen in seiner/ihrer Aussage. Aber zum Einen wäre dies wohl zu viel Aufwand gewesen, zum Anderen wohl auch für den Spieler irgendwann etwas zu konfus geworden.

Die Geschichte selbst weiß von Beginn weg zu überzeugen, schafft es trotz relativ weniger Schauplätze spannend weitergesponnen zu werden und in den Bann zu ziehen. Lediglich 1-2 Situationen empfand ich persönlich als fast schon zu "lächerlich" inszeniert, als dass sie sich harmonisch in das Gesamtbild eingefügt hätten, aber wie schon oben erwähnt, das gehört wohl zum Charme eines FMV-Spiels.

Technisch gab es von Beginn bis zum Ende keinerlei Probleme. Als sehr angenehm empfand ich die optionalen Untertitel, auch wenn diese nur englisch zur Verfügung standen/stehen. Allerdings waren die Schauspieler meist sehr gut zu verstehen (abgesehen von 1-2 etwas "rauschigen" Ausnahmen).

Insgesamt empfand ich den Preis dem Spiel sehr angemessen, da es mich über die gesamte Spielzeit hinweg sehr gut unterhalten konnte. Von spannend, mysteriös, abstrus, bis hin zu schallendem Gelächter war Alles dabei. Ich persönlich würde mich sehr über einen Nachfolger freuen, sehr gerne auch wieder mit Detective James, äh Jenks ;) Eigentlich MUSS (soweit finanziell abgesichert) es fast einen Nachfolger geben. Eine Frage hätte ich da nämlich noch... Aber keine Sorge, das Spiel per se ist/wurde in sich abgeschlossen! Ich möchte nur nicht spoilern.

In diesem Sinne,

free to be free! ;)

25820417.review:
Although they are not our typical style of game, my partner and I occasionally enjoy playing point and clicks together. I saw Contradiction and managed to convince her, with a bit of hesitation, that we should give it a shot. We had a lot of fun and laughs with it.

Contradiction: Spot the Liar, is a point and click murder mystery game that revolves around finding clues, spotting lies and contradictions in the characters responses, ringing the Chief, and, most importantly, watching loads of FMV scenes where the characters are portrayed by flesh and blood actors. The story revolves around a the death of Kate Vine, a student of a pretty dodgy libertarian Ayn Rand style business school set in a small English hamlet.

What really makes the game is the acting. In particular, Rupert Booth brilliantly plays Jenks up to 11 in terms of his mannerisms, and comes across as a mashup of Richard 0'Brien and David Tennant. Every sign of the horns he pulls was a source of hilarity, and although it was a little cheesy, it is also incredibly endearing. Another special mention has to go to Paul Darrow, who does a wonderfully sinister and creepy portrayal as Paul Ryan. All the other actors do a great job with their respective characters but it's these two that, for me, stand out the most.

The gameplay of finding clues and spotting contradictions, for the most part, is very solid. There are a few times where both of us felt like the contradictions were a bit of stretch, but for the most part they sit in the virtuous mean of not being too obvious and requiring some thought, while also not being a complete stretch of the meaning of the term. It's difficult to get these things right, and the few times where the game was a bit obnoxious in this regard is totally forgivable and forgettable. 

POTENTIAL SPOILER BELOW

[spoiler] Another weaker part of the game is the rather abrupt ending. I certainly felt that we were leading up to uncovering some big conspiracy, but that never really came to pass. So a little lack of catharsis here, but again, nothing unforgivable. [/spoiler]

Overall, we loved the game, and would highly recommend it, although I do feel like this is probably the kind of game where you get the most out of it playing with other people. I would also love to play a sequel should it ever come to pass, and would be happy to donate to any kickstarter should the need arise.

25790294.review:
Contradiction is one of the best FMV games I've played in years and a very good game in it's own right.
The FMV format does have limitations but it's big strength is having real actors and real locations. That's why contradictions format of a detective trying to piece together a mystery works well. The actors can give away subtle clues, they may be lying or feeling uncomfortable that only LA Noire with it's advance facial capture comes close to recreating.

The characters are all pretty interesting from the very quirky Inspector Jenks, the reserved and frosty Rebecca Rand and of course the excellent Paul Darrow as Paul Rand sneering his way through dialogue. 

The mystery has lots of red herrings and false threads so unlike a lot of mystery games not every clue matters and must be used and sometime the most innocuous thing leads to a big revelation.
That's not to say there are not flaws. Although the video is great quality the sound is a little tinny in some scenes.
Being an FMV game there is a low level of interaction but it suits the format. It can get a little frustrating having to sit through the transition scenes (though they do get shortened)
The interviewing is a bit stop and start as you will find out a bit of information from person A that allows another conversation stream with everyone else. So you have to go round asking each person that one extra question. I swear I knocked on one characters door 30 times and mostly with only 1 extra question to ask.

The menus are simplistic but functional. The clue system generally is good, but can sometimes get stuck on suggestion (you have 5 questions for person A, when that person isn't available to answer them), but overall keeps you from becoming too frustrated. The cheat system will spell out for you pretty much what you need to ask next, as sometimes the contradication can be stretching the term.

Overall very enjoyable, it's different to the usual fare and shows the potential FMV games still have.
Similar games would be the Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective series.

25366063.review:
While Contradiction occasionally falls prey to non-sequitur "adventure game logic," it will be a charming, nostalgic romp for any FMV fan. And, unlike many FMV exercises, the acting manages to be well above-par, though some actors tend to ham it up. Clearly an heroic effort on a shoestring budget, the game is worth a shot even at full price. 

Be aware that whileany reviews herald this game "difficult but not frustrating," I think be conflating "difficult" and "unnecessarily obtuse." When a game like Resonance requires me to open a mathematically locked door, and I pull out a pen and paper for high-school-level algebra, that is upping the difficulty without adding frustration. When Contradiction's in-game hint system recommends that "It's time to check out the woods again" with no narrative justification, it's being obtuse-- and therefore frustrating. The hint system shouldn't be a necessity, but here it clearly is.

I don't really mind, though, because I had extremely low expectations. It is, after all, an FMV game, and very few of those were exceptional (GK2 and Black Dahlia, for instance). Sure, at one point they were touted as the pinnacle of gaming technology, but few managed to become anything but campy (Phantasmagoria 1&2), goofy (Under a Killing Moon-- still fun, though), and messy (Ripper). Ultimately the core "fun" of an FMV game lies in the quality and interactivity of the video production. Contradiction takes smart steps in that direction despite failing as a hardcore adventure game.

I've expect the protagonists in adventure games to randomly pocket/steal items, quipping "Maybe this will come in handy later." If you're not familiar with that sort of suspension of disbelief, Contradiction may not be fun for you-- nor would most adventure games, honestly. The finale in Contradiction, for instance, tosses out a good chunk of previous interviews when a suspect makes a connection between two clues. Yep, even if you already figured it out yourself, you have to ask someone else to do your police work for you. If there were a way to properly examine inventory items, the game could've and should've ended before the halfway mark. It's typical suspense/police drama fashion to have a "gotcha" moment like that, though; in that respect Contradiction is more film than game.

Still, I liked it, I had fun, and I would recommend it to the right audience.

Contradiction is an excellent murder mystery game with just enough interaction to make it fun. It plays like a sort of choose your own adventure style movie. Well, you don't choose your own adventure, there's only one path through the story, but it's up to you to discover the proper combination of button presses to continue along that path. This makes it seem kind of lame, but it is very satisfying to uncover the contradiction in someone's answers that uncovers the next stage of the investigation.

This is an FMV game, which means the whole thing is video. Yes, this makes it kind of goofy, but in such a charming British way that really only makes it more fun. My Wife and I kind of love Jenks, the goofball detective who leaves no stone unturned (especially the ones that happen to fall right at his feet literally out of the pocket of one of his suspects).

You should play this game, if only to get to the bottom of just what the deal is with Simon's Homebrew. Honestly, I never would have suspected it to have gone in the direction it did.

25086953.review:
Hello! TL:DR 9/10

This is the first game (that I can remember) ever deciding to write a review for.  I loved it first and foremost.  Devs, if you are reading this, please read to the end as I have a question about Darrow (an actor's name, no spoiler), and a comment regarding a bug at the end.  As for everyone else... There will be zero spoilers here, but enjoy!

This was a fun and remarkable tale first and foremost.  It is a brave slice through a genre that has far too little games in it (L.A. Noire is the only other one I can think of off hand).  It's engaging, well executed, and, for the most part, well acted.  Darrow was an excellent actor and capped the game off, and Rupert's acting and quirkiness left me smiling (again, using actor's names so no spoilers of any sort).  Being in America, and a Realtor, I absolutely loved the United Kingdom setting.  The images of homes, pubs, and nature has always been captivating to me, and I never got tired of exploring the streets within the story.

The progression often felt realistic, as I can only imagine how little real life detectives have to go off at times.  That being said, while it was often a challenging yet fun experience of finding the contradiction in the townsfolk's statements, there is ultimately only one path, so it varies from L.A. Noire in that sense.  This is something that, if there is a follow-up ever (not that it needs one or doesn't need one necessarily), or if there is a spiritual secessor, I'd like to see incorportated. 

I understand that for the devs, the idea of story boarding hundreds of more scenes where paths are led to nowhere sounds daunting, but it also sounds and feels more realistic.  The possibility to accuse or arrest someone wrongfully or incorrectly would make the game feel more expansive and intriguing, as you'd know there is always a possibility of getting things wrong.

That being said, Contradiction doesn't necessarily need that to still stand out.  It's an engaging mystery that I simply had to help solve.  The story can be slightly linear at times, and repetitive at others.  A few scenes intended to be serious were just impossible to take seriously without laughing, but all-in-all you won't find another game out there like this (as a bit of an aside, there was a game I believe on the Super Nintendo that tried to do something similar to this and it was vile and done poorly; so if you've played that, I wouldn't make your decision to play this based upon it).

In the end the game, for me, earned itself a 9/10.

Now for a quick aside for the devs... I noticed at the end 2 things.  First, a question: Based upon the dedication at the end, did Darrow pass away in real life?  I seriously hope not as he was an excellent actor and played his role to a T.  Second, a comment: At the end, once completeing the game, there is a small bug that keeps you at 96% completion after the credits role, and puts you back in the location you were at prior to experiencing the final scene, however, you cannot click on anything (the ! that means you are in a scene and cannot make an action pops up).  The only way I was able to resolve this was to save the game, close the application via right-clicking on the icon at the bottom of the screen, re-open the game, load my saved file, and then things were fixed.  Doing this gave me the 100% completion, and allowed me to save my game with this standing (although the final achievment for completing the game without ever using a cheat had already recorded itself prior to closing and re-opening).  Hope this helps!

On the other hand, there were the occassional problems with some of the controls locking up, especially if you accidentally "dragged" a button rather than pressing it. Moreover, the list of items to interrogate people about got way too long towards the end, since the game wouldn't remove at least some of the topics that lost their relevance for the sake of the player's convenience.

Finally, some my problems with late plot development in the game are as follows (SPOILER WARNING): a number of threads and themes are opened and left unresolved (a suspicious suicide the previous year, the occult, delivery of poppy pods, etc.); the game's protagonist even mentions some of them in his ending speech, more than just hinting at a sequel. Another plot point that bothered me was how the scene of one character ordering another to "deal with" the protagonist is directly followed by said character meeting the protagonist at a secluded location and not taking the opportunity despite having an armed help at their side and being discovered doing something more than shady. Finally, at some point the protagonist starts insiting that the investigation has to be finished by midnight, although I don't recall any logical reason being given for this arbitrary deadline.

25024568.review: I loved this game. I play a lot of point-and-click adventure games, and my favorites are the ones with a detective theme. This is a detective game that focuses on interviewing suspects and spotting contradictions in their statements. Furthermore, I am glad that this game was made using full-motion video with live actors. I remember when full-motion video with live actors was trending among adventure games. I really have missed playing video games made with this technology.

24984623.review: It's really fun if you enjoy murder mysteries, and the game doesn't take itself too seriously.

24938597.review:
Miluju detektivky. A proto vždy jásám nadšením, když se můžu v nějaké hře vžít do kůže detektiva a přijít na kloub nějakému tomu trestnému činu. A jak moc jsem si užil vyšetřování vraždy v Contradiction?

[h1]Vesnička Twin Peaks[/h1]
Jste policejní inspektor Jenks a přijíždíte do zapadákova zjistit, zda smrt mladé Kate byla sebevraždou nebo vraždou. Musíte se rozhodnout rychle, protože čas nelítostně běží a přesně o půlnoci musí padnout z vašich úst verdikt, co že se tu vlastně osudné noci stalo.

Příběh sám o sobě je už stokrát omílané klišé, což není nutně na škodu, protože je zde uchopeno trochu jinak. Postupně budete odhalovat věci, z kterých vás bude mrazit a dokonce zabrousíte i k okultním věcem. Dál už nebudu nic prozrazovat, přijděte si na to všechno sami.

[h1]Nejlepší možná realistická grafika[/h1]
Hra Contradiction byla vytvořena díky kampani na Kickstarteru, tudíž od ní nelze čekat kvality AAA her. Spíš se tu sešla parta nadšenců a chtěla vytvořit něco nového a do jisté míry se jim to i povedlo.

Možná víte, že v osmdesátých letech byly "in" tzv. FMV hry. V těch byla určitá část tvořena skutečnými herci. Nejznámější bude určitě série Wing Commander s Markem Hamillem, ale já mám na mysli spíše detektivní sérii Tex Murphy. Byla to adventura, kde místo cutscén byli nahráni skuteční lidé. O to více pak bily do očí adventurní pasáže, které vás vhodily do ošklivého prostředí.

Zde na to šli ale tvůrci jinak a vše je tu nahráno živými herci. Úplně vše. Prostředí je vyfoceno, takže realističnost je tu na 100%. Lepší grafické zpracování už prostě nenajdete!

[h1]Ententýky... [/h1]
Samozřejmě, že Kate někdo zavraždil a na vás bude odhalit onu osobu. Důležitých postav tu je málo, zhruba sedm, o to více ale dostane každá z nich prostoru. Zde mě překvapila jedna věc, a to kvalita zahraných rolí. I když tu jsou jisté kiksy a někteří herci se občas chovají špatně, v drtivé většině případů je jejich herectví dostačující a navíc je tu i jistá grotesknost.

Ta jde nejvíce vidět na hlavní postavě, inspektorovi Jenksovi. Ten dělá různé grimasy, neustále přehrává a vám? Vám to vůbec nevadí. Ona se tahle hra nebere zas tak moc vážně, i když je pravdou, že párkrát vás z ní bude mrazit. Ale obecně tu přebírá otěže právě komediální stránka, která tomu všemu přece jen sedí o něco lépe.

[h1]Tam a zpátky[/h1]
Největší jádro problému hry Contradiction tak vězí v její hratelnosti. Musíte procházet menším okolím, sem tam použít nějaký předmět a jinak mluvit a mluvit a mluvit s lidmi. Každá z postav vám něco sdělí, to se vám připíše do deníčku a zde přichází hlavní deviza hry, která se dostala i do názvu. Pokud si někdo protiřečí, vezmete danou větu a vložíte ji do rámečku. Tam také vložíte další větu, jejíž tvrzení se neshoduje s tou první. Pokud je vše správně, dané věty zezelenají, Jenks prohodí prosté "Aha!" a vy můžete sledovat, jak to dává dané osobě pěkně sežrat. To je tak, co se týče hratelnosti, vše.

Hra je rozdělena na úseky po hodinách, takže začíná v pět hodin odpoledne a poslední kapitola je ve 12 hodin odpoledne. Každá kapitola má pevně dané hranice, kdy v ní musíte usvědčit ze lži určité lidi a poté se můžete posunout dále. Čím dále jste, tím více lokací a akcí máte i přístupných, a proto se vyplatí projít vždy celou mapu.

Zde se bohužel objeví první mínus hry, kdy se prostě někdy od vás očekává, že jste věštec. Mě se třeba dařilo výborně, ale neviděl jsem jednu cutscénu, která se měla odehrát v lese, proto jsem se na několik minut zasekl. Jak jsem měl ale vědět, že tam mám jít?

[h1]Čas ubíhá[/h1]
Další špatnou věcí jsou paradoxně ony rozhovory. Občas jsou tu věty, které si zapíšete do deníčku tak vágní, že vám prostě nedojde, co si protiřečí a jednou dokonce musíte spojit dvě nesouvisející stopy! Musíte prostě předpokládat, že se tyhle dvě věci nějakým způsobem ovlivnily a to mi nestačí. Bohužel zde musíte vybírat vždy věty jen od jedné osoby, nejde tedy vybrat jednu větu od osoby A a druhou větu od osoby B.

Pak to jsou i samotné otázky a předměty vašeho zájmu. Občas působí křečovitě. Nejlíp to šlo vidět asi na Simonově kole. To si takhle jdete kolem domu, všimnete si kola a hned se všech lidí ptáte, zda ví, že Simon jezdí na kole. Na to vám většina lidí řekne, že o tom nic neví a vy si tak říkáte, proč se ptáte zrovna na tuhle blbost. A pak, těsně u konce hry, po téměř šesti hodinách, tuhle věc využijete. Hurá.

S tím bohužel souvisí i další zápor a tím je rozpolcenost celé hry. Chápu, že ne vše se bude stáčet automaticky k oné vraždě a že určité věci jsou prostě slepá vodítka. Ale vy tu zabrousíte do takových různorodých témat, až se mi občas i obracely oči. Jelikož nechci spoilerovat, budete mi muset v tomhle prostě věřit. Kromě vraždy Kate zde proberete tolik věcí a budete se jimi zabývat, i když zcela zjevně nemají s oním ohavným činem nic společného. Tenhle bod se nejvíce projeví právě na konci hry, kdy si uvědomíte, že tu zůstalo tolik nezodpovězených otázek, až se vám z toho i zatočí hlava.

Posledním zjevným záporem byl pak i samotný konec hry, který byl takový nijaký. Ukončení každého díla je důležité, protože někdy dokáže do propasti strhnout i zbytek hry, byť byl jakkoliv kvalitní. Víceméně se tu vše vyřeší tak nějak samo, nepřichází žádná katarze, žádný pocit zadostiučinění, žádný pocit, že to VY jste to vše odhalili a zíráte tak na titulky s pocitem, že konec mohl být o dost lépe vyřešen.

[h1]Plusy[/h1]
+ originální zpracování
+ dobré herecké obsazení
+ zajímavé postavy
+ hra se nebere až příliš moc vážně
+ zajímavé spojování protikladných vyjádření
+ délka hry kolem šesti hodin (možná nevypadá jako moc, ale hra aspoň není nudná)
+ čeština (odkaz na konci)

[h1]Mínusy[/h1]
- občas nějaký herec extrémně přehrává nebo nehraje moc dobře
- rozpolcenost témat
- někdy působí dané otázky křečovitě
- takový nijaký konec hry
- záseky ve hře, které jsou způsobeny tím, že nejste věštec

[h1]Konečný verdikt[/h1]
[b]Mé hodnocení: 6,5/10[/b]

Hra Contradiction jako by popírala sama sebe. Na jednu stranu je tu výborný vizuál, herecké výkony a lehkost, s jakou procházíte hrou. Na druhou tu je pak rozpolcenost témat, křečovité otázky a špatný konec, který vám ponechá takovou pachuť na jazyku. Zkrátka a dobře - pro detektivy je tohle nutnost, ostatní by koupi měli pečlivě zvážit.

24823518.review:
Well... I really enjoy this game!
First, I must say that English isn’t my mother tongue and I’m now a video games player in his 40ies ..

So, Yes, I’ve played all the FMV video games from the 90ies : Gabriel Knight, Phantasmagoria, the 7th guest, etc. 

This game is way better, regarding the “movie part”, if you compare to the “first generation” : everything works smoothly and in “HD” good looking. Actors are good in this game. You play a real video game and not a “VCR recorder games”…

It’s an investigation game, so you will need to do the errant boy, in order to get facts, objects or to meet people...
The story is rich and you need to be prepared to a lot of  unexpected developments …

The interface is easy to get with and I can’t find any big flaw. 

If you are into “investigation games”, this is a good one ! 

Now, If you are a non-native English person, you will need to play with the subtitles on…

The most difficult part in the game are the contractions : it’s really easy to search and find the right facts: you will need to check all the answers of the suspects… Luckily, you take notes 

The only drawback is the way that Baggy Cat carries on the story : you need to go to the wood in order to see specific acts … and  to revive the “general story”…. It’s a little bit “unnatural” but if you are stuck you can check the light-bulb and get a tip, in order to unblock the story.
It’s easy and it’s not really cheating… because, Yes, you can cheat in this game (but you won’t have all the achievements of the game....) 

A very good and affordable game…

I hope to see more of Baggy Cat’s games in the future !
Thanks for Contradiction !   :-)

24771547.review:
Overall, this was a fun mystery for anyone who may want to play detective.  The main character, Detective Jenks, played by Rupert Booth, was a bit on the goofy side, which keeps the story light and fun.  The background music (By Tom Follin) sets the tone perfectly.  Paul Darrow gives a brilliant performance as the sinister Paul Rand--the sort of character you love to hate.  The story was a bit strange, but this kept things interesting.  My only real complaints are: 
1) the game mechanic in which you must spot the contradiction from the same character--this became a bit of a frustration in that you might spot a contradiction between two characters but be unable to pursue it.
2) Once you start, don't plan on doing anything else for the next twelve hours.

I recommend this game.  It's a bargain.

24767694.review:
The acting from certain characters is a little eccentric, but not in a bad way. The camerawork was very professional looking and the actors' lines were delivered well, which would have made the game particularly immersive if the map didn't open abruptly every time I wanted to go from street corner to street corner. Gameplay never seemed tedious, even after visiting the same characters multiple times; after a lengthy introduction video the first time you met someone, every subsequent conversation cut right to the chase.

I absolutely recommend the game to anyone--regardless of your interest in detective games; I myself was less than thrilled by the concept of a point and click detective game until I played this title. I would love to see Jenks make a return in a future sequel. Congrats to the developers, the actors, and everyone else who took part in the production for making an excellent game!

24714953.review:
What a phenomenal game!

So, contradiction is a dedutive adventure game where you investigate a murder in a small English village. As the game goes on, you go around town, collect clues and information from people, and then find mismatchinf info to crack them and further progress the game.

And this simple concept is executed brilliantly! The whole game is filmed with live actors who do an outstanding performance and have wonderful dialogs, the mystery is top notch and is full of surprises, and the puzzles actually stretch you quite a bit - especially by the end, when you have so much information to work with :D It feels amazing, like you are a real detective on a case! I wholeheartedly recommed this to anyone who loves adventure games, mystery solving and just awesome detective movies!

24663629.review:
My goodness, I cannot say enough about this game, but I will try to keep it short. This is by far one of the most engaging games I have played in years. Solid proof that a good story done in a restrained and carefully crafted manner can be better than all the bells and whistles in the world. I have an Oculus Rift that I have been obsessed with over the last few months, and this simple video based game literally made me forget about my Rift for a week. Now that is saying something!

Did I mention the story was amazing...it's amazing. Kudos to the writers on this project. Probably the best game story writing I have seen since Jane Jensen.

The video, though supposedly done on a budget, was very well done, especially for an FMV title. We all know how bad they can be at times. Not here. Solid camera work, and a very defined and artistic style. Music also did wonders in this title. The mood was always perfect, and did so effortlessly.

The navigation can take a bit getting used to, but once you get the hang of it, it is very effective. Few minor tech issues with things not being clickable unless you go back and come back into a menu, but otherwise very solid.

This one is worth full price, and honestly compared to some games I have played, worth even more than asking price. Do not pass this one up!

24661470.review:
This was a fun game!  The video aspect was refreshing, with real people instead of computer generated avatars and characters.  It was like an interactive movie with an interesting plot and characters that were a hoot.  It was paced well with a nice balance of easy and hard contradictions.  There were a couple of contradictions that were a little far fetched but overall if you reviewed the clues you could get to the contradiction.

 User interface -  I used the mouse so I can't comment on the keyboard UI option. The user interface worked well - you were able to get the job done without having to deal with hassles in figuring out the UI.

A good game and definitely worth the money.  Let's see a sequel!

24657960.review:
This game treads the line between serious and unintentionally hilarious in the best way. 

As a guy that didn't play any FMV game before this I don't have any nostalgic ties to it but if they're anything like this one then I really missed out and I need to track some down. 

While it is true that the ending can be a bit disappointing and doesn't wrap up every plot line, it's bevause the dev wasn't able to put in everything he wanted due to budgetary restraints, which is a shame since the plot you do solve isn't the most interesting one in the game.

There is a lot of fun to be had with this game though, despite it's obvious low budget and if a sequel ever comes up on kickstarter I know I'm going to be donating to it.

24607962.review:
結論から言うと、ミステリー好き（+英語がわかるor翻訳ツールや辞書など使って、自力でなんとかできる人）には超オススメ。
「矛盾」がわからない人、英語が理解できない人にはススメない。

◆良かった点
・イギリスのミステリードラマファンは結構ハマる内容
・キャストに有名どころがほとんどいないが、さすがイギリス人、みな演技がうまい
・矛盾を突いて真相を暴いていく、という、「逆転裁判」的な操作方法
・動画画質が良く、動作が軽い
・セーブ・ロードが早くて、操作性が良い
・詰まったときでも、ゲーム内のヒント（チート）だけで進められる

◆改善してほしかった点
・チート回数をカウントしていながら、それによるおまけモード的なもの（Jenksの捜査スキルを評価するなど）が何もなかった
・日本語字幕をつけてほしい
・次回作に続くのか、続かないとしたら、もやもやが残るだけのラストシーン

◆感想
イギリスのミステリードラマファンとして、一本のドラマを見る感覚で楽しめた。Paul役のPaul Darrowさんは、スパドラで放送された「Law & Order UK」に判事役で出られていて記憶に新しい。村の外れにある湖で溺死した女性の死の真相を、半日で解き明かすという設定は、一見無理があるように感じるけれど、８０～９０年代前半の推理ゲームファンにとってはとても胸アツ。コマンド総当たりでなく、論理的な思考がカギとなる推理方法は大人のゲーマーのみならず、若くても論理的思考が好き・得意なミステリーファンにも受け入れられるのではないかと感じた。英語教育はアメリカ英語で受けて来た人間にとって、イギリス英語は聞き取りづらいが、字幕があるのでわかりやすい。また、イギリス英語独特の言い回しを知ることができて英語の勉強にもなり、一石二鳥。このゲーム内容で、この値段は安すぎると思う。ぜひJenksシリーズの次回作も作ってほしいと思うし、その製作費もまたKickstarterで募集するのであれば、次はぜひ寄付したいと思う。

24450848.review:
I adore this game, highly recommend!

[u]Pros[/u]:[list]
[*]Good, solid acting from everyone* 
[*]Seamless FMV with the environment, looks really natural
[*]Good mystery story, with lots of small details that keep being added as the evening progresses
[*]I’m very glad they didn’t go with the obvious bad guy, and that they kept you guessing until the end
[*]The contradiction gameplay is fun, makes you feel involved and a little bit like a real detective
[*]Love the small English village atmosphere[/list]

[u]Cons[/u]:[list]
[*]Sometimes it’s hard to know which contradiction the game is looking for. I would see some that the game didn’t recognize, and sometimes I couldn’t see what they wanted me to put together. But most of them were fair, in my opinion[/list]

*The main character, Jenks, can be a bit hammy and over-the-top, but I think it added to the overall charm. And also the other people’s reactions to him are funny. He is constantly calling his boss, and his boss sounds a bit exasperated. He keeps calling at people’s houses throughout the evening, and I thought if this wasn’t a game, these people would be frustrated. And when the night goes on, they do start rolling their eyes and everything. It really became a part of Jenks’ character for me.

24420869.review:

24411850.review:
I don't normally write reviews for games, but this was so exceptional, I needed to gush about it. This is easily the most intellectually stimulating and funny mystery game that I have ever played. Unlike most "mystery" games, in order to solve the case, you need to apply logic and thought into detecting inconsistencies in the stories of the witnesses, rather than just finding a new piece of evidence on the ground. Also, the all-video aspect of this game made it amazing to watch. I deeply loved all the actors and the way in which each brough their talents to the table.

I highly recommend buying this game if you love campy humor or are looking for an intriguing mystery to delve into!

24409506.review:
What do you know... ABOUT THIS??? 

A truly enjoyable FMV game for every fan of the adventure game genre, especially those who are into detective work.

You are investigating the crime of a woman in a small town. As you go around the village and gather evidence and information, you can talk about your findings with the villagers you interview. In order to advance in the game, you must spot contradictions in their answers (hence the name SPOT THE LIAR!). If you're truly stuck (and this WILL happen), you can always telephone the chief of police to give you a few hints.

New characters, places and objects will be unlocked with every passing hour and the plot will thicken to an extent you wouldn't have thought.

PROS:

- Beautiful settings
- Enthralling story
- Excellent actors
- It's challenging to spot certain contradictions, which adds a lot of fun!
- HD
- It's an FMV game, which had been forgotten for a long time, and it's very nice to see it's back in such a great title

CONS:

- You haven't bought it. BUY IT NOW!

10/10

24401594.review: I didn't believe that a live-action game would turn out as well as Contradiction did.  It has a linear plot that accepts only the sequence of activities that it wants, and to me some of the contradictions you're looking for require information you don't have.  This is the very rare exception to the general rule that the flow is logical.  Consumer advisory:  Pay VERY CLOSE attention to the way that responses are written in the notes provided.  If you miss a word, the contradiction is much more difficult to find and the connection requires much more effort to find.  One thing I did miss in this implementation is that contradictions between characters aren't fair game.  That is, if different characters give you different versions of a situation, that isn't a contradiction -- a contradiction exists ONLY a character contradicts himself.    Perhaps contradictions between characters require a lot more effort to supply data allowing them to be resolved, and the timeline is much harder to implement.  Grumble, grumble -- what am I bitching about?  I REALLY enjoyed the game as it was released -- maybe too much since I started thinking about how it could be improved.  Improvement is NOT really that important:  buy the game and enjoy what's there, dammit!  I thought the performances were really well done, although I kept rooting for Jenks to take off his hat (play the game and you'll get it.)

24326777.review:
A good game with some clever puzzles! Some of the actors are quite good-- some are overdoing it (which may have something to do with their direction).

The story is rubbish, though. Red herrings in a mystery game are one thing-- but massive and largely unavoidable trips into interesting, but ultimatly unfulfilled plot lines leaves you feeling like this game is the first part of a multi-part game and that the ending to this one isn't good enough to warrant your intellectual investment. After you let that feeling sit with you for a bit, you start to realize that the majority of the play time was just having you on.

That said, there's some smart social commentary in here about Ayn Rand and her brand of insanity. Rather liked that.

At the end of the day, Contradiction was engaging. And I'd look into more games like this now. FMV certainly has a place in the modern day.

24323866.review:
Enjoyed watching and playing along with Jenks in this murder mystery game. Most contradictions are easy to find although there were a couple ones that stumped me hard enough for me to have to peek at a guide and then subsequently slapping my hand over my forehead for not thinking simply and clearly. Game design-wise, the point-and-click adventure is straight-forward and simple which I find welcoming. There's no combining objects or looking for items amongst a setting, it's really just moving Jenks and clicking the magnifying glass when it appears. That's it.

Story and film-wise, I enjoyed all the actor's performances including the possibly overexagerated motions and facial features. Audio is the biggest issue that should be improved upon especially where there's echo and noise in some of the rooms. It's only an issue when it's not a conversational scene.

Whether you enjoy a good story, like mysteries, and don't have a problem with simple point-and-click mechanics, this is a game that you can enjoy interacting with and watching with popcorn in your hand.

There isn't really any replay value though which I hope, if a sequel comes to fruition, will offer more branching options, endings, and choices as this story is very much linear.

24205289.review:
...wow. That was really really good. It's 4:30 AM for me right now because I didn't want to stop playing until I finished! I learned about this game from a Let's Play, but I actually stopped watching after the first video because I already wanted to buy it and play it for myself. And boy am I glad I did; I can't recommend this game highly enough!

The story was incredibly engrossing, and it left me thirsting for more. Jenks is fabulous -- his facial expressions are perhaps the best thing about this game. There were a couple points where I knew /what/ the contradiction was but had trouble figuring out the precise pair of statements to trigger the cutscene. It was also a little frustrating that info you got from one person couldn't be used in a conversation with another person (besides the things added to your "inventory" anyways). Sometimes (especially after rewatching a clip and stopping it partway through) the buttons on the side would just...not work anymore. And sometimes the screen would flicker like it was trying to play a different clip before realizing it wasn't supposed to. Ok I'm stopping with the negative things now because I'm probably making it sound terrible, but honestly I loved the game so much that these weren't really that big of a deal to me.

When you start out, this seems pretty straight-forward. A girl died, but the circumstances of her death are a bit odd, so you're investigating. As you start to learn more, things get so bizzare that you can't help but want to dig even deeper into what exactly is going on. Actually, the way it progresses reminds me of my programming job. By the end, the solution seems straightforward in hindsight, but it took a lot of work to realize how straightforward it was. But despite the amount of work needed, the process makes your understanding of the situation so much deeper and richer that the time is well worth it.

This game is just begging for a sequel, or at the very least something more with Jenks! Please make it so I may throw my money at it!

24173623.review: Recomend to anyone who loves cheesy but awesome games. Can't wait for a sequel!

24154063.review:
I finished this game in one sitting of a little over 6 hours, and absolutely loved it!

Pros:

1) The acting is good. Not "Hollywood movie" good, but quirky and entertaining where it needs to be and serious where it doesn't. I loved it. Jenks, Ryan Rand, and Paul Rand were tremendously amusing. Everyone else was fine as well, of course. But they were the stars.

2) The music isn't too bad.

(Though it does have its troubles, mentioned below in the "cons" section.)

3) The scenes are shot well and the transition clips are good.

4) The look of everything is enjoyable.

5) Unpredictable, at least to me. I had no concrete ideas (only educated guesses) regarding who was responsible for what up to the end. Everything about the clues and what it gave you to work with was very interesting, and its narrative weaves an intricate web.

Cons:

1) The UI was a bit buggy a couple times. The first time I spoke to Ryan Rand I couldn't exit and had to restart the game (thus forcing me to do the conversation again). But I never had that issue after and the other minor UI issues I had during interviews weren't game-breaking.

(Be sure you save semi-often! Perhaps after every round of questioning on a new clue.)

2) The ambient noises had a mild sound of compression that I could hear, and being something of an audio engineer, I found it slightly annoying at first, but it stopped bothering me pretty quickly. I also have the EQ set on my PC in such a way that these noises might appear to me when they may not to others (necessary for when I edit audio).

3) The music is cool and mostly fitting, but nothing overly memorable, and while I did also list the music in the "pros" section, I will note that a couple of times the music that started during certain scenes for mood continued into other parts such as interviews and sort of drowned out the actors as they spoke. I tried to correct for this by adjusting the (limited) in-game audio settings, but that didn't actually resolve the issue entirely. The game does have subtitles, however, so at least there's that, and this wasn't that big of a difficulty. It only occurred twice or so. I also found that closing and opening the game once stopped the music from playing. Regardless, I suppose they could've cleaned this up a bit.

Rating:

9/10.

Contradiction is definitely worth the price (I'd pay a little more for it, to be honest), and just the right length for someone like me who doesn't have too much time to devote to games.

I hope there's a sequel!

P.S. This is the first game that I've ever bothered to review on Steam.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of murder mysteries and the click n'point genre. I think it's brilliant that instead of just trying to find clues, the focus on the game is about trying to find the contradictions in the characters stories. I've played some games with FMV (granted it was in the 90s) with Gabriel Knight II and some of the old sierra games, and so seeing this revived with better footage makes me happy. The controls were easy to understand, the acting while cheesy in places is actually very good and really amusing. If you want a good story and a fun time, I would recommend buying this game. I do hope there is a sequel.

It should be noted however that if you're hoping for one of those laughing happy endings from like murder she wrote where everything is wrapped up in a bow, you might have a bit of trouble with this game. 24059537.review:
Love loved it! What an enjoyable ride. While the subject and themes were disturbing, Inspector Jenks' performance gave the game much needed lightness and humor, and the two balanced each other amazingly well. 

Critiques: The difficulty could be raised. I never had to use a cheat or a walkthrough, by which I don't mean to pat myself on the back, but rather to say that as a non-detective I would've liked to struggle more. To be honest, I would cut the "tips" option completely. It told the player exactly where to go, who to talk to, and when there was nothing left to do but sit in front of suspects looking for a contradiction. Eventually I just stopped using them as I started to feel more like I was just leading Jenks through the game than actually solving a mystery by myself. Instead, I'd pull more focus to the Cheif calls. The subtle tips the Chief gives are more than enough to lead you in the right direction of who to ask about what and were amazingly emmersive. I even caught myself scratching my chin a couple times over his words! However, I didn't think the game did a good enough job highlighting the Chief as a rescourse, or using in-game hints to let the player know that now would be a good time to call him (i.e.: maybe Jenks inner monologue after disturbing events/interviews). 

Continuing with the difficulty idea, it would be nice to have the magnifying glass icon traded with an interactive screen of sorts. If possible, maybe a way to scroll through views of a certain area? For example at the jetty: (SPOILERS) the shot used does not display the ground plane of the jetty, yet after clicking the magnifying glass Jenks finds the broken pendant lodged between the wood panels. If there was an investigate mode, or something that could allow the player to look and click on suspicious objects for themselves (IF they can spot them out!) would lend HUGELY to a sense of acomplishment.

On to audio/visual aesthtics: The music and ambient noise was wonderful, though the former could be a bit repetitive.  Also, a few other recordings of Jenks' "aha!" noise for found contractions would be nice. Lastly, I was a little disappointed with the video-editing decision to make everything "blue" for nighttime; however, knowing that the budget was low, that time contraints are a factor, and that high-quality video/lighting equiptment may not have been avalible, it's a passable offense as it got the changing time-of-day message across.

Despite all of that, so SO much fun!!! As the game progressed and my percentage completed climbed, I had to keep reminding myself that good stories must end, and so did this game. I can't say that my heart didn't beat a little bit faster at the prospect that ATLAS would return! Look forward to my name on the kickstarter. Bravo!

24035169.review:
I have been here for the last ten minutes trying to work up something that would express my feelings and give this game the justice it deserves. That said, this is very much a classic point and click adventure with what at first glance may come across as almost a gimmick. That is the fact it's actually a well shot movie instead of the usual 3d graphics we are used too. This while seeming odd really does the game good as it sets it apart as the actors help sell the story being told here. If you are a fan of point and click or if you missed out on the great heyday of the point and click adventure games this is a great pick up for you. It isn't perfect but it is solid and really shows the care of its creators and its actors. I would like to see this game get the sequel it so deserves. While it might seem somewhat expensive at first glance the value for money is there. I find it more enjoyable than some movies I have paid for to rent or to own so don't let the price be the ultimate deciding factor in this.

Pros:
[list]
    [*]Engaging Story
    [*]Good quality video
    [*]Good actors, especially when you look at how much they had for a budget
    [*]The "Chief" tip system is very solid and very good at helping you get back on track
    [*]Integrated cheat system for when you are really stuck
    [*]Solid audio and it's really nice to see subtitles available
    [*]Actors do a good job of "telegraphing" when they might be hiding something
    [*]Reasonable price
    [*]Easy to follow logic (anyone who has played old school point and click games can understand how this is a good thing)
[/list]

Cons(these tend to be very minor annoyances):
[list]
    [*]The hints the "Chief" give can come off sounding a bit cryptic at times.
    [*]No real replayability, but this is common give the genre
    [*]While the acting is good there are a few scenes and lines that come off cartoonish or they break the fourth wall a bit.
    [*]Would be nice to have the option to skip some transitions
[/list]

TL;DR: Solid point and click detective adventure game, with good acting and a good story. Suffers from lack of replayability but makes up for it with a unique take on interactive storytelling and point and click style games. Worth the money, if $10 is too much to spend at this time, then add to your wish list and pick up your first chance you get.

23997419.review:
[use Google Translator, foreigners]

Contradiction: The All-Video Murder Mystery Adventure é um jogo no estilo FMV onde você acompanha a investigação de um suspeito suicídio, num vilarejo britânico. Esta investigação se dá através da análise das entrevistas com os habitantes locais. Através do registro das falas das personagens, o jogador é capaz de perceber contradições e usá-las para confrontar o suspeito, possibilitando, assim, que a história prossiga, eventos surjam e o jogo avance. O jogo se passa em 8 estágios, cada um representando uma hora do dia, com a investigação começando às 17h e terminando meia-noite. Para avançar-se uma hora, é necessário detectar essas contradições que serão o gatilho para o desenvolvimento do enredo.

O jogo é bom e prazeroso. Quem tageou ele aqui na Steam tem que tirar aquele "rpg", pois tem zero elementos disso aqui. Eu adicionaria "puzzle", já que você só joga se souber pensar, basicamente. O que ele peca, na minha opinião, é criar muito gancho para uma possível sequência e não priorizar o plot principal em si. Se a sequência for impraticável, terá sido muito recurso e tempo destinado em vão. [spoiler]E é um tanto anticlimático fazer um auê todo sobre um provável satanismo e corporações malignas para no fim ser o basicão passional de sempre. Sem falar que em meia hora de jogo já se é possível ver a pista suprema da história, mas os criadores te forçam a usá-la apenas no final showdown da coisa, rç.[/spoiler]

ps: a atuação não é ruim, povo. Vamos parar de usar como critério técnico o produto onde o ator está inserido e sim a performance dele? Tirando os coadjuvantes masters, que deviam ser pessoas da vizinhança que pegaram para ajudar, todo o elenco principal foi bem bom, principalmente a parte feminina. Agora é torcer para que consigam outro crowdfunding e saia um Contradiction II.

23875494.review:
I just completed this game, and I've got to say - for a low budget Kickstarter project, it was great! (For a FMV mystery game, there was definitely room for improvement, though.) This is a spoiler-free review.

+ Acting was actually pretty good, even though Jenks was a little over the top from time to time. (I feel like that's just fine, though. I enjoyed the quirkiness of the character.)
+ No completely subjective puzzles
+ Good score

= The calls to the Chief are used like a rail system which progress the story. I like mysteries I could theoretically solve all by myself without the introduction of outside information.
= There are forced story points which occur simply by wandering around the map at the appropriate time. I tended to use fast navigation whenever possible to cut down on loss of momentum, but would occasionally be presented with a scene I didn't realize was coming.
= Recycled footage, while a great cost management move, did get a little old after watching it for long time.

- I found the middle stages of the mystery far more challenging than the earlier or later stages. This was probably due to the sheer number of possibilities, but also due to subtlety. (Guess I'm not as clever as I'd like to think!)
- If this game occurred in reality, Jenks would have died from the exhaustion of walking back and forth so many times. There are unavoidable navigation clicks that the push pins don't help you jump past.

Please make a sequel, and please price it under $10. If you do, I'm in!

I hope that means this sets up for a sequel, because otherwise it feels like a betrayal of the genre.

[/SPOILERS]

Either way, the gameplay is smooth and the tempo nice. A nice 3-4 hour experience.

I have never reviewed a game before on Steam despite my large number of them largely because most others are already saying what I think. But having just completed this game I see this as highly recommended. Yet I feel like I was just traumatized. The last two sessions I played of this were simply because I was pot commited and I wanted to see how the story ended. It's hard for me to articulate why exactly I dislike this game without some degree of spoiling but I won't so don't worry. 

The tragedy of this game is that the start showed such promise and the writing was solid. But by the end of the game the lack of technical polish and writing chops is so visible to be painful. It tears me up to be this negative because i'm sure this was put together by a passionate group of good folks. But the eponomous Contradictions range from vaguely clever to unbelievably convoluted and obtuse. Further the climax and final chapter is contrived to the point of being laughable. Characters suddenly do things for no reason and the ultimate reveal is so anti-climactic but is played straight to the point of mellow drama.

To put it concisely this game ran out of something, I don't know if it was money, or time, or patience. But this bears all the signs of someone setting out for something much grander, but then having it all collapse and having to build something workable out of the ashes. A noble effort, but do not waste your time like I wasted mine.

This was a great mystery game. It's unique, interesting, and most of all, fun to play. The game comes with a built-in hint and cheat system that is very forgiving; this is in fact one of my two complaints. It feels like mystery games shouldn't be this easy; you get directions and suggestions on where to go anytime for no penalty. My other complaint is that there are parts where it can drag on a bit, but otherwise, it's good.

I definitely recommend this game if you're looking for a new mystery game to play.

Also, I definitely want a sequel to this sometime.

I will say...okay, I have three complaints. There were times where it took me an unnecessary amount of time to find a contradiction. Some are hard to spot, which is good, but each conversation gives you only tidbits of what was said, and the vague descriptions + vague connections can make figuring it out hard. And you can't contradict between witnesses, you can only find contradictions within the person's own testimony.

23426207.review:
This is a FMV detective & mystery game developed by Baggy Cat, created thanks to a kickstarter campaign. Since I love detective games and tv-shows I decided to give this one a go. This is a lovecrafted masterpiece, great from start to finish. I'm gonna try to explain why.

You play as detective Jenks, investigating a girls suicide in an english village. Mysteries surrounding the suicide quickly leads to a murder investigation. Jenks only have a day to solve the mystery. He quickly finds out about a private school for adults called Atlas that uses some questionable methods, and you learn more and more as you go. Every chapter is an hour in the game, but every chapter took me more then an hour each. It's a pretty tricky game, but you can use clues if you get stuck.

 You interview people that live in the area and find clues. You look for contradiction, opposites, that a character has said and use that against him/her. It's very exciting and satisfying when you prove that someone is lying.The FMV is very nicely done, captured with HD cameras and different view-angles. They re-used a lot of footage for the enviroment and moving, but added filter to it once it got later at night, a quite smart technique actually. It's made by a small studio with limited resorces after all.

Jenks is very funny, and he really acts out. You will smile a lot during the dialougues. Don't get me wrong though, the voice actors did a great job. Most of the characters are very serious, so it's kinda nice that Jenks mixes it up a little with some humor. The best actor is the boss at Atlas, he is an old grumpy man with some great lines. 

You can also find the FMV game on IMDB, if you want to see the list of actors. Score is at 8,9/10, which is a really high score, but I think Contradiction deserves it. I looked up some of the actors and they have been doing lots of movies and shows before. They feel believable which is of course important in a game like this. I could never figure out who the killer was until the end, and the plot was great.

I won't spoil anything, but let me just say that the ending is kinda open for a sequel. Yes, you do get a satifying story from beginning to end, but there is some loose ends that scream for a sequel. Things that weren't investigated enough, characters that obviously had more to them. I looked at the forums and comments on the internet and it seems like everyone just wants more, a follow-up game. It really hope so too, because I really like these sorts of games.

There was some spooky moments in the game, or somewhat creepy at least. It added to the mystery in a nice way and it keept me playing until the end. The old english village with stone houses, lots of wierd things going on and with a bunch of intrigues between the characters just gave me that "murder in midsomer"-vibe. You know, that english tv-show about a chief inspector solving crimes. I really love that, cause I think england is a good place to film these sorts of detective FMV (full motion video) games.

Overall I really enjoyed my time with this game. It was different, and I love to combine two of my favorite things, crime detective drama and video games. I would recommend this game to anyone else interested in this sort of experience. I hope this game get the success needed to fund a sequel, because I really wish to find out more about the village, the characters and some of the unsolved mysteries. This experience is worth full asking price, no doubt.

This is a great game, not particularly difficult but not a breeze either. Excellent value for the money at the current price, and must-have if/when it goes on sale. The players are wonderfully odd, and several of them give a lesson in how great actors can be seated most of the time and still chew the scenery. About the right mix of live action and finding contradictions, and the clue system covered just about every sticky point. A little repetitive on comings and goings but transitions are quick, so not much time is wasted. 

As the game description suggests, this would be an excellent game to play through the TV for a group, but probably could not be finished in a single get-together or party setting. Also, I see little replay value unless you want to more closely parse the dialog.

Part of the enjoyment for me was the English village setting, great locale! The video quality is excellent.

Wikipedia says the developer had some headaches putting this together but I really hope he makes the proposed sequel, and he can count me in.

22593240.review:
Contradiction is not perfect by any means but still a decent game and worth the price. Everything is HD and the audio quality is good, but they do just slap a colour filter on some scenes to make it seem later in the day. A small detail but I found it a bit odd.

The acting varies from great to being a bit campy. Overall I didn't mind but the main character, Inspector Jenks, did come across as too 'happy' or 'nice' when he is supposed to be investigating suspects in a murder case. Paul Darrow as Paul Rand was superb though.

My two biggest complaints are that you can't actually get the wrong person and the inventory is a bit of a mess.

You progress through the investigation 'one hour' at a time and are supposed to solve it before midnight. But time only passes when you reach a certain point in the story and confront a character with contradictions in their statements. Until then time doesn't pass in-game, so the time limit is a bit arbitrary. You also can't fail, something which would have been interesting but is not explored at all and would have added some replay value.

The 'inventory' is cluttered, including items (screwdriver, torch etc.) as well as evidence to present to suspects and statements to ask them about. But when you are interrogating someone you are given a list with all of them in, even things you can't actually speak to them about and items that you only use once in the story. They are colour coded but I think that splitting them up would make a lot more sense and make the questioning sections a little more streamlined.

It's a decent enough story, they set up/tease the possibility of a sequel which could be good. It doesn't have ridiculously tedious adventure game style puzzles but still makes you pay attention to what is going on. Overall I would recommend the game to mystery and point-and-click fans who want something a little different.

22575209.review:
This game is great! It has a fun puzzle dynamic that's a little bit similar to something like L.A. Noire, but that requires more actual thinking on the part of the player. The acting is suprisingly really solid, not overly campy or godawful like a 1990s FMV game. The guy playing Paul is freaking intimidating. It's also got some sweet horror elements, and the writing is mostly great. The story is like Law & Order mixed with Call of Cthulhu. If that sounds like something you want to see, you will probably like this game.

It's also surprisingly long for something that costs $10. It probably will keep most people busy for a good 6-8 hours, depending on how much you cheat. Which is quite a bit longer than most of the Telltale episodes, which usually cost $15.

If you like detective games, adventure games, or horror, this is a must play.

22281833.review:
Началось всё со здорового скептицизма. А как ещё может быть, когда видишь новость про то, что бывший видеоигровой композитор внезапно объявился на площадке Kickstarter с планами создать небольшое посвящение FMV-играм, бывшим довольно популярными в первой половине 90-х и очень быстро исчезнувшим с горизонта, не выдержав конкуренции с развившимся 3D. Масла в огонь недоверия подливала ещё и очень скромная сумма в 3000 фунтов, которую запросил автор и которой, по его мнению, должно было хватить на то, чтобы не просто разработать, а снять адекватный и на сегодняшний день визуально актуальный "живой фильм". 

Получился первый блин далеко не комом. Да, поначалу игра пестрила багами, но на сегодняшний день это вполне полноценный продукт, в который даже опциональные субтитры завезли, поэтому сейчас её можно смело рекомендовать и тем, кто английский язык на слух понимает кое-как. 

Играть предстоит за эксцентричного инспектора Дженкса, расследующего вставшее в тупик дело о смерти студентки в небольшой Английской деревне. Ваша же работа как игрока заключается в том, чтобы помочь инспектору с поиском улик и — что самое главное! — противоречий в показаниях опрошенных им свидетелей и подозреваемых. Несмотря на то, что фигур, как-либо связанных с трагедией, немного, головной боли они вам обоим создадут немало. Как и полагается свидетелям, заочно подозреваемым в убийстве, все без исключения они будут врать, не краснея. По такому случаю Дженкс носит с собой небольшую записную книжку, куда заносит все важные факты, полученные от опрошенных жителей, и тщательно высматривает в них любую нелогичность. Внезапно заметив, что у кого-то из опрошенных факты друг с другом не клеятся, Дженкс может наведаться к нему и накатить на него бочку, прямо уличив во лжи. Так и проходит игра: находится новая тема для разговора, инспектор всех о ней расспрашивает, после высматривает нелогичность в их показаниях и добивается более честного ответа, который зачастую рождает новые темы для разговора, и всё сначала. Небольшое техническое ограничение кроется лишь в том, что инспектор Дженкс не может искать противоречия в показаниях разных свидетелей относительно друг друга. Поймать на вранье Вы можете только одного человека и только на основе того, что он сам Вам сказал. Это немного сковывает игру по части разнообразия ситуаций, но несильно её ухудшает. 

И Вы не представляете, как интересно это оказалось! Даже уже в самом начале игры попытки найти расходящиеся факты методом перебора оказываются малоэффективными, поэтому волей-неволей приходится вчитываться в содержимое записной книжки главного героя и искать хоть какой-нибудь намёк на то, где же свидетели облажались. Никто не станет Вам подсвечивать важный для сюжета текст, а во время опроса над протагонистом не будет появляться никаких восклицательных или вопросительных знаков. Задачу отделять воду от значимых реплик игра возлагает полностью на игрока. Но Contradiction очень дружелюбна к игроку и предлагает два уровня хинтов. Использовать оба вида подсказок можно без ограничений (но второй уровень не даст получить часть ачивок в версии для Steam), только захотите ли Вы? Ведь подобный лобовой подход к поиску улик и противоречий в показаниях свидетелей заставляет себя почувствовать настоящим следователем, который копается в этой рутине и выискивает в потоке информации хоть что-то, имеющее отношение к раскрытию преступления. Самим разработчиком, кстати, рекомендуется проходить Contradiction коллективным разумом, и я даже немного жалею, что не последовал совету.

Не очень хорошо продуманный интерфейс вполне может подпортить впечатления от игры. Все темы для разговоров, все выуженные из персонажей факты, все сюжетные и не очень предметы — всё лежит в одном и том же пункте меню.И если поначалу серьёзных проблем с навигацией в недрах сумки протагониста не возникает, под конец игры она превращается в такой бардак, что большую часть времени Вы будете только продираться сквозь потерявшие актуальность темы и искать те, которые имеют к текущим событиям непосредственное отношение. А ведь ещё надо противоречия искать...Несколько сказывается мобильное происхождение игры, заточенное под сенсорное управление, но авторам действительно следовало бы скомпоновать рабочий инвентарь инспектора более эргономично.

В любом случае,игрушка хорошая и к прохождению настоятельно рекомендуется.

Full Review: https://what-used-to-be.blogspot.ru/2016/03/contradiction.html

22113350.review:
Overall this was an engaging game.  A simple interface, good audio/visual quality, and pretty well written.  The idea of comparing pieces of interviews to catch people in a lie was new and interesting, although sometimes some of the "contradictions" seemed a bit of a stretch, while other times something that seemed clearly out of place didn't count as one.

I do have a couple complaints.  For one, you can't skip any of the video transitions between locations, which can start to grate your nerves if you go back and forth a lot between some locations.  Also, most of the acting is very well done.  Most of the suspects' testimonies feel very natural, and a couple feel comfortably heightened (a bit of moustache-twirling, without being fully cheesy).  The protagonist, on the other hand, is irritatingly exaggerated.  As an inspector looking into a potential murder, he almost comes across like he's having a good time and not taking any of it seriously.  Everyone else is playing it straight, while he's hamming it up.  I called him many bad names in my head while playing.

Without giving anything away, the door is left open for potential sequels, which I'd be glad to see.

22089202.review:
Encore un jeu qui montre que le FMV peut être exploité de bien belle manière. Les vidéos sont de bonnes qualité, les acteurs jouent tous particulièrement bien (pour un jeu vidéo), et on se croirait vraiment dans la peau de l'inspecteur Colombo !

On a affaire ici à une véritable enquête à résoudre par le biais de nombreux interrogatoires. Le concept est ici de faire parler nos suspects de tous les sujets possibles, jusqu'à identifier des incohérences, menant ainsi à de nouvelles découvertes. C'est évidemment de plus en plus dur étant donné que les sujets s'accumulent.

Dommage toutefois que ce soit le seul mécanisme du jeu (la collecte et utilisation d'objets représente une part négligeable). Mais c'est réussi et il faut se creuser la tête pour mettre en évidence les bonnes pistes, et éliminer les fausses.

J'espère qu'une suite verra le jour.

21983498.review:
Pros:
Gorgeous FMV at modern HD resolutions and well-acted performances from the small cast
Detective Jenks chewing up all the scenery is an acquired taste but I thought it was hilarious
Story takes twists and turns you wouldn't expect
Mouse only control style is brilliant and allows you to navigate very well
Paul Rand (Paul Darrow) is an excellent sneering antagonist and I'd love to see more from him in a sequel
Nostalgic design stays faithful to FMV games of old
Leaves you wanting more


Cons:
Abysmal ending - you're questioning someone about something relatively minor and they pretty much shout ALRIGHT I KILLED THEM FINE YOU GOT ME out of nowhere
Some of the navigation is confusing, the woods in particular
Some characters fall flat particularly one who just stares into the fire and says "no" to every question. Questioning him seemed pointless at some point.
Some of the contradictions are a logical stretch and many contradictions exist that aren't rewarded because all the characters lie so much and so often. Sometimes the solution is obvius, often you have to trial and error your way to win.
Menus and UI are drab, overly complex and unappealing to look at.

Contradiction: Spot the Liar was a Kickstarter project that could have used more funding. Every aspect of the game struggles against its limited budget but that gives it some element of charm. I'm a huge fan of detective style games like Ace Attorney and Danganronpa but something about cracking the lies and contradictions wasn't as satisfying in Contradiction as in those titles. I think a sequel with a more freeform environment and ability to investigate every nook and cranny for evidence would work better.

Overall I loved streaming Contradiction for friends and would recommend it to anybody who grew up with FMV games like Phantasmagoria.

21967762.review:
This game is a cosy investigation played out in gorgeous FMV segments. You progress the story by walking between locations in a sort of Google Maps fashion, and interviewing the characters you find in the hopes of making them contradict themselves. The overall feeling is one that players in the UK will recognize if I say "weekend evening ITV murder mystery". It's a police procedural that has more in common with Poirot than The Bill.

The core mechanic gets a bit wobbly once you're a couple of hours in, because the list  of available topics is so long that it's impossible to hold it all in your head at once, and spotting contradictions is a matter of scrolling up and down the list, reading off each point at a time until something you spot something. And them hoping that the game recognizes it as a contradiction, because not every instance of contradictory text is necessarily something that will move the game forward.

It's charming in setting and cinematography, and the acting is winningly hammy, so the niggles with the problem-solving fade away, especially since a lot of it is easy enough that you can just keep propelling the story forward.

21942124.review: Absolutely loved this game! I was fully immersed from beginning to end, and felt adequately challenged throughout. Inspector Jenks is a charismatic protagonist who I would very much love to see in further sordid investigations!

21911019.review:
This is one of the best FMV games that I've played, if not THE best one. That isn't to say this is a flawless masterpiece, there are many problems, but there are also alot of positives.

I'll start with the negatives - and this is my biggest complaint. The clue/hint system itself. As you progress through the game your list of possible contradictions naturally grow, making it more difficult to scroll through the list and decipher the short, vague descriptions of what the character said. I think to counter this, there needs to be less possible contradictions, perhaps separate them with "interest" notes that act as a reminder of what the character said. Also, there should be more to it than simply selecting and combining two statements; introducing evidence as part of the contradiction adds more variety and, well, sense.

Another problem is the lack of direction... it's as if the game doesn't know whether it wants to be linear or not, forcing yourself to explore every location multiple times throughout the night, or use the hint system (which you will be using ALL the time). I would have preferred if the game was linear, only being able to explore areas that are needed, and introduce a sort of point 'n' click mechanic where you move the mouse over things in the room rather than a generic magnifying glass.

With that, I think the rest of the game is absolutely phenomenal (especially given this is an FMV game). My favourite elements are this game's writing, music and story. Whilst it IS your bog standard murder-mystery detective story, there are certain things this game does that spice it up, adds flavour, makes it more... involving and personal. For example, I just love seeing the short clips as Jenkins walks up to a house, or turns a corner, or up steps; showing his shoes, his hand opening a door, or his awesomely smug face that you can't help but smile at. And speaking of Jenkins, he's a loveable character, acted out well and is my favourite character of the game. However, this isn't to say the acting for every character is amazing, certain actors I feel weren't up to par or tried too hard to the point where their dialogue and execution felt unnatural. I won't name names, and I did on-the-whole enjoy all the acting, but these two characters stuck out to me as being below average.

There's also the "aha" eureka moment when you finally find the contradiction, Jenkins will confirm this with a Tomb Raider 2-esque "aha" that Lara Croft does when she finds an item. Which is awesome. Another game I feel like this is similar to is Scratches, another game set in England, with an English cast, and offers another murder mystery with a plot twist or two. I mean, even in both games you report to your colleague about updates (Scratches was Jerry, here it's the Chief). Then there's the whole British setting to it that I like and can identify with. The village this is set in was a nice change from the typical towering urban American and I like the lighting and the fact the game takes place in the evening 'til night, the idea of hours progressing based on your own actions is a neat, immersive, organic way to approach progress.

I won't spoil the ending, but it does leave some threads hanging, and not in a good way. Certain characters seem to have disappeared off the face of the planet, collected evidence which were completely useless and character statements which are pointless filler. Having said that, some of that unnecessary digester flavour is what makes this game more life-like, as a real detective won't have perfect results with each candidate.

In the end, I loved the game despite its flaws, I wish they offered a downloadable soundtrack as I feel it was put to good use, the tingles and bells as you explore and find out more about the murder sounds great and as if you're making it closer to the truth. I can recommend this game to adventure lovers, movie-goers or people looking for a nice, relaxing, charming, well-written mystery presented in a clean, HD format.

21898744.review:
这游戏真的非常非常的有趣，和看了部电影一样，而且真的有种警探的感觉。没有波澜壮阔的冒险，作为玩家所能做的仅仅是从纷繁复杂的线索中，找出他们的矛盾。很多对话其实都没什么用，但正是这种从无效信息中挑出有效信息，并与后面的信息发生矛盾。这点非常非常的有趣。虽然没有中文，但是有基本英语能力的人玩起来都不会太困难，可能有些词需要字典，大多数时候都没有障碍。如果真正喜欢玩推理游戏的人建议入手，英语不应该成为这个游戏的障碍。
