21816020.review:
TLDR: Highly entertaining, worth the price, well crafted, something we looked forward to playing, Took a little patience at first.  

Being completely honest, I was not impressed by this game at first. My SO and I bought this as something to play together at night after the wee one went to sleep.  The main character didn't strike me as fitting the bill at first and some of the acting was so cheesed up it made me think I was going to regret my purchase.
We were quickly persuaded to continue, however, after a few well placed lines here and there. Deliveries that perfectly tied in to the mild frustration experienced early on while trying to ask everyone everything. 

"If i were to do THIS would it mean anything to you?".  As if the inspector knows in advance that it's a waste of time...

There are many aspects of the acting and deliveries that made us cringe, being lovers of Brittish murder mysteries, but after playing for a bit the humor of the game become a bit more obvious. The hammed up lines here and there, the over- acted reactions, and the characters that were briefly thought of as out of place become perfectly suited to their roles.  After the first night of playing we were hooked, looking forward to an hour or so here and there of playing and talking to each other about our theories of what is going on.

I would highly recommend this to anyone looking for an entertaining escape from adventure games of late, anyone who enjoys BBC mytery dramas that can also stand some humor, and anyone just looking to be entertained.

I will be interested in playing the sequel if and when it's released. (Oh, and one small nitpick--the labels and arrows on the map were a bit confusing.)

21671186.review:
Absolutely loved the game. Very fun, with engaging story.

I'd say the acting is maybe a bit exaggerated, but it's fun, and seems to be on purpose. The game also seems to sometimes fail to recognize the contradictions and I had to try the same thing a couple of times before it was "recognized", but this was a very rare issue and didn't really bother me that much.

I was positively surprised by the difficulty of the game, and how the difficulty grew over time. I expected that with such clear options to choose from it would be easy to find the answers, but it really gave me a lot of excellent "AHA!" -moments when I figured out what the solution was.

The one thing that really bothered me about the game was how some scenes seemed to be accessible for a long time with very little to do in them, and then certain events only happened when visiting some scenes. I was constantly re-visiting all the locations with no clear reason, just to make sure I found any events in seemingly random locations.

I can definitely recommend this to anyone who enjoys any kind of mysteries and adventure games, or is looking for an unique story experience.

21400154.review:
In a nutshell:  "Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney" meets live action profesional UK production.  With decent story and gameplay.

The basic mechanism is really just typical "Ace Attorney" gameplay (i.e. finding contradictions) with high quality FMVs story clips.  But unlike games associated with either features, it is not campy.  In fact, its presentation is top-notch.  The cinematics have been framed, edited and treated with exceptional care.  No green screens or CG effects.  No explosions or major action scenes.  The movies avoids the usual trap of taking on a too big of a scope.  It actually looks like a TV movie.  Except that it is not.  It is a game.

But behind the clips lie a writting team that produced a story that, although quite simple at its core, keeps you engaged like a typical page-turner.  The rich scripts are delivered by superb acting.  Your avatar, Inspector Jenks, at first appears to be a bit too expressive, an over-actor if you will.  But, much like Columbo, his quirks grows on you, and you come to accept his maneurisms (which is good, since you see him all the time...).  Then, unavoidably, there is the sinister Paul Rand, expertly played by veteran actor Paul Darrow.  If you have come to love "Kerr Avon" for his cynicism and egomania, rest asured that Paul Darrow has not lost any of his reptilian flair from his "Blake's 7" days.  The rest of the cast also handles themselves up to par.  No one acts "amateurish"... Well except one "dazed" person, but that could have been intentional...

Gameplay-wise, one feature that is THANKFULLY lacking is the dreaded "pixel hunt".  There is none.  When a location needs to be investigated, you do not need to smash the mouse button around the screen like a maniac.  You just simply click the magnifying glass that appears at the bottom of the screen, and Inspector Jenks will then handle the rest.  This allows you to focus on solving the contradictions.  In fact, gameplay can be summarized with A) walking around ( with some fast-travel points to instantly move between locations that are far apart), B) talking to people, and obviously C) finding contradictions (i.e. match two items from a conversation with a character that contradicts each other, exposing a lie...).  There are very little "use-item-here" situations, and when there are, they are quite obvious.  Also, there are no time-based or reflex-based situations either.

However, there have been times when I wanted to scream at the game that "THERE IS A CONTRADICTION RIGH THERE", but that being said, I only needed some external help only 3 times along the way, once being my complete ignorance on a certain subject that prevented me from knowing that "such" with "such" was an impossibility.

Also, although the case do have a sense of closure, you do get hinted that there are more at stake.  So you could say that the ending is... "partial".

However, these problems do not diminished the fact that I thoroughly enjoyed my journey through this game.  This is one of the first of recent "serious" FMV games.  Solid production, engaging story and acting, fun gameplay.

21356388.review:
A really wonderful and fantastic game, with a heaping helping of hilarious cheese. The main premise of the game is to investigate the accidental(?) death of a young woman in a small town, but mysteries quickly pile on and turn into more mysteries, as your character interviews people left and right (some of them high as a kite) and turning up increasingly bizarre pieces of evidence. 

The real meat of the game is the interviews -- you have to actually pay attention to what people are saying and try to catch them in a lie. It's super fun, as most games tend to lead you around by the nose these days. It's also quite difficult at times, especially when your list of topics and suspects grows longer and longer and you have a hard time determining what is a lie versus a merely ambiguous statement. Rarely, though, I would discover someone had made a clear contradiction, only to have the game dismiss it, but it only happened two or three times the entire game. 

This is honestly the most fun I've had with a game in a long, long time. I played it with my significant other, and we had a million times more fun deducing (and occasionally laughing) together than we would have if we'd played it apart. This game is worth it at full price.

21343783.review:

It is not always obvious what you have to do next you can ask for a hint but the answers often seem unrelated to the dialogue/line of enquiry you are persuing.

That being said the story is engaging and it is a fun game that doesnt take itself to seriously. The actors seem to have enjoyed the roles and their entusiasum for the characters is infectious.

Also I played this on an eight year old pc running vista so perhaps the system requirements are more forgiving than suggested.

21291350.review:
Played this through with my roomate. Took about seven hours with the two of us thinking on everything, no cheats used. It's a wonderful challenge, and none of it particularly unfair; often with these kinds of games you get into a situation where you're lost in the verbage, trying to figure out which exact lines the game wants you to choose, even if it's not the most logical. This game doesn't suffer from that at all, and we were generally able to single out the exact choices we had to make when hit with inspiration. 

Acting is spot-on; my only real complaint is about how jarringly hammy the lead detective is, but it's so over-the-top that it eventually becomes strangely endearing. Might not be that way for everyone, but I've come to love Jenks' great facial expressions.

The ending leaves ample room for a much larger sequel, and I hope the devs are able to fund it. At $10, this game is a fucking STEAL and it's one of the better detective-type games on Steam right now.

Would highly recommend to fans of detective shows, detective fiction, and fans of Danganronpa and Phoenix Wright who need their fix between games.

21263662.review: Absolutely fantastic FMV game, the characters were interesting and fun to discover and get to know, and the acting was very good for a tiny budget kickstarter game. The atmosphere of a sinister plot in a small English village was great and the FMV style only helped this aspect. My only con is some of the contradictions can get a bit tenuous, but other than that i enjoyed it all round. I hope this gets a sequel, it deserves one!

21253102.review:
'Contradiction - Spot the Liar' had my attention as soon as I started it. You play as a detective who is inspecting a suicide of a college girl named Girl, who happens to be enrolled in a business course of an organization called Atlas which has all the right amounts of shady. It’s a brilliant setup and is very engrossing. I started playing this with my mom, who had never ever played any sort of video game. She immediately liked it and that’s saying a lot!

Coming to the mechanics, I really loved it. I think it has got its roots from the very famous board game 'Cluedo' and it works on the same principle of questioning the suspects and finding a contradicting statements they have made and so spotting their lies. It’s a really neat mechanic and it meshes in perfectly with this game.  

The presentation is well laid out and the menus are easy to traverse. I really loved the little cut scenes which play out when switching between areas but it got a little monotonous in the end and I wished there was an option to skip it. But it’s not a very major gripe that it will keep you from playing the game at all. 

Speaking about cut scenes, the main cut scenes are quite enjoyable. Mainly due to the over the top acting of Detective Jenks with his ridiculous outfit, with the more serious acting by the rest of the cast. There were some time where I felt that the acting was not up to the mark but it was negligible. I really enjoyed the acting of Mr. Paul Rynd who had a tone very similar to Professor Snape from the Harry Potter Series. 

The story, wow it did grip me all the way from the beginning till the last bit. The ending for me was a letdown, I feel it was rushed and left many questions which I wanted to know unanswered. They introduced a lot of supernatural and horror elements which was fantastic for the brief about of time it lasted, but they shied away from it towards the end. Maybe due to the time restrictions they had to rush the final bits of the game. But I’m sure if they had given more time it would have been a 10/10 experience. This was one of the two issues I had with the game.

The other issue was some of the contradiction puzzles seemed easy, it may also be because I was always in track with all the replies given by each and every suspect for each and every evidence, but some contradictions are very hard to find.

Overall I had a lot of fun playing this game, it kept me hooked throughout until the end bit. They did throw a hint for a sequel in the end which would solve all the mysteries. I hope they manage to come out with it in the future. Finally saying that I do not recommend this game to anyone will be a contradiction itself, so yes go and play this game, its good! I want more of this please!

21150492.review:
Le dernier jeu d'énigmes en FMV que j'avais était Shivers. Mais c'est pas vraiment de la FMV (juste l'intro la fin et 3 cinématiques). Phantasmagoria était déjà plus dans le ton. Ceci dit, tout ça prouve une chose: Tout ça date d'il y a plus de 15 ans... Du coup, quand j'ai vu Contradiction en promo, je l'ai acheté.

Résultat ? C'est un bon petit jeu. Pour les habitués de point & click, le jeu pourra sembler relativement facile. La mécanique de gameplay principale étant de confrontrer deux éléments contradictoires dans un témoignage, on fait plutôt facilement le lien entre les contradictions malgré la présence assez importante d'éléments qui, au final, ne servent à rien. 

Tout le jeu possède un léger côté kitsch avec des acteurs qui surjouent un petit peu. Suffisamment pour que ça amuse, mais aussi suffisamment peu pour qu'on ne tombe bas dans le gros cliché lourdingue. L'histoire est sympa et se laisse suivre. Je n'irai pas jusqu'à dire que c'est l'histoire du siècle, très loin de là, mais j'ai apprécié que la plupart du temps où j'avais envie de faire une reflexion pertinente à un personnage, Jenks s'en chargeait pour moi (beaucoup trop de jeu où les héros manquent clairement de répartie et de matière grise). 

Globallement on sent que le jeu a un petit côté indie mais il est propre est bien fait (j'ai eu quelques bugs (type texte plus selectionnable) mais qui se résolvent facilement). Au moins vous savez exactement quoi acheter quand vous achetez Contradiction. C'est pour ça qu'il est si bien noté. Si le genre vous intéresse, vous allez forcément apprécier.

Si je devais lui trouver un gros reproche, ça serait surtout le côté : "Je trouve toujours les bons objets au bon moment" qui est pas crédible pour deux sous. C'est dommage, le reste tient la route.

J'espère sincèrement qu'ils réussiront à financer une suite parce qu'au final, on s'attache à tout l'univers.

21132868.review: I love, love, love this game. 20873635.review:
I think I haven't played such a well executed FMV adventure since forever. 

This is clearly the result of a very dedicated work and the scenes look amazing. Also, the actors are great in their roles and the story gets interesting really fast. There is a hook for a sequel at the end, but the main story concludes in a satisfactory manner. 

Pros:
- Really well acted and directed FMV adventure game. Decent soundtrack, too. It's incredible that all this was accomplished on a short budget.
- Interesting way of navigating around the locations.
- Virtually no pixel hunting.
- The UI helps a lot in order not to get stuck - and if you use up hints and chief calls and still don't have clue, there is also a "cheat" system to power through your predicament. 
- It is not really a short game, or at least doesn't feel like it. It takes its time and you get to meet and get to know most of its (multiple) characters quite well. 

Couple of drawbacks:
- The gameplay is mostly backtracking over locations to interrogate/ ask questions based on new info you discover. However, there is a three-level hint system integrated in the game that assures that you will never get stuck
- 1 or 2 of the (several) contradictions that you are required to spot seemed a bit far fetched.

A definite recommendation from me to anyone who enjoys FMV adventures.

20865646.review:

20762662.review:
I want to take this time to congratulate the makers of this game... The imminent return of good FMV games is in good hands with this developer.

The acting is intriguing, the music and sound push the story along well and the story is superb (even if it somewhat leaves you hanging), and the control is simple enough that anyone can sit down and enjoy about 7-9 hours of mysterious fun.  Keep in mind, though, you will still have TONS of questions that don't receive answers...cliffhangers, if you will....so, if that is something that turns you off in games, then this game is not for you.

I was intrigued even more about this game when I realized half way through playing it that is was funded through Kickstarter.  It is nice to see a publicly funded game that is actually worth buying.  I hope they will continue to make more chapters, but that apparently can't happen without game fan monetary support...So, what I suggest is watching like maybe 1 chapter of a you play to see if it intrigues you...If so, buy it and show your support...that's what I did.

Well done, chaps...well done indeed...

20746746.review: I had hesitations going into a purely FMV game, but wow this won me over. It's a really interesting classic adventure style game that is carried by great acting. 20707369.review:
Whenever I play FMV games I think about Phantasmagoria. The year was 1995 and it was a miracle for a child to make a real person move by only a single mouse click. After 20 years, although the video quality is much higher and I am not considered a child anymore, I still enjoy playing FMV games.

First of all, this game has a very solid story and good acting. The events and consequences have logical relations and acting is neither ridiculous nor amateur. The cast gives you the feeling that you really are the inspector and they are the suspects.

Furthermore the contradiction finding technique is so cleverly designed, that it makes you feel like you achieved something really important when you find their lies. 

On the contrary the bugs and the "not so easy to understand menu design" are the downsides. Sometimes it is not possible to change the cursor to a hand and one needs to watch one of the former dialogues to fix the issue and exit. The menu is definitely not very user friendly and not so easy to comprehend.

But still, I respect everyone who contributed this game only because I enjoyed playing it. As I mentioned above, the game is not perfect but it is worth playing, I hope they develop a new game, maybe a sequel or a game with a new story in the nearest future. As a result, in my opinion the developers, cast and the rest of the staff deserve an applause for their effort. Thanks a lot for the good time!

20620109.review: If you've any love for mystery games, full-motion video games, or adventure games then this is the game for you. 20618709.review:
Quick review: (Sadly there is no way to simply "thumbs up" the game without leaving a review.) I'm not usually into point and click adventures but this FMV (full motion video) game feels like a sleeper hit. This was a kickstarter game from a small but enthusiastic studio. You can tell they put a lot of time into this. The characters each have their own personality and the acting is better than most indie games. The story feels rushed/iffy at times but overall it's enjoyable.

This was fun to play from the couch using the steam controller, there is a nice profile someone created or you can just use the built-in mouse emulation feature of the controller.

The save system is a bit quirky--if you choose "Save and exit" next time you start it will look like it is showing 0% progress, just click "Resume" and it will usually put you back where you were. It's safer to manually choose "Save 1" or "Save 2" before exiting the game and then manually load your save by selecting "Load 1" or "Load 2" the next time you start.

20565323.review:
It is a mixed bag but I mostly enjoyed my time with Contradiction, mainly because it is really nice to see the effort of reviving the FMV genre with the help of contemporary technical means. The acting is still as amazingly cheesy as it was decades ago but the shots of course look way nicer than before.

I give this a recommendation although I have two major complaints:

1) This will be familiar to players of the Ace Attorney series. Throughout the game you spot contradictions and facts that just don't add up, but you're sadly restricted to point out the contradictions the game wants you to spot at the appropriate times. The game would hugely profit if there was a way to give more freedom to the players and their own wits. Ways to actually FAIL, different ways to tackle the same problem and things like that.

2) Mild spoiler alert. People who want to buy the game should stop reading here.

The game sets a lot of conflict up and admits itself that Jenks has only scratched the surface of what is going on in the story. This of course stirs the appetite for a sequel but the problem is, that it really devalues the game as a whole. The payoff of the whole murder mystery is quite meager compared to the huge setup(s) which might leave some players dissatisfied at the end.

20559529.review: Absolutely loved this game, really immersive and well written. Couple of minor bugs when trying to drop in contradictions, remember to save every now and then. Great game to play with a few people sitting around trying to solve the mystery, gave us 8 hours of fun!

20538124.review:
While it is quite a linear experience, "Contradiction: Spot the Liar" is still a very enjoyable ride. The story is chock-full of uncooperative characters, all with interesting personality quirks which makes it fun to just question them. In addition, main character Inspector Jenks is such a goofy character, his facial expressions and mannerisms are simply hilarious, reminding me of Columbo in a way. While it might sound like a knock against the game, I find it's quite accurate of the murder-mystery shows on cable TV: the actor does a fine job, as do the various characters.

As for the technical aspect of the game, it simply looks fantastic. The backdrops' quality are beautiful, the indoor shots are for the most part very well done, and the actors all work very hard to obviously show their hand when you're supposed to pick up on a contradiction.

My only real issue with the game is that the audio mix is sometimes odd: the voices sound a bit tinny or distorted. In addition, there is a striking lack of sound effects. I feel foley work would've made it even better, or more ambient noise would've helped bring the world to life. 

All things considered, "Contradiction" is a very well crafted game with a strong intrigue and only a few drawbacks. Even the actors, who are quite good at chewing scenery and making the lines about them, manage to turn in a strong performance all-around. It makes them more believable in a way, and more suspicious which is exactly the point of the game. I am definitely looking forward to seeing more FMV (full-motion video) games like this, and I'm hopeful the team at Baggy Cat will have something new for us very soon.

20452181.review:
Even though the first 2-3 "hours"/parts of the game (out of 7) are quite enjoyable, the game becomes stale very fast.
If it was only this, I would still recommend the game, but here, we have a "logic/detective" game that doesn't follow it's own rules and forces you to roam the game board aimlessly in order to trigger a "random" encounter that you couldn't do without.

The game is based on a statement matching system that requires you to match 2 statements made by the same suspect that explicitely contradict each other without any possible addition of information from the part of the player... Except when it doesn't... at least 1 instance of the game requiring you to match 2 statements that don't explicitely contradict each other, unless you expect the detective to add information he witnessed (which he never does except in this instance). Basically, the game doesn't follow its own rules.

Also, the game has the defect of all old-style point and clicks: you have to click exactly what the programmer thought was the right solution, in the order (mostly) the programmer thought was good for the narrative. Therefore, expect to be frustrated by the game not letting you make obvious connections simply because you're not clicking the exact 2 statements that can trigger the next event. (possibly because you haven't roamed aimlessly through the unskippable mini cut-scenes between each game-board tile in order to hope and find a random event and a new clue)

And if that wasn't enough, I recorder 2 instances of the game storing a "corrected statement" of one of the "suspects" in a unexpected place, forcing me to search for them in random discussion menus.

In short, this game comes from a good idea, but is 2x longer than it should be, and not executed as well as it should. Making it a frustrating mess of a game.

20373927.review:
Da amante della saga di Tex Murphy, appena ho visto la combo FMV+Detective non ho saputo resistere e l'ho preso, pur senza troppe aspettative. L'ironia del protagonista ricorda quella di Tex mentre le meccaniche di gioco sono molto diverse. L'azione è praticamente inesistente, così come non ci sono scenari da percorrere. Si passa da una schermata all'altra, anche attraverso una mappa, alla ricerca di pochi indizi. Gli indizi non vanno ricercati come fossero hidden objects ma apparirà una lente d'ingrandimento sulla destra e cliccando andrete direttamente a focalizzarvi sull'oggetto da trovare. 

In Contradiction non ci sono oggetti da combinare nell'inventario, tutto è focalizzato sui dialoghi e gli indizi veri e propri verranno forniti proprio durante queste sessioni. Esempio: Fate tutte le domande al personaggio A, poi al personaggio B e al personaggio C, quest'ultimo vi fornirà una risposta che vi porterà a tornare dal personaggio A per dei chiarimenti e il personaggio A - nel rispondere - cadrà in contraddizione con una risposta data in precedenza. Dal "taccuino" selezionerete le due risposte e avrete un nuovo dialogo che magari questa volta farà emergere un nuovo personaggio a cui fare visita. 

Per quanto il gioco sia lineare, la presenza di battutine frequenti, la buona recitazione dei personaggi e l'andamento per nulla scontato di tutta la storia, rendono difficile staccarsi da questo titolo prima di averlo finito (la durata è di 7-8 ore). Consiglio caldamente l'acquisto a chiunque sia armato di buona pazienza, perché i dialoghi vanno ascoltati (e letti) con molta attenzione, essendo le contraddizioni non sempre lapalissiane. Inoltre, dato che è relativamente breve, vi consiglio di iniziare a giocarlo quando avete tempo di finirlo in giornata o al massimo in due giorni consecutivi, così non perdete il filo e non siete costretti a rileggere tutto!

20366599.review:
Je veux le sequel de ce jeu! 

L'expérience est vraiment sympathique, surtout avec cet inspecteur en décalage complet avec le monde autour de lui. Les personnages sont très profonds, les acteurs excellents et le tout est filmé avec beaucoup de talent : le jeu est fluide et intelligemment monté. 

Certaines contradictions ont beau être un peu tirées par les cheveux, ce jeu est addictif (j'y ai joué presque d'une seule traite) et il est presque nécessaire d'y être accroché puisqu'il faut parfois se souvenir de discours tenus bien au début de l'enquête. 

Ce qui est beau c'est la fin, comme dans tous ces films où l'on vous montre ce qui est évident tout en vous cachant et vous menant à de fausses pistes pour finalement, à la fin, se dire "mais biensûr ! "

Je conseille ce jeu à tous les fans du genre, aux passionnés d'enquêtes et de polar. 

Attention, il faut un bon niveau d'anglais pour suivre et retenir les différents indices et interrogatoires. 

Thank you Baggy Cat & Kickstarter for bringing back the FMV to a quite awesome level of viability !

20352986.review:
The premise of this game was great, unfortunately it wasnt executed as well as it could have been.

For what appears to be made on a small budget, I cant really fault the acting, even though 1 character appeared to be nursing the same drink for at least 4 hours, only to spill it late in the game. THE FOOL!
The characters were a strong point for the game, even if the acting sometimes fell short. Jenks was intelligent, calm and occasionally humorous. The rest of the cast appeared to have depth and real individual personalitles. 
At times it was a little frustrating as information i wanted to further investigate was brushed aside immediately after it was revealed. I also took exception to not being able to ask certain questions to avoid upsetting a character, i couldnt imagine a real detective sparing the feelings of possible suspects while attemepting to solve a possible murder.
 There were times that you would notice a contradiction between two characters but be unable to follow that obvious line of questioning. it was almost like them giving you vital clues but then shaking keys in front of your eyes as a distraction so you didnt solve the case too quick. It made the game feel as though you were looking for clues to progress the story and not looking for clues to solve the case. Kind of like being shown a giant tender steak cooked to perfection, with roasted vegetables and a small amount of mushroom gravy on the side but forcing you to eat multiple entrees made up of non delicious fillers, before sinking your teeth into that juicy rare steak. 

Using the map as a fast travel can stagnate your progress as walking through certain areas at times will trigger events that you may otherwise not travel to. They regualrly feel unimportant to your progress.
Without revealing spoilers, the story couldve been rearranged in a fashion to make it fit together more smoothly instead of feeling like you've ignored vital pieces of information.
 I also feel that the game could have benefitted hugely from flashbacks.  I wouldve loved a chance to get to know the victim through story driven flashbacks as important  information was revealed. Maybe this was a budget issue for them and it was something they were just unable to include, which is understandable. 

It was a fun FMV detective game. But some small adjustments couldve improved the immersion immensly. mainly the organisation of the story and how in the timeline you were given certain bits of information. 
It really feels like they have opened some interesting oppurtunities if a second game was to be created.

Overall it was an enjoyable game with potential to become a fun series, especially on the back of Inspector Jenks. 
While i do reccommend it, I do so hesitantly. I've attempted to explain what i found to be frustrating with the game and hopefully help you to make an informed decision before purchasing.

20346585.review:
Really enjoyed it. The acting was great, the story was interesting, the puzzles made sense. The central mechanic of finding inconsistencies in people’s stories works pretty well. It’s so much more enjoyable than QTEs, minigames or the typical adventure game thing of collecting random items and combining them in weird ways.

The one thing I didn’t like is the way you have to keep revisiting the same locations over and over again just to see if anything has changed. This repetitive process pads out the length of the game considerably.

Two of the hardest contradictions to spot (for me) were at the very end of the game, so I’d say it’s pretty well balanced difficulty-wise. By the way, if you do get badly stuck, but don’t want to cheat, I’d recommend rewatching the cutscenes: at least two of the contradictions rely on remembering minor details you could have easily forgotten about if you’re not playing the game in one sitting.

20288013.review:
Do you enjoy mystery games and might be interested in trying out full-motion video (FMV) games then look no further! 

Contradiction is a simple point and click game. You travel back and fourth between various suspects to question about clues that you find or through talking to other suspects. The main aspect that sets Contradiction apart are the full-motion video that feature great actors; my favorites being Jenks and Paul. It does remind me of a beloved series Ace Attorney although it is much more simplified but still enjoyable. 

As the entire game is shot in full-motion video, it is a joy to watch and interact with the game. You can really tell when a character is nervous or lying from their acting. The most endearing part is the investigator, Jenks with his comical expressions. 

Although this game is quite straightforward and not really a game that you need to replay I think it is still worth playing. I do agree with some that the ending is bittersweet as you slowly uncover deep hidden evils within the settings and characetrs, however I think it is only an encouragement for a sequel that I really hope they will go ahead with. If they end up promoting their sequel onto KickStarter, I know I would love to help fund it.

Only at the end while watching the credits did I find out it was small budget, I found no shortcomings when it came to quality, actually, I think it was very well done. 20220444.review:
Contradiction mi ha fatto tornare alla mente il bellissimo "Xfiles The Videogame" di fine anni 90 su pc. L'avventura ci mette nei panni del solito investigatore di turno, dalla personalità bizzarra e resa davvero bene dalla recitazione. Tutto è vero film HD. 20205400.review:
This was a charming detective game that left me feeling very satisfied by its conclusion. As other reviewers have noted, the acting is weird, stilted, and melodramatic. Somewhere between a latin soap opera and David Lynch project, set in a rural English town. And the UI is servicable, but not pretty or easy-to-use.

But the actual act of bumbling through interviews to solve the mystery is exciting in its execution. The game asks you to build a detailed mental model of what's really going on in the town, and rewards you for making remote connections. 

And one of the more interesting ways it does this is by not letting you "gotcha" a suspect by surprising them with information given by another interviewee. Every character provides plausible responses to each new piece of evidence presented, but is only pressured into breaking character when you actually find contradictions in what they have said themselves.

For example, say Alice tells you she didn't steal an envelope of cash, but Bob tells you that he saw Alice steal the envelope. You can't do anything with that information. Instead, you must look for contradictions only in Alice's previous statements that would support Bob's story and present them to Alice. It's devilishly clever, and prevents you from blindly progressing in the story without building those connections yourself.

It's not a perfect game, but a really fun way to spend around 5 hours playing goofy detective. And playing with a group is even better.

20203981.review: This game was _amazing_. Highly reccommended! Not just a fun game but a legitimately gripping story all the way through!

20202113.review: We really enjoyed Contradiction. It was a lot of fun to play as a team, sharing ideas as we made our way through it. Some of the clues were a little frustrating, but the final one was so very satisfying. On top of being a fun game, the team behind this game managed to pull off a satisfying mystery and a creepy story.

20200366.review:
The plot was intriguing and at times... creepy. So creepy. The solutions weren't always obvious, I had to really dig through the statements to find the contradictions. So while it's still possible to solve the case without using any hints, don't expect it to be a cakewalk.
The performances were great, there was a good balance between 'comical' and 'chillingly intense'. Spotting the lies and then making Jenks grill the suspects was very enjoyable: go Jenks! 
The cinematography was beautiful and there were subtle dolly-ins/zoom-ins at just the right moments. The brilliant application of dissolve - together with the UI and controls - made the experience seamless, simple and stunning. Sound design was equally detailed and amazing.
The game guides the player to the solution and it's impossible to improvise, but I don't see this as a bad thing. It's like an interactive mystery novel: while you can have your suspicions, the story still only has one ending and you're just along for the ride. I enjoyed this ride immensely and can't wait for more!

20157627.review:
There are two reasons I can't recommend this game.

1) It seems the game designer is not a very good game designer, just a good writer and director. You are supposed to be an investigator, but you can't really do things an investigator should be able to do. If you ask two people about the same subject and you know one of them is lying, you can't really see a contradiction between dialogues of different people. You also can't investigate for yourself. It claims to be a point-and-click, but all you do is click on a magnifying glass and Jenks do all the job for you (not very nice for a game...). Basically, the game is about talking with people and just waiting for them to lie about something (because none of them are very good liars). 

2) The ending. It is the most disappointing ending in any murder mystery investigation game. If this was a real-life investigation and I was the investigator, I would probably solve the case in 20 minutes, but apparently Jenks takes 7 hours to do so because he's either lazy or clueless about clear evidence.
---KIND OF SPOILERS AHEAD---
Basically, there's an unique tape on the victim's driver's license (you can see at the trailer). I noticed it right away and early on the game Jenks comes across the same tape on window. However, this is not presented as a clue (even though it would clearly be something a real detective would notice and use as evidence). Anyway, this would not bother me if this particular tape was not the only thing that actually frames the killer. Near the ending, the tape comes across as important again, and when you ask the killer about it, he or she just confesses the crime. This to me is just the most stupid thing.

TL;DR
If you want a good point-and-click mystery game, look for some of Nancy Drew's games. They're way better in gameplay and mystery plot.

20107584.review: I pledge allegiance to the Jenks. Seriously, it's a great old-school like FMV adventure point-n-click.

20098751.review:
Interactive detective movie in a small village. This game was like a breath of fresh air - good concept - very well implemented with good script and slick editing for modest cast - quite fun - best tried with friends or family together with output to TV screen - occasional rare minor interface bugs but easily overcome - some scenes and acting quirky and quaint but all the funnier for that - there is enough for a couple of evenings or one very long one - would fit in with a weekend effort with friends or family nicely. 

Was very happy to forgive any minor shortcomings of this game because overall the effort and polish of what was attempted was accomplished very impressively; it is not easy to script, edit, act out and film such a work so well - the developers have done a good job on this - appreciate it and I hope you will enjoy this interactive TV detective show as much as we did. 

I picked it up when on a heavily discounted price tag and found it great value entertainment - I don't often review games but this delivered what I was expecting and was fun - deserves support, success and sequels.

19891291.review:
Well that was a surprisingly excellent game.

I'll do the negatives first, because there's only a couple. Mouse controls are a little buggy. Some of the things that seem contradictory aren't (e.g. I met someone, but I also only heard about them after they died) and equally some are a little off (i.e. the text doesn't give you the full story, so you need to remember it from the interaction) but there's maybe 3 or 4 cases of both overall.

First off, the FMV is excellent. The actor who played Jenks is downright brilliant at it. No cheesy B-movie; it's all solid acting.

The gameplay is spot on. Everything you need to do is logical and not frustrating.

My favourite part was the story. At no point does it suddenly decide that there is some huge worldwide conspiracy where the USA is run by the Illuminati and aliens are taking over the world and it's all hidden in this little village. It's a good murder mystery because it remains a mystery rather than a silly fantasy.

And it does the whole 'quaint English village' thing ABSOLUTELY PERFECTLY. No more of this silly tally ho wot wot tea and crumpets malarkey; it's just a perfect setting.

The story was great through, the ending was (mostly) great, the acting was brilliant, just overall an exceptionally good game I would recommend to everyone. I'd put it at 6 hours for a playthrough.

19886593.review: Great solid detective gameplay. Wish the clues provided more options, but challenging notheless.

19875891.review:
[h1] "A few more questions... if you don't mind?": Transfórmate en el tábano de un silencioso pueblo inglés [/h1]

Un título muy interesante, sugerido para los amantes del género de detectives, especialmente si se difruta de las series policiales británicas. Las actuaciones, aunque más de alguna vez parezcan un poco exageradas o estereotípicas, son precisamente un recuerdo nostálgico de esos personajes arquetípicos siempre presentes en los capítulos de estas afamadas series.
Si bien la búsqueda de contradicciones y el trabajo de investigación no son excesivamente complejos, posee una trama muy interesante, llena de diversos nudos e interrogantes que te motivan a concluir el caso sólo para saber qué es lo que se esconde detrás de la cortina y cómo las piezas del rompecabezas encajan entre sí.

De mencionar algunos aspectos negativos, son más que nada detalles, como el hecho de que a veces las transiciones entre escenario y escenario son un tanto repetitivas y hacen al juego un poco tedioso. Por otra parte, la banda sonora es reducida, aunque cumple muy bien con sus objetivos.
Pese a estas falencias, fundadas en el reducido presupuesto con el que contaban los desarrolladores, el juego se nota que fue hecho con mucho cariño y se esmera en superar estas barreras y brindarte una experiencia de investigación muy divertida.

Resumen: Un buen juego, hecho con mucho aprecio y esfuerzo. Recomendado para los amantes de los juegos de detectives y los nostálgicos de las series británicas del género. El nivel de desafío es apropiado -quizás para algunos sencillo- y el transforndo del caso es bastante interesante.

VEREDICTO: 8/10

19707043.review:
Contradiction is a minimally funded (via Kickstarter) live action (or if you're old school, FMV) point-and-click adventure that you should buy and play so they can make a sequel.  The end.

Okay, so without giving anything away, the game is mostly about listening to suspect interviews and trying to find contradictory statements.  There is minimal use of the traditional adventure item inventory. If you have no interest in the backtracking, reviewing conversations, or getting stuck that is typical of the last 30 years of adventure gaming, stop reading, because this game won't convince you to like those things.

However, if you are still reading, there are only two questions worth considering for whether you should play this game.  Is the acting too cheesy to tolerate, and does it play well as an adventure? As for the acting, I enjoyed it.  The casting is good, the voices are good, and only the main character (the inspector you play) is heavily overacting, but in the most endearing way possible.  Of course realize that I am predisposed to enjoy the genuine British accents and setting, so without that bias, you may not fall as heavily in love with these actors as I did.  You've got some believable ladies, and several appropriately disturbing gentlemen, one of whom stands by a mantelpiece and channels a smarmy Tim Curry while the other sits in a comfy chair and does a condescending Ian McDiarmid.

As for gameplay, I was able to finish (and 100% the game with no cheats) in a couple of days amounting to maybe seven or eight hours without ever getting maddeningly stuck.  Regarding gameplay, here's my breakdown.

The so-so:

You backtrack a lot.
There aren't many locations and only a handful of items of very limited use.
Due to the nature of the writing, you will think of tons of connections that you can't inquire about.
You can only get further info on contradictions (see the name) and no other connections.
You can't inquire about statements from two different characters that contradict each other, only the self-contradictory statements.
The scenes aren't really reshot for different times, just put through a blue filter for darkness (wait, that's not a gameplay element).
There are typos.

The good:

None of the contradictions are impossible to spot, but only a few are totally obvious.
It's satisfying to find a contradiction because you noticed something visual in the scene that isn't really stated in the summaries you choose from. The statements that act as inventory items are helpful enough, but a keen eye helps too.
There are options for hints and cheats, although I didn't use them.
Calls to the police chief serve to summarize where you stand in the case without acting as cheats.
There is no lore-reading necessary.  All of the story is fully acted out or recounted through live interviews.
The feeling of progress is extremely satisfying, and the advancing of hours acts as milestones.
There are red herrings everywhere, which creates a believable atmosphere, fully fleshed out.

I've played a lot of adventure games since the 80s, and I think you should play this one, even at full price.

19545636.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
There's been a suicide in a village. You play as Inspector Jenks to see if it could be something more sinister. 99% of the game is interviewing suspects and finding logical errors in their statements.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Excellent writing. What seems like a simple suicide case becomes more bizarre as the story progresses.
+ Good acting and interesting characters. Some of the actors really delivered a great performance.
+ High-quality full motion video that is very quick to load. Even when switching between locations quickly there is no lag.
+ Music is well done. Whoever directed this game knew how to use the right music to emphasize tension.
+ No pixel-hunting for objects. Any important items are automatically added to your inventory after a search prompt.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Poor Steam integration. I can't take take screenshots or use the Steam Chat overlay. I played this on Windows 10.
- Conversation buttons don't work sometimes. Annoying but can be fixed by replaying a dialogue or exiting the conversation.
- Although the main mystery can be solved, some loose ends still remain. The developers say this is an experimental game, and a sequel may be made depending on user feedback.

Literally one of the best games I've played this year.

It was my first FMV ever and I randomly found this out while browsing through detective games on Steam. It was a great surprise. 
First off, the cast is outstanding. Amazing actors and brilliant performances, they really help the narrative a lot and make everything interesting. Then the media quality is good as well, since videos are in full HD. Characters are just awesome: they could literally be all killers and that's what makes the plot interesting, since it's really hard to understand what happened until the very end. 

I have to admit that sometimes the game is a bit repetitive, especially in the mid-part of the story: if you are not particularly expert in puzzle games, you'll most likely end up stuck in a boring loop of: find a clue-talk to everybody- find a clue - talk to everybody -and so on. But maybe it's just me being stupid. 

Overall, absolutely recommended, totally worth its price. (I've paid its cd key 0.89 $, but it's full Steam price still seems totally fair to me).

19246945.review:
With a mere ~$6000 Kickstarter budget, Contradiction accomplishes beautifully what L.A. Noire couldn't pull off with ~$48 million:  a spot-the-lie detective story where the contradictions are actually contradictions.  

If you want running, jumping, headshots, open worlds, experience grinding, leveling up, skill-trees, and loot (all of which I love immensely), look elsewhere.

If you want an easily-accessible, story-driven mystery game where you can sit back with a friend or two and brainstorm together about whose story doesn't quite add up, this game is worth every penny.

Altogether, about 8-12 hours long (depending on how quickly you work it out).  

Will definitely be buying any game like this that the developer makes in the future.

19244298.review:
I spent an hour each evening for a week, with my wife calling the occasional clue from the other side of the room, and finished this game fairly easily. That's not a bad thing - a game that lasts just a week. It provided seven hours of fun that we thoroughly enjoined.

For a kickstarted game it was very well put together, great acting (the detective's scene chewing aside), nicely filmed, and the cast was entertaining. A couple of spelling mistakes in the text did not detract from our fun,

There are fewer than a dozen items to pick up, find, use, whatever, and it's pretty obvious where each is used. Once you get the hang of how to select two different statements by the same person and compare them for "CONTRADICTIONS" the gameplay is pretty much sorted. Talk to everyone about everything, and if you get stuck call the chief - but in general if you think you've got nowhere else to visit and nothing else to talk about, it means you have at least one person who has contradicted themselves and you have to select both statements. That will cause another cutscene that will add to your evidence and off you go to talk to everyone else about it.

The game installed easily, started up quickly, and the video playbacks were seamless. [Win 10, Geforce GTX 570, 24GB RAM]

Worth the price of a round of drinks at the pub. I'll definitely look out for the sequel and chip in for a kickstarter if they run one.

19240540.review: This game was very well thought through, beautifully shot and exicuted. Overall a very easy purchase and fun experience.

19235813.review:
When you finish Contradiction there is a screen which says that the game was made independently on a tiny budget, and that if you liked it you should leave a positive review so more games like it can be made.

     Well I hope they make Contradiction 2 some day. This game was really great. It did so much with it's "tiny budget", the idea of a seqel has me really excited. 

    There's something about FMV games, especially Mystery/Thriller FMV games that I love. The characters are all so interesting and memorable. It makes me nostalgic for Gabriel Knight 2 and Phantasmagoria. 

     Next time you're looking through Netflix and you cant find anything to watch, buy this game instead.

19231584.review:
Contradiction was a very enjoyable game, not only for me but for viewers on my Twitch stream as well. The story itself started out interesting enough to catch my interest, and the further we dove into it the better it got. The acting was awkward and cheesy, which you're either going to love or hate. Personally I enjoyed it, it was all very charming.

The actual gameplay was interesting, but could get frustrating. Towards the end of the game I felt the clues and category of clues got a bit much, and could make it difficult to find specific statements to make a contradiction with. The difficulty was spot on for me. We had some frustrating moments in the beginning, trying to find the contradiction, but in the end it felt fair and just right. Unlike other people, I'm glad the game had no QTEs or other gameplay features tacked on to provide more involvement for the player.

The mystery was very captivating, and if there was anything this game lacked it was tying together a few more loose ends. While you do end up solving the objective of the game, it leaves you with many more questions than when you started the game. If we do end up getting a sequel for this game, I will without a doubt buy it and play it. 

If you enjoy FMV games, mystery solving, or just want to kick back with a laid back story I would definitely recommend it. The price tag is fair, if you ask me.

19212069.review:
Ich habe das Spiel zufällig beim stöbern im Steam-Store entdeckt. Ich bin wirklich sehr überrascht, dass ich zuvor noch nichts von diesem Spiel gehört habe. Es hat wirklich sehr viel Spaß gemacht und war, zumindest für mich, eine neue Spielerfahrung. Die Schauspieler und Charaktere sind alle sehr sympatisch und glaubwürdig. Es war Spannend bis zum Schluss.

Im Grunde wird die Handlung vorangetrieben, in dem man die Widersprüche (Contradicions) in den Aussagen der Befragten findet. Obwohl ich nicht so wirklich gut in der englischen Sprache unterwegs bin, konnte ich das Spiel problemlos durchspielen. Es wird ein sehr deutliches, britisches Englisch gesprochen. Dennoch habe ich mir die englischen Untertitel einblenden lassen. ;-) Etwas schade, dass wohl kein Budget für eine deutsche Übersetzung mehr übrig war. Aber man kommt donnoch sehr gut zurecht.

Ich finde die Grafik sehr gut. Was ich als einziges zu bemängeln habe ist, dass das Spiel zwar eine Ultra-Wide Auflösung unterstützt, aber dadurch oben und unten Teile des Bildmaterials fehlen. Mein Monitor hat eine native Auflösung von 3440 x 1440. Um das Spiel ordnungsgemäß zu spielen, habe ich die Auflösung auf 1920 x 1080 geändert. Damit lief das Spiel einwandfrei (natürlich mit schwarzen Balken am Bildschirmrand, aber stören nicht).

Über ein Fortsetzung würde ich mich sehr freuen und würde ich mir sofort holen. :-) Meine Kaufempfehlung ist 100%, auch für Leute, die etwas Angst vor dem englisch-sprachigen haben.

19196530.review:
This budget game has a lot of community-theater style overacting (which may be a plus), and a really messed up terrible UI (which may be more of a minus than you'd imagine).

If you've ever heard about this game and considered buying, it's probably because you don't mind a bit of hammy acting - in fact, you consider the bad acting to be a part of the game's charm. And that's fair enough, I found the acting and story interesting enough to carry me through the game as well. 

However, what you probably don't know is the terrible, no good, awful UI the game uses. It's basically "baby's first adventure game interface", and it's bafflingly bad. Not sure if it made more sense on a tablet, but it could really use a redo on the PC. In other "why is that a thing" interface issues - you can't skip dialog, you can't skip all the minor (or major) cutscenes that take place as you walk around, and you can't focus on spots of interest after the first time you see them. Oh, and the game will always default to windowed mode with subtitles off when you restart it, regardless of what settings you left it with. 

All of the above may well serve to turn a charming little FMV mystery into an interminable slog. 8/10 for the story, 4/10 for the experience of actually playing the game, 6/10 in total. Only buy if you're really into adventure games and terrible FMV acting (which I am)

Edit - Apparently the tablet version has an even worse interface, and what we're getting on steam IS updated. Fair enough, but it's still horrible.

It's pretty good - its a really old school noir-like mystery that has a lot of red herrings and because of it the story isnt very focused. 19035818.review:
I would love to recommend this game, I really do. 

I fully played it over the last few days and really enjoyed it. The story is interesting, the characters are varied and fun, the gameplay is easy to grasp without much explanation. Some of the acting can be a bit campy depending on the characters, though I personally find this pretty entertaining. 

The keyboard option for the game feels a bit unwieldy for interrogations, but for walking around the map it functions fine. Personally, I prefer to play using the mouse. (I didn't try using a gamepad/joystick.)

But, alas, I can't recommend the game for one big, glaring reason: the interface tends to bug out randomly and stops functioning until I close and reopen the game when I play with the mouse as input method. (I did not test the keyboard mode enough to know if it's also affected.) Sometimes this can lead to losing progress, especially if you haven't saved the game manually for a while. The good news? As far as I've noticed, the interface bugs don't corrupt save files or break the game permanently, even if you save after the bug kicked in. 

I also have to warn you that this game's ending is a bit open-ended and has a sequel hook. It's not really a cliffhanger, but if you want your games wrapped up neatly with no questions left unanswered, you'll have to look elsewhere. 

If the interface issues don't bother you, don't mind to regularly save manually using the two save slots and have no qualms with endings that don't give full closure on every detail, I think you can safely buy it, though.

19019801.review: Fun game, short. it took me about 6 hours to complete. The story was not overly complicated, but it had a good number of characters and they do a good job of keeping you guessing about the murderers identity.   I enjoyed the acting and mood of the game.  It looks great, music is tense and works, and video production value is high.  This the a really good MFV.   Primary job here is to follow the clues, which you really can't miss once you get a hang of the game.  Following the stories of the suspects and finding a few items and twists and turns that lead you to the next person to interview....and ultimately spotting the lie....to get to the truth of who killed your murder victim.   Listening for the lies was the best part. It was really fun trying to match the right contradictions.  It's also the  games most difficult task - finding the exact two sentences that prove a person is lying. Sounds easy... but towards the end there are a lot of sentences and trying to remember which conversations they came from can take a bit of time. They list every thing out for you and provide hints if you need them.  Even though only one person can play in the game at a time, you could play with someone else next to you, figuring it out together would be fun. I only wish it was more interactive...hunting for more physical clues, murder scene etc... I can only image where this developer is going to give us next!

18971846.review:
What is "Contradiction - Spot The Liar!"?
It's an investigative game that uses live-action movies for the entirety of its gameplay. I know, you can read it on the store page, but I need to start from somewhere now, do I?
I think it's one of the best investigative games I have ever played, I loved it in its entirety.

Why?

Well, I loved the acting. I found Detective Jenks really likeable and funny for certain expressions he makes and kind of exaggerated reactions to some of the things he hear from the people he interview.
I loved the case, the story... it left me with the desire to have more. I really want to know more about the background of the case. I'm not going to spoil anything though, you'll have to play it yourself. Trust me, it's going to be a fun ride.

Gameplay wise there's not a lot to say. It's a point and click. You click the names of the locations on the screen to move around ( or use the map to move faster ), you talk with people choosing the clues you want to know more about and when you think you found a contradiction in what the guy said to you, you point it out selecting two pieces of information that contradict each other. Easy and very effective.
It gave me a lot of satisfaction when I actually found out what was the clue, the contradiction, I needed to corner someone.

The game runs really well, didn't encounter any real problem while playing. Just an error that occurred from time to time, inside the pub usually. When I wanted to stop asking Rebecca and tried to leave the pub, almost immediately Jenks called for Becca again as if I clicked the bell again. When that happens an error message pops up in the upper left corner saying that there was an error of some sort and that if that persisted I should have restarted the game.
Nothing bad really happens, no corrupted saves or game breaking bugs so I don't know what the error was really about.

Longevity wise, I think it's long enough for a good experience. I wouldn't be concerned about it.

To wrap this up I highly reccomend this game. It's really nice and if you like investigating stuff and live action movies I think this game is for you.

Ps: I really want another game of this, Jenks is so cool!

18968281.review:
Contradiction is one of those games that you could easily miss, unless you are specifically looking for a FMV game and it would be a real shame to skip past it.

The writing is first class and the story is really interesting and flows flawlessly.  The character development is what keeps you interested throughout and the acting of the cast is matched to any great detective movie.

I am a big fan of point and click games and FMV and its just a shame there aren't more FMV games on the market of this standard.

I really hope there will be a sequel in the near future, even if it has to be done via kickstarter, I for one would happily help fund it.

In short - a great game which will keep you entertained throughout and well worth the money

18959690.review:
I bough this game really not knowing what the expect. The price was good, and so were the reviews and so I thought I would give it a crack. It's not for everybody, but if you are into your murder mystery, and you don't mind spending a little bit of time thinking, it's definitely worth a punt.

18957843.review:
The game initially caught my eye for being an FMV, a rarely used but personal favorite genre of mine. But genres aside, this game was simply put the most fun, enjoyable playing experience I've had all year. Contradiction strikes a perfect balance between smooth, relaxing gameplay and painstaking difficulty. It will test your investigative skills to their limits. 

It's an easy enough concept;  exploring this enigmatic village and speaking to its various eccentric inhabitants in order to solve a mysterious murder. But the challenge lies in truly paying attention to the tiniest details, made harder by an increasingly complex story unraveling all around you. A similar FMV game I played earlier this year, called Missing, showed the same kind of promise. But it was overly bogged down by quicktime events and other mechanics that felt out of place. There's none of that in this game, it's traditional in the best way possible. I would liken it more to older FMV titles like In the First Degree and the Gabriel Knight series. 

The characters are intriguing and interesting, and the acting is perfection--some of the best live performances I've seen in a game. It's dramatic without being contrived or cheesy, with a good dose of humor mixed in. The main lead of Inspector Jenks, played by Rupert Booth, has quickly become a favorite protagonist of mine. It would be a joy to see him reprise this role, and the game opens up a rich world of possibilities when it comes to a sequel or series.  The game truly is challenging, that's no exaggeration... but offers some relief with a hint option if needed. My only complaint, if I had to think of any, would be the sometimes tedious nature of moving around; but there's an option to move more efficiently via a map so I guess that truly leaves me empty-handed when it comes to saying anything negative about this game.

18955617.review: A lot of fun to play through. Enjoyed the acting and characters. Not the usual pick up everything and try every combination everywhere you get from most adventure games - the challenges actually make sense and can be figured out through logic.

18866778.review:
This game is an IOS port and is based on FMV. You are a detective that needs to solve a murder crime by talking to people in the city and collecting objects. You have only a few hours to solve the crime.

This game is structured in hours. After you accomplish everything that is scripted for a segment, the game advances an hour and opens us new places, objects and people to talk to.

What I liked:
The FMV is in full HD glory and well made.
The game is not overpriced.
There is a hint system.

What I did not like:
The acting is campy most of the time.
You are required to visit the same place several times because there might be a new person or object in that location. I hate backtracking.
The game is based on a system that requires you to spot contradictions between dialogues by confronting them. At first, I enjoyed it, however it got old very fast.

Steam only allows me to recommend a game or to not recommend it. I guess "Depends" would be a good recommendation, based on how much you like crime investigations, FMV and lots of backtracing.

Because I did not enjoy and could not care to finish it, I could not recommend it. Instead, I recommend "Her Story" which is also based on FMV and asks you to watch FMV to make sense of a crime. I believe Her Story execution is simply better.

18865943.review: Incredibly well done for the budget. Great acting and awesome story. I can't recommend this game enough.

Plot twists notwithstanding, I would have appreciated a game in which all characters come across as more or less innocent from the beginning. In any case, tremendous fun and highly imaginative. Thank you for your visionary work, I will certainly be looking forward to a sequel!

This is a murder mystery and you’re playing a police officer who is trying to solve the case. You do this by interviewing people, searching for clues, and finding contradictory statements. 18836843.review:
I'm very glad to see the full video adventure games making a come back, thanks to the technology we now have for the actual data storage means and thanks to less expensive video cameras and such. These full video games had emerged eons ago with the CD storage but quickly died because of being terribly expensive to film and because the CD storage wasn't good enough; videos weren't compressed or anything and quickly filled a cd with barely anything. 5 CDs games were legions and were quickly  hated for being cumbersome and annoying to use. Now thanks to a better technology the videos won't rip your eyes out as they did in the past (interlaced mode videos were deadly! ^^) and they can feature more than one hour of filming. And with the digitalized era, we don't have to fiddle with the numerous CDs or DVDs or anything anymore; a couple of clicks on Steam and you're set! Yes, a game all filmed is terribly kitsch but it will have better characters - you do relate more to human beings than to pixels after all. 

Contradiction have a good story, even though it's rather classical it's really well told and unfolded brilliantly. It has good characters and the gameplay of spotting the contradictions is quite effective and fun! Of course it will be a bit harder for non-English native players but it's still doable - if I did it, anyone can lol. The music is good. The game settings slowly going from day to night is clever and effective. The game lasted 7 hours and it was really a fun ride!

In the forum the dev talked about making another similar game, I can't wait! More, please!!

18825971.review:
This game is oustanding fun.

We sat down to try it out and ended up spending 6 hours playing the entire thing in one sitting. The story and characters draw you in almost immediately and you can't help but keep playing as contradictions and evidence gradually get unearthed. 

As far as the story goes, it's an engaging murder mystery set in an English village full of quirky characters. It's a very visually satisfying and well made game. The live action video format is really well used here - it doesn't feel at odds with the gameplay at all and most of the scenes are beautifully shot. The whole thing has a great cast - Jenks, Rebecca, Paul and Ryan are particularly well done. The feel is campy whodunit fun with some sinister undertones and the game balances it very well. It's challenging enough to make you feel like you're putting the detective work in, without being frustratingly impossible. The answers are all there if you look for them and you get a huge feeling of satisfaction every time you catch someone out in a lie.

Fantastic and novel game - fingers crossed for a sequel.

A nice fmv adventure. Nice video quality and sound. 

The goal of the game is to find what happened to Kate (murder or suicide) by investigating a small town and interrogating the people in it. You do that by spotting contradictions (hence the name) in their statements. 

I enjoyed the game although i found the ending a bit more abrupt than i expected and a lot of things left unanswered (probably for a possible sequel). 

I would reccommend the game to the people that enjoy the genre. There are no illogical puzzles and although the contradiction system is iffy at times (the contradictions are not hard to spot but some times there are contradictions that the game just doesn't care about) the game is still worth it. 

As a highlight of the game for me was the main character Inspector Jenks. The actor was really emotive and funny. Cheesy at times but the good kind.

18683286.review:
En Contradiction juegas el rol del Inspector Jenks de la policia que llega a un pequeño pueblo a investigar un suicidio reciente con sospechas de que algo mas sucedió y no fue solo un accidente.

A lo largo de una noche en el juego Jenks tiene que investigar, interrogar, encontrar contradicciones ala Phoenix Wright y resolver el caso para la media noche, Contradiction es un juego 100% cinematografico con hermosos videos en HD con actores decentes, si has jugado Red Alert 2 o 3 podrás darte una idea de como puede ser un juego asi. Mientras que las actuaciones no son un 100% material de Oscar son totalmente perfectas para una pequeña historia de misterio.

Conforme avanzas en la historia y vas conociendo los sospechosos juntas evidencia, temas y objetos que te ayudarán en tu tarea de resolver el caso, si te atoras y no encuentras una solucion para alguna contradiccion el juego te ofrece pistas hasta "cheats" por si lo unico que te interesa es avanzar y ver mas de la trama del caso.

Ampliamente recomendado si te gusta la serie de Phoenix Wright donde encontrar contradicciones en lo que dicen los sospechosos es tu principal arma para progresar en el caso, requeriras de un gran nivel de conocimiento de Ingles ya que el juego no cuenta actualmente con traducciones o subtitulos a otros idiomas, si tienes algo de conocimiento de ingles y buscas subir tu nivel este juego puede ser una gran herramienta escuchar y leer subtitulos te ayudará con pronunciacion y comprension.

Las unicas negativas serian la falta de subtitulos a otros idiomas alejando a todo posible mercado que no es de habla inglesa, aparte un pequeño problema de interfase donde el boton de EXIT deja de funcionar haciendote creer que no tienes otra opcion mas que cerrar el juego a la mala (ALT F4) pero si te llega a suceder tiene una simple solucion, has que el Inspector Jenks vuelva a escuchar cualquier respuesta de algun sospechoso y dale al boton de skip o exit, eso usualmente arregla el bug.

Pros:
+ Experiencia 99% cinematica HD con actores y 1% interface para tu evidencia y menus.
+ Buena actuación de parte de gran parte de los personajes.
+ Interfase facil y simple de usar para navegar en el juego y revisar tu evidencia.
+ Ofrece un buen reto encontrar las contradicciones, tendras que pensarle bien o hacer trampa.

Contras:
- Puede ser muy repetitivo presentar cada evidencia a todos los sospechosos para escuchar que tienen que decir sobre ello, por ejemplo viajar a una granja, subir las escaleras, tocar la campana, hola! mas preguntas! sabes algo sobre este CD? NOPE, ok gracias :D
- Pequeños bugs de interfase como el mencionado arriba sobre el boton EXIT pero tiene facil solucion (lo ideal seria un pache que lo arregle) tambien cada que volvia a iniciar el juego se apagaba la opción de Subtitulos haciendolo una pequeña molestia volverlo a activar cada que volvias al juego.
- Solo en ingles.

Calificación: 8 de 10. 

Altamente recomendable si eres fan de juegos de misterio o aventuras graficas, peliculas interactivas y tienes buen nivel de ingles.

A very well crafted game with a compelling user interface.   They say that this game was created on a tiny budget and it shows but not in any place important.  The actors were very good--they could be (and probably have been) on any quality BBC production.  With a larger budget, they could make the sequel this this truly fantastic.  For example, in this game the characters were always interviewed in the same place.  Ryan seemed to have an endless glass of whiskey over the many hours that the game takes place.  Simon always appears to be in a bright afternoon kitchen even at 11:00 PM.  And Inspector Jenks doesn't have a mobile phone but has to return to a pay phone.

Having the next sequel end with one of the classic mystery wrap ups where you have everyone in the same room and reveal the actual murderer would cost a lot because you would have to record many different video takes that would not be used.  However, the fun there would be you could replay the ending multiple times.

I played this game with my wife and we enjoyed it as much as a good British mystery series--maybe a bit more because it was interactive.  I hope that everyone likes this game as much as I did so that the sequel will be created with a larger budget.

On the whole, spot the liar is exactly what FMV games should be. Tim Follins has figured out a great and simple mechanic to interact with a fairly linear scripted story. Listening to each of the characters detail specific facts only to catch them in a lie is quite rewarding. Although the acting comes across as fairly hammy in the beginning, it grows on you and I'd say works mostly throughout the game.

I played through the entirety of the game with my Girlfriend and we both enjoyed it throughly. The only slight critique I'd have is that the game on occasion requires you to walk around the small village in order to trigger a certain event before letting you continue. There's no real gameplay reason to do this, as the map function conveniently lets you warp most places. In fact, seeing the same travel animations time and time again becomes a little tedious, so it's somewhat counter-intuitive that this is occasionally required for the sake of progression. Perhaps in a future installment the game would force these required encounters if you were to warp past something.

This is - however - a minor detail and on the whole, it was well worth the money spent. Give it a go. It's the type of game that definately deserves a sequel.

It's just like being in an episode of "Midsomer Murders"

Remember back in the 90's when FMV was introduced into PC games? (like Phantasmagoria and the like) well, finally, FINALLY we have a game that takes that potential and adds a good game into the mix.

18600613.review:
There is a certain level of charm exclusive to FMV games. I hated them back then, but now they're all endearing in their own special way. With the computer graphics of today, we can achieve practically anything. That really isn't as exciting as it used to be. Maybe I'm just getting old. I'd probably start yelling at clouds, but I never go outside. Whatever the case, Contradiction - Spot the Liar! is a great example of what the medium is capable of.

Detective Inspector Jenks is tasked with solving the mysterious death of a young woman. Over the course of a single night, he will collect evidence, interview suspects, and discover contradictions. In terms of game-design, the process isn't complicated in any way. Take the Phoenix Wright series for example. In those games, your primary method of progression is tied to spotting contradictions. If you mess up, you're punished with a loss of "life". There are no punishments for mistakes in this game. You can even take as much time as you need to solve the mystery. I appreciate the more casual approach to this investigation. Due to my cautious nature, I tend to save every couple minutes in the Ace Attorney games, which really hurts the pacing. 

An aspect that I really enjoy about this game is it can feel like nothing is really happening. I compare it to the Gene Hackman movie "The French Connection". If you take out the car/L-train chase and the shoot-out at the end, you're left with nearly an hour and a half of "boring" police work. A lot of attention is paid to the characters, and how their mostly fruitless investigation plays out. You'll go through a similar process in this game. With every new piece of evidence, you'll  end up asking everyone what they might know about it. Some won't know anything at all, but you're still treated to an answer. The person you're questioning might also make an odd quip or comment. Even if they don't have anything to do with the investigation, these character moments add a lot of personality. 

That's why I strongly suggest that - unless you're well and truly stuck - you don't use a guide for this game. Aside from spoiling the answers, you're also taking away the immersive qualities of this game. A lot of the detective work in this game could be considered dull, but that's usually how it goes in the real world. Often the evidence won't consist of something significant like a murder weapon or a fingerprint. In any case, since you're essentially working to solve this mystery in a single night, you won't have access to a bunch of CSI gadgets. All you really can do is think about what everyone tells you, and weed out the red herrings.

This game was made on a budget of 3,000 pounds. 3,000! The more I think about it the crazier it sounds. Some of the voice recordings sound a little off, and the "night" scenes were filmed in the day-time, but otherwise there's nothing that really stuck out as cheaply done. The acting is fine as well, though you're liable to remember Rupert Booth's (Jenks) 1,001 facial expressions most of all. He makes even the most banal scenes amusing. 

Definitely give this game a look, especially if it's already in your library.
