18578005.review:
If you like any mystery games at all, this is absolutely, without a doubt, the best one you can find right now. The story is a pretty great murder mystery that most people probably won't guess until the end. Some veterans might realize half-way through, but with the characters in the game, and how well they are acted, you can be led down the wrong road pretty easy. You are kept on track without your hands being held, so you will never truly be lost, but it can steer your guess of who is guilty all over the place.

As I mentioned, the acting is pretty damn good. There are some scenes that are just decent, and the main detective, Jenks, is kind of a goofball, but it's intentional. Pretty much every time you need to know if someone is lying, there is the smallest tell in their acting, but not enough to just give it away easily. I hope they make a sequel, and I hope they keep most of the cast.

The graphics are all really well put together live-action scenes. The transitions are perfectly shot and perfectly timed. The games flow is probably the most impressive thing about it. They give you just enough flair without making you wait too long to get where you want to go. There is also a shortcut system if you want to travel to the other side of the map fast. It's a beautiful game all in all, great stills and great video, all in crisp 1080p.

The controls and UI are very good. You have everything you need and it's not in-your-face. The entire game can also be controlled with the mouse. You click where you want to go, and it gives you a 1-3 second scene of the main character, Detective Jenks, heading there. If you don't want/need any clues, you never have to use them, but it has 3 different layers of hints, not counting the acting tells. The first is a lightbulb button that reminds you who you havent talked to yet and lets you know that you need to go find out if someone is lying, without telling you who. The second is a phone call to your Chief, it lets you know who you should be questioning if you need to narrow it down. Lastly, it allows you to cheat and tells you exactly who to ask about what, if you are stuck.

The only complaint I could even muster about the game, is you end up with a LOT of clues over half-way through. This means a lot of remembering and a lot of scrolling. It keeps all your information for you very neatly organized, best it can, but it gets a little tedious to connect the clues, or contradictions, later on. It's not necessarily a bad thing and certainly isn't badly designed, but it's worth mentioning. Actually pooling similar things together would defeat the purpose of finding the contradictions, so it's nothing they can improve, I just feel bad about writing a perfect review without mentioning even something slightly annoying.

TL:DR

I'm not necessarily a fan of mystery games, mostly because so few of them are good, but I loved every minute of this game and it lasted about 7+ hours. I bought it in a bundle, so it was even better deal for me, but it's worth the base price of $10 for sure, I just didn't know about the game beforehand. But even if you aren't sure about the game, at least get it on a bundle/sale if you like mystery games at all, or even mystery books/movies actually, you will love this.

18569717.review:
This is a very cautious and very reserved recommendation. This game will not be for "everybody". At all. It is quite rough around the edges and suffers a few frustrating faults. But. I personally enjoyed it immensely and think it is very much worth looking in to. I got this game in a bundle without having heard of it or it's Kickstarter campaign. It wasn't on my radar at all, even when purchasing the bundle I had my eye on other titles in it, this was just going to be a “throw in”. But it was easily the star of the bunch! 

The game is impressively well acted, written, and shot. No Oscar performance or anything but also not cheesy in any way. A lot of “FMV” games or live action cutscenes in video games tend to be on the more campy side of things but this finds the balance in between. They're clearly having great fun, but still portraying the characters well. Never a “cringe” moment. The story and writing is solid and deep enough to mostly keep you guessing. And develops a full atmosphere. Then the cinematography or whatever you want to call it is great within the context of it being a game. Exteriors are particularly well framed. 

But it is rough around the edges as I mentioned;

-The “along for the ride” straight line story and not being able to accuse anyone or effect outcomes might bother some but I enjoyed it. Nice casual experience. You don't change the story or have options, you just figure out how to keep it going.

-My biggest issues were some of the “contradiction” choices. You progress the story by presenting evidence to different characters you're interviewing and then taking their answers and finding things that contradict. Doing this flusters them and makes them reveal more to the story. I found at least two of the contradictions annoying in the fact I was on the right track but you had to make sure it was the exact right two statements to get it to trigger. Even though very similar (almost identical) answers wouldn't trigger it. The first time this happened to me I was certain I was on the right track but just happened to not match the perfect two. After circling the map and characters multiple times I thought I bugged the game. Which led me to consult a guide. I felt a "oh comeon!" moment knowing I had virtually pointed out the exact same thing with a different answer. And I hate consulting guides! Haha. But searching for these contradictions led me back to a guide once more later in the game... I feel shame. Then some other contradictions just felt a little too buried in the grey area. And then I'd have to glance over a list of the contradictions somewhere but I also seem to recall an early one not even feeling like a contradiction, but don't quote me on that.  

-The last chapter has a lot of clues uncovered by stumbling across corners of the map manually. Which is fine because I like checking corners and had developed a habit of it every chapter. But the game up to that point triggered these events automatically when fast traveling over the area. Might get someone stuck/annoyed.

-Ending was fine with me but might leave some asking for more. There was a deliberate attempt to put more information than needed in the game to make the detective work worth it but this led to more story arcs that went nowhere. And some unresolved that did go somewhere for a bit. Which is kind of the point as well... We live in a world of sequels. And with some fine tuning and smoothing out I'd look forward to a sequel from the same team! Though I think an entirely new adventure would be more thrilling. Either way I hope the people involved from the gamemakers to the actors have more up their sleeves in some form. 

Its a fair price for the entertainment value if you aren't expecting deep gameplay or any replay value. Me being cheap and the higher percentage chance of the average gamer not enjoying it, I would recommend waiting for a sale or getting it in a bundle of course. But I think $9.99USD is fair for what you get if its in your budget. Check it out!

18452079.review:
To truly appreciate how good this game is, you have to first understand WHAT this game is.  Interactive fiction, yes.  A full-motion video game (FMV), sure.  But more than either of those, it is a modern-day implementation of the age-old tradition of art commission.

A small team of talented and passionate people reached out to the gaming community and humbly petitioned them for support; the help they needed to bring something they truly believed in to life.  In the end, an understandably skeptical KickStarter community offered £4,010.  Let me repeat that.  £4,010.  At that funding level, Contradition is an astonishing achievement; not only in its polish and enjoyability, but also in what had to have been the colossal charity and collaboration of everyone involved in its making.

Contradiction is an interactive fiction experience in the form of a high-definition, full-motion video game.  A young woman has been found dead; drowned in a lake at the outskirts of a charming hamlet in the English country-side.  Detective Jenks arrives on scene at 5:00PM to investigate and finds the inhabitants of the village not nearly as wholesome as their idyllic surroundings.  At the center of it all is an inscrupulous father and son duo and their cut-throat, corporate executive training program, Atlas.  Jenks has until midnight to solve the mystery,  Tour the town, gather the evidence, and interview the witnesses.  Spot the contradictions and help Jenks close the case.  The Chief is counting on you.

This is British Detective Pulp at its finest.  From the quirky and unflappable Detective Jenks to the deliciously villainous patriarch, Paul Rand, great performances throughout elevate the story-telling well past what I would have alllowed a work of this budget and format could deliver.  The settings are lush, but genuine.  The makeup and costumes are "just right" in their tasteful understatement.  The music and sound effects create mood and communicate enviroment in as expert a fashion as I have ever heard.

The game design is both intuitive and innovative.  The control interface is clever and unobstrusive; an asset to he gameplay instead of a necessary evil.  The offering of both a hint system and a full-on "cheat" bailout welcomes players of every commitment level.  Chapter progression marked by advancing hours and subsequent nightfall are perfect for communicating urgency in a natural and realistic way.  The game is altogether worthy as a vehicle for delivering the quality acting and engrossing story.

I ran into only two challenges with the gameplay and those are easily overcome with a couple of no-spoiler hints:

1.  Start every new chapter by walking the entire length of the village, including the nooks and crannies, and entering evey location.  The quick-travel map can result in a vital progress point being missed for a frustratingly long time.

2.  The hourglass symbol that signifies that there is something in the scene for Jenks to investigate is easy to miss.  Watch closely for it, especially when making the aforementioned new-chapter walkthrough.

18437622.review:
Put on your thinking cap, you're deffinately going to need it for this one.

Contradiction is FMV murder mystery game, where you take the roll of Inspector Jenks, trying to solve the case of Kate Vine's "Suicide". 

Now, there's not TOO MUCH to say about this one.

The game has simple controls, just use the mouse to click around and investigate. Gameplay consists of finding evidence, interrogating suspects, and, in the event they contradict themselves, or lie, Calling them Pinnocchio as their nose grows. (The nose doesn't really grow). The further into the game you get, the more evidence you get, making it more difficult to find a contradiction, as you pick through the different topics (Something you WILL have to do), that is, unless you're Sherlock Holmes, in which case you'll have no troubles at all. 

The acting in this is is superb, It really feels like a good detective movie. While there are a few instances of the actors hamming it up, it never really takes you out of the experience. The writing is great as well, the more information you get, the more you, the player, will actually start to speculate "Whudunnit", as it were.

As for the contradictions, Most of them make perfect sense, but there are one or two that, for me, feel like a bit of a stretch. 

The audio is great, you'll hear the crunching of footsteps as Jenks walks around, the relaxing sound of the wind, and even the ticking of a clock in the background of some scenes. I wish I knew where this was filmed, because the scenery is really very good, it's one of those places that you want to visit on vacation.

I'd say this game is a reccomended purchase for anyone who loves a good mystery, and my personal rating is a 9/10 on the whole thing. 

Hope this was helpful!!

18432988.review:
I highly recommend this game!

I bought this game solely because Paul Darrow is in it. I wasn’t expecting much from the game. To my delight, Contradiction – Spot the Liar made for an entertaining evening… and late evening… then early morning…  I hooked my pc to the big screen and played along with a house guest who doesn’t play a lot of video games. We were hooked almost from the beginning. 

The navigation is simple and reminds me of DVD games. I thought the gameplay would get dull – location, interrogate, repeat, but the pace of clues and strength of the acting kept that from happening. Like most games that rely on questioning suspects, there are questions the player wants to ask that never come up. As this relies on finding contradictions, this does become more of an issue at times, but not to a point that crippled gameplay. There are lots of red herrings or lines of inquiry that go nowhere. I can’t tell you how many times we picked up an item and said “Don’t forget what Simon said about that. That’s important.” only to have nothing happen. Rather than annoy, it left us with a longing for a sequel. 

The acting is great. I found Jenks’ shoes and hat a bit annoying, and every time he flourished the evidence at a suspect I expected him to say “Is this your card?”, but it added to his quirkiness. Paul Darrow is great. He brings nuance to the role and is still one of the best “reaction” actors I’ve seen. 

The only real downside is replayability. I’d love to get my game night group together to do this, but it won’t be as much fun for me. I’ll still probably do it. 

If I were the producers, I’d make a 20 minute playable demo using the existing material and mechanics to help sell this and get money for a sequel on Kickstarter. Something that shows off the ease of interrogation and introduces most of the characters would be a great marketing tool and short enough to share with friends (particularly the non-gamer 40-55 demo who would love this game if they knew it existed).

18411602.review:
Contradiction (Widerspruch) ist ein Spiel, das sich wie ein TV-Film spielt. Echte Schauspieler, echte Orte und Umgebungen, nur wenig erinnert an ein Spiel. Also mal was anderes...

Die Handlung spielt in einem englischen Kaff und ein Inspektor aus London ermittelt in einem Todesfall, der sich hier ereignet hat. Selbstmord, wonach es zunächst aussieht oder doch ein Mord? Unsere Aufgabe ist es, diverse Personen zu interviewen und aus den Antworten Rückschlüsse zu ziehen und so am Ende Lügen bzw. die Widersprüche zu entlarven. 

Die Handlung schreitet stundenweise voran und bis Mitternacht weiß man Bescheid. Man muss sich aber nicht gehetzt fühlen, denn die Stunden drehen sich nur weiter, wenn man alle Hinweise zusammen hat und die richtigen Schlüsse gezogen hat. 

Die Personen zu befragen und die wenigen Orte zu besuchen stellt jetzt keinen hohen spielerischen Anspruch dar. Vielmehr ist es so, dass man von einer Person zur anderen läuft und die neuesten Hinweise abfragt. Die wichtigsten Eckpunkte des jeweiligen Gesprächspunktes werden notiert und dann heißt es kombinieren. Zwei Notizpunkte ergeben einen Widerspruch; hat man zwei richtige zusammengesetzt und eine Lüge entlarvt, wird die Person dazu befragt. Ein Beispiel: Jemand sagt, er kenne sich mit Pflanzen nicht aus, hat aber weiter vorher gesagt, er hätte mal Pflanzenkunde studiert. Das Beispiel ist schon fast zu einfach, es gibt nämlich weitaus knifflerige Aussagen. Und je weiter man in der Handlung ist, umso mehr Notizen hat man, die augenscheinlich nicht immer zusammenpassen. Da muss man entweder sehr sehr aufmerksam sein oder zur Not eine Lösung konsultieren. 

Nach 5-6 Stunden Echtzeit hat der Inspektor den Fall gelöst und man darf sich zufrieden zurücklehnen. 

Ich bewerte das Spiel positiv, weil es sich nicht unbedingt in die Länge zieht, auch wenn man mit neuen Hinweisen immer wieder bereits besuchte Personen aufsuchen muss, was in der Realität in etwa so wäre, als käme der Inspektor 20 Mal an einem Nachmittag vorbei. So ist das halt, wenn man in einem Spiel ist. 

Die Darsteller machen ihre Sache gut, das Ganze wirkt recht rund. Weniger ins Gewicht fällt, dass bei manchen Befragungen zur späten Abendzeit (wenn es schon dunkel ist), im Raum offenbar noch Tageslicht vorhanden ist. Auch hat mich der Inspektor nicht hundertprozentig überzeugt, er kam mir etwas übersteigert vor, vielleicht wäre ein anderer Darsteller überzeugender gewesen. Aber sei's drum, das sind Sachen, wegen denen eine Abwertung nicht gerechtfertigt wäre. 

Eine Fortsetzung darf gerne kommen!

18389902.review:
So I am a bit of a video game music nerd. I stumbled across this game when I learned that one of my all-time favorite composers, Tim Follin, had returned to the video games industry since "retiring" from it in 2005 after his amazing talents had been wasted on mostly unknown or poorly received games. It was quite to my surprise that Follin was returning to the industry to work on a game not only as a composer, but as a designer and writer as well. So how does a game made by someone with no design experience who's been absent from the industry for 10 years play? It plays about how you'd expect, for better or for worse. It's not all bad though, Contradiction is charming in a unique way that I think can only be accomplished by a first-time designer who, as far as I can tell, has been isolated from the popular design trends, progressions and philosophies that have developed in the last decade or two.

Contradiction is a full FMV murder mystery game straight out of the 90s which I admit would have been way more eye-rolling if I hadn't just played the excellent "Her Story". You play as Fredrick Jenks, a British detective who is tasked with investigating a murder in a small fictional village. All locations in the village are essentially still frames, even though some are animated, and you can move between the frames by clicking on UI arrows displayed on the screen which always triggers a short movie of Jenks strolling to where you guided him. While interviewing suspects, Jenks has a list of topics he can ask about which when selected, loads an an FMV scene where Jenks grills the suspect about whatever you selected which often then reveals more topics to ask about. The main gameplay mechanic in Contradiction is to find pieces of the suspect's story that don't quite add up or are downright contradictions, hence the title. Most of the contradictions are pretty logical, but some are a little more of a stretch or are otherwise debatable. Thankfully, this game is pretty generous with hints and gives them to you in a way that doesn't make you feel stupid or like you're cheating. Jenks can go to the phone booth and call his chief who will generally point you in the correct direction to progress the game or also may hint at contradictions suspects have made.

Follin, whose composing career work dates all the way back to the Commodore 64 and ZX Spectrum days, also composed the music in Contradiction. It's not quite as in-your-face as some of my other favorites of his. It's more appropriately subtle and blends in perfectly as Jenks traverses the village looking for clues and interviewing suspects. Aside from the music, the extremely cheesy acting is another standout in Contradiction, especially with the actor portraying Jenks who loves to smirk at his suspects with his trademark goofy deductive grin. In fact, Jenks is so excitably overanimated and the acting in general is so cheesy that it makes me wonder if it was an intentional directorial choice or if Follin actually thought his actors were delivering believable performances. In any case, I'm happy about it. The delightfully cheesy acting seems to fit the style of this game perfectly as does the music.

But in addition to the cheesy acting, there are several other strange design choices and signs of low budget production you should be at least aware of before playing this game, especially if that sort of thing bothers you. I've heard this game was riddled with UI problems at launch that have since been corrected, but one holdover is the strange combination of topics Jenks can ask about with the physical items he's carrying into one functional grouping. Your items and your topics appear together, but you can't use a topic like an item and most items you can't bring up in conversation, making this a puzzling design choice. I've also encountered a bug a few times where none of the suspect's answers were selectable as contradictions and I had to leave and re-enter the scene in order to fix it. (Minor spoilers ahead). The budgetary constraints this game was made were apparent in the poor sound quality in the FMV scenes but especially obvious in the ending to this game. The latter half of the game really seems as though its building up to something as the plot starts sprinkling in elements of the occult and mysticism. But it's all thrown away at the last second when the murderer is revealed and the game just ends quickly and unceremoniously - but not before strangely setting itself up for a sequel. I later read that this abrupt ending was apparently due to financial constraints and a sequel would only be possible with enough support of the first game

Summary
It has design problems, bugs, obvious budget problems and wonderfully cheesy acting but I really enjoyed Contradiction in spite of itself. It was a flashback to the old puzzle games I played as a kid. All things considered, Contradiction is a pretty good first attempt at making a game for someone who has no experience doing this sort of thing. At the very least, I'm glad Follin is back doing things in the games industry and I hope he gets the funding and support to make a sequel so we can see what lessons were learned and what improvements can be made

For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

18371051.review:
最近迷上了真人影像的游戏，继Her Story之后。但是感觉这款游戏设计的没有Her Story那么精巧，当然不是指拍摄部分啦，画面还是非常棒的。

优点：
1. 高清画面，有些场景美的可以直接截屏做壁纸
2. 找到矛盾的设定，类似于逆转裁判，不过显然没有逆转裁判做的那么戏剧化，更偏于真实平淡
3. 错综复杂的剧情糅合了宗教、心理元素，据说正在筹资做续作
4. 各种游戏操作（相对Her Story）比较丰富，另外都比较真实，所有的道具使用后都不会扔掉（陆夫人实况时经常看到的吐槽2333还好没出现物理学圣剑）除了不戴手套拿证物，还有侦探先生夸张的盘问表情之类的。

缺点：
1. 游戏系统到后来就是套路，找东西、盘问、找矛盾，到了新的时间点各个地方触发一遍剧情，卡关的时候只能点tips和打电话给警长（有的时候tips还提示得莫名其妙）（没有选择cheat因为会拿不到成就）
2. 确实很真实，线索和矛盾隐藏在大量冗余的信息中，但是！这也导致游戏的难度升高，乐趣降低，很难找到矛盾点，尤其对英语苦手。
3. 这点是对于英语苦手的，有一些宗教、心理、药物方面的生僻词汇，有一次我卡在了morphine处，因为我只知道这玩意是安眠药，并不知道它是吗啡含有罂粟成分。。。。

总的来说，游戏的方式比Her Story多，但是各种引导玩家去探索和触发这些线索的设计并不那么精巧，我觉得这样的游戏除了剧情设计复杂引人之外，需要有引导或者暗示玩家的设计，来服务像我一样智商比较捉急的玩家……这点我有些佩服现实的办案人员，在一堆冗余信息里找到有用的东西。。。

因为没有人写过中文测评，所以写一篇服务同胞，推荐这款游戏，各方面表现都相当不错，10刀挺值的，不过其实我是在论坛里要了人家免费赠送的50%coupon买了这款游戏，感谢Majestic Bum。

Thanks for your coupon, Majestic Bum!

P.S. 大家玩的多游戏制作者得到的支持越多，就越有可能有续作，That's why I recommend the game! The true purpose! lol

18338792.review:
After watching some eps from Jesse and Dodger's playthrough of it I had to go out and get this for myself and it was probably the most fun I've had with a mystery game like this. Most mystery adventure games I've played are pretty serious, gets you into the mood because it's crime game. Contradiction, while it didn't get me into a serious mood, it did get me into a mood that made me really care about Jenks, very invested into Atlus, and wanting to close this case. Also, the actors... Though the acting is kind of weak at some points it really added to their personality and how you feel about them and this game (Jenks, Paul, Rebecca, and James being my faves). I had so much fun playing this game and I really do hope they end up making a sequel because I really want to know more about Atlus OR have Jenks in more games. He can really be the Sherlock or Nancy of FMVs.

Now... All that being said, I do feel that the ending came about a little too... simple. You closed the case you came here for, but now you're left with so may questions that can be brought up in later installments; I get it. Well, I liked it. The contradictions, if sometimes a little far-fetched, are difficult enough to feeling challenging but not so completely off the wall that you rage quit in frustration. The UI is clunky but in a way that strangely adds to the charm. The acting's got plenty of ham going on, which, again, adds to the charm. And I liked the story - including the ending.

The big downside for me is the lack of a proper 'fail state'. You can't really mess this game up - you'll just be left to walking around until the puzzle solution dawns on you. 18322278.review:
[b]Non Spoiler Section![/b]

It's a fantastic game. Not perfect, but almost certainly the best FMV game I've ever seen & quite possibly the best FVM game made so far. I made my way through it in just under 6 hours, and feel I got excellent value for money at that, because of the unique nature of the game when compared to most games out there.

I played it solo and it's great fun that way, but I imagine it'd be even more awesome played with friends/family (that's certainly what I'm currently planning if/when there's another one - possibly even with this one once I've had time to forget enough of the specific contradictions). 

Anyway: the visual quality is great,  the soundtrack is awesome (both music and environmental sounds) and the acting is pretty much spot on for me. Yes Jenks is rather over the top, but I get the feeling he's meant to be. It certainly worked well for me, because Jenks, being 'my' character, ended up reflecting my sense of triumph at finding a contradiction, or my bafflement at asking about the same mundane thing again, as a result.

There are still things that could be improved. In a future patch, or a next instalment, I'd love to see hybrid keyboard/mouse control added. I preferred the mouse driven interface for questioning, but as things stand that meant also using the mouse to walk around, which I actually liked the keyboard better for. It's not a huge issue though, and the game is certainly quite playable with either.

At times it can also be annoying that the game doesn't permit follow-up questions except by finding contradictions. This is an inevitable limitation of the format, but it can be annoying to have spotted something (or have made a conjecture) and find yourself unable to ask about it for quite a while, until something comes along to create a contradiction that does allow you to ask about it at last.



Coming up: some minor spoilers, you have been warned!



Sorry, don't mean to bother you, but you have been warned about minor spoilers, right?



You're sure?



Quite sure?



[b]Spoiler Section![/b]

Okay then, let's start with the ending. I'm fine with it, but can see where some people would find it annoying. Inspector Jenks gets his alien/man/woman/demon/killer-rabbit (I'm not going to spoil that much) as you would expect from a game like this. But a lot of other loose threads are left unresolved. For me personally there is enough closure this way to let the game stand alone, but quite a lot of it does seem to be setting up/teasing a sequel (and I enjoyed it enough that I hope it does get one).

The story does have a few weak spots, the most obvious one being Jenks having apparently no way to leave the village or call in support when he feels threatened. Or the fact that there's no way to request more information on anyone beyond what you're given in the introduction.

Still, in the end, the story holds up well enough and makes an excellent vehicle for some terrific gameplay, which is what matters in this case.

18319939.review:
TLDR: Absolutely worth buying if you like FMV games (like Tex Murphy) or want to try them out. ~5-7hrs gameplay.

Absolutely loved the game, reminded me a lot of the old Tex Murphy games. Good mystery and suspense. Well shot and well acted.

It takes about 5-7 hours to complete, and doesn't really have any replay value As there is no branching options and you need to complete all of part x to unlock part y. Having said that it is enjoyable enough to maybe play through a second time. For me personally the price felt about right for the content received. 

Actual interactive gameplay is minimal, however the challenge and fun comes from finding the right contradictions within the interview system. 

There is only a small amount of text acting as a tutorial and if you miss it some aspects of the game can be confusing and frustrating. Such as why can't I use one characters responses against someone else? . Once you get use to and understand the system however you will find it works really well within the game.

The main downsides from the game are twofold. 

Firstly the story feels incomplete like there needs to be a bit more to give a better conclusion to the Atlas sotryline. While you complete your origianl goal the ending feels somewhat abrupt. Hopefully a sequel or some DLC will fix this.

Secondly the navigation feels clunky - with a lot of clicks to move around the place (a better mini map might be a suggestion, or better placed pins. Also there are a number of areas that are only used once in the entire game, yet remain clickable - there either needs to be things to do there, or they need to dissapear once you discover what you need to. 

Overall this was a great game, well worth playing and I eagerly await the sequel so I can rejoin Jenks on his investigations.

Like others I ended up buying this because of the Jesse Cox and Dodger LP.

18306192.review:
A lovely FMV (Full Motion Video) experience set in a humble environment and a cast of certainly eccentric characters. I really love the delivery from the actors/actresses since that's the meat of the game when interrogating them as suspects (OMG Jenks!!! xD). 

Also another aspect of Contradiction that should be praised are the different levels of hints available to you for support. If you get stuck after asking everyone around and collecting any items available at a time, you can call the Police Chief who can give you subtle hints as to where your should focus your attention on to progress through the game. If all else fails, the tips or "cheats" can give you straight answers, meaning the game itself bypasses the need to leave the game and look up the internet for solutions. This means you remain in the experience but also can afford to see solutions to your current problem without spoiling yourself with accidental glances at a whole walkthrough.

The music is subtle but very appropriate to this game with an orchestral flair. Upbeat as it may be at times, I also found that most of the time there seemed to be an overarching sombre atmosphere. This made me feel sad that as fun as playing a detective solving a mystery can be, the story is still dealing with a tragedy. Props to the soundtrack.

Gameplay wise, the choice between using the keyboard or mouse only is very much appreciated. Also the inclusion of an overhead map that is accessible at all times (except when interviewing suspects) really helped to get to places quicker than slowly walking scene by scene to places.

In terms of criticisms, I really don't have any at the moment except for two small things. Without getting into any spoilers, personally the ending was a bit rushed and left a few story threads unresolved. Also there aren't any branching paths in terms of progression meaning progression is rather linear. However having delved into a little history behind the development of this game, it was a marvel that the developer managed to create such a smooth and wonderful FMV gaming experience on such a small budget. Also the way the story is set up, a follow up sequel would definitely make sense to expand upon the intriguing world and characters introduced in Contradiction. 

But don't let this intimidate you as I personally felt the majority of the story isn't necessarily left on a major cliff-hanger as this game presents a rather great self contained plotline with a potential for more on the horizon.

All in all, loved playing what is essentially a choose your own adventure game wrapped in a film like presentation.

TL:DR Really fun game with a slick and simple interrogation system accompanied by hilarious characters with entertaining acting.

This was really a ton of fun.  I was a bit wary at first because I was afraid you wouldn't really be doing very much actual playing, but the contradictions are so fun to dig out and it always feels like an accomplishment to exult in when you catch someone in a lie.  It really is one of the best games I've played this year and it has left me satisfied but still wanting more.  I'm very excited to see a sequel.

It does have its weak points, but most mystery plots do.  You will find yourself yelling at characters to notice things that seem so obvious but they totally ignore.  But if it can happen to Sherlock I can forgive them a bit.  It did not take away from the enjoyment for me at all.

The acting is spot on.  If you like British television, especially their mysteries, or really any sort of whodunnit style entertainment then this will be right up your alley.  It has all the intrigue with a hint of the macabre lurking around every corner.  There are campy characters who you will find yourself laughing out loud at constantly and ones with such gravitas that you actually find yourself shrinking back in your seat in intimidation.

So yeah, this is well worth the $10 and the 6-8 hours of your time for a playthrough.  I would not say there is much in terms of replay value, but I did finish with 96% completion and am really curious to see what I missed.  I would love for them to allow you to go back and conduct interviews after the finale just so you can try to find that elusive contradiction.

I'm not normally one for reviews but this game deserves one, this game is everything you'd want in terms of acting and story to the point that I found myself often jumping at the bit to try and figure out the "contradiction" just for a few more lines of dialogue wonderfully acted out.

In terms of difficulty its pretty simple once you get a vague idea how this game works as opposed to finding similar answers you look for the "contradicting" ones which usually need hard evidence, while some games would have you take responses between characters everything in contradiction is based on one character.

An example of the system would be:

Sarah says bob doesnt do this

Bob says he does

It doesn't matter what Sarah said you want to contradict bob so perhaps bob says he hates doing that in one answer, yet he does it in another.

18140566.review:
Contradiction is a engaging "experimental independent game" where the player interviews characters and uses their statements against them to uncover the mysteries surrounding a young woman's death.  It's a quick but highly engrossing game with plenty of Christie-style twists and turns that should keep any player interested from start to finish.

All game play is HD full motion video with real actors.  This is part of the "experimental" aspect of the game.  The idea is that the player is interacting with a short movie, or possibly a TV show, on a fundamental level.  While I feel like the game missed that intended mark, the FMV added charm and personality to the game that traditional CG graphics wouldn't have achieved.  The acting is on-point.  The characters are stocky but effective.  The writing results in several genuinely heartfelt, menacing, and terrifying moments that make unlocking scenes and finding the next clue exhilarating.  The story is linear--there is one murderer with one motive--and while this doesn't bother me, I would be interested in seeing any future installments playing with a "choose your own adventure" theme.

Mechanically, Contradiction is a simple point-and-click adventure.  You use your mouse (or the arrows on your keyboard) to move around the map, choose clues from a list, and find contradictions.  It doesn't bring anything new to the genre, except for maybe the cut scenes, and it does fall into a lot of the same issues that other traditional adventure games are prone to.  My playthrough involved a lot of walking back and forth between locations whenever I got stuck, easily adding on another hour to an hour and a half to my play time.  There were also a few extended cut scenes that definitely felt like they were intended to be part of a longer interview section, but were gutted to meet the developers' very strict budget.

I can't say that Contradiction is a difficult game.  The contradictions themselves, with an exception here and there, were easy enough to find.  Rather, Contradiction runs the risk of being frustrating.  There is a lot of evidence, a lot of characters, and a lot of dead ends and red herrings to sort through in order to get to the end of the game.  The game keeps track of everything each character has said, but it's on the player to remember what six different characters said about upwards of two dozen pieces of evidence.  Increasing potential frustration is the fact that contradictory statements have to come from the same character to count.  The player can't use what character A said against character B until character B slips up.  And then characters A through F say the exact same thing about a piece of evidence, which doesn't get you anywhere.

And while I found the ending of the story to be satisfying and clever in hindsight, I thought that the last piece of evidence was a little disappointing, if only because it was maybe too obvious, especially after all of the running around we did.

Overall, I would give Contradiction a 9/10.  The developers have done a lot with a simple concept by focusing on what makes the game unique.  By keeping it a relatively short game--5-7 hours tops--Contradiction stands out as an excellent Friday night game to share with friends.  Like any good story, there's room for speculation and growth.  Even if we never return to Edenton, Baggy Cat has succeeded in a lasting and endlessly enjoyable classic mystery.

A very fun experience. The actor playing Jenks kept the entire story light and fun despite the dark connotations of the events. He might have gone a bit too far with silly faces from time to time but honestly it was refreshing and entertaining given nonstop wicked overtones.

Pros
The acting is well done for such a small budget, Jenks is straight up wacky in some scenes and calm and reflective in others. I cant imagine he takes his job too seriously. Its a shame because I feel like there are some specific scenes where acting more like a professional and being more concerned for his personal safety would add to the character rather then feel disjointed.
The musical score was very involved as well, gave a nonstop air of foreboding that really helped to set the mood and atmosphere of the game. It also sounded like the major plot points and reveals happened to often coincide with heavy piano notes being played. Could be my imagination but I think that it was done intentionally.

Cons
The interface was a bit jarring at first until you got used to it, various topics would highlight as green while others stayed blue but this didnt actually translate to any hints or topics you should try to converse next. It felt random and led to lots of extra time spent re-exploring topics that werent needed to find contradictions that didnt exist
You will find dozens of things that people say that are contradictory by definition that dont lead to cutscenes, this can be  frustrating over time as you feel that you caught a person in their lies but the payoff never results of actually discussing it with them. Likely this was an error of budget contraints or logical omissions in the games story and script. Either way I would highly encourage the developement team to either include cutscenes for each of these in future games, or more carefully write the dialog so that we dont spend half the game pouring over linking contradictions that aren't intended by the developer.

18078997.review:
A very good murder mystery with a spot-the-liar mechanic.

So this game is exactly what you expect from it, you're gradually advancing dialogs by spotting two arguments that contradict each other. That's really the meat of the game. Basically if you enjoy murder mysteries and instead of getting the solution served on a platter as the non-interactive-movies do, you want to be the detective who spots the contradiction, this is the game for you. If you don't there's nothing here for you.

Question is, is it good?
The short answer to that is yes. 
The story is excellent. It's interesting and at every part you know what's going on, there's no real plotholes or things that seem too far fetched.
The acting is just lovable. It's serious, but it got charme and actually that charme keeps you playing. You just want to see the next line of dialoge. You want to see inspector Jenks asking "what do you know about this?". You want to see the response from the the villains. This could easily become a boring experience with the wrong actors, luckily they are just perfect, with Rupert Booth (Jenks) and Paul Darrow (Paul) easily the best. Everything also is also very fitting, the scenery, the directing, the edeting. Everything that is film in this game is just very good.
Are the riddles good? - Yes they are. Without any more spoilers all the dialog riddles are good. It's enjoyable.

So are there any downsides? Certainly there are
Character have a habit of conveniently dropping stuff on the floor - to the point of it beeing so ridicoulous, it's almost a running gag, seriously, if a character drops one item accidentally, it's believable, if it's rougly 10 items... it's a bit less believable. 
The items are used to unlock sites and further conversation, These little item riddles are more for the immersion and the feeling of doing investigation outside the dialogs, but are real no-brainers. It's all very conveniently placed and the feeling of accomplishment isn't there in those moments, the meat is really in the dialog, not the item-riddles.
The interface isn't the best either, but the game can get away with it and my biggest complaint. The interface tends to bug out. Sometimes you can't click on stuff, have to go to the menu and come back. Really guys, in a game with such minimalistic gameplay, you can still do bugs?
Also there are several contradictions in the game, which you can't spot or can only spot later. There's a guy drinking whiskey and claiming there's no alcohol around. One guy claims to have known the victim, yet claims she was blonde, when the was in fact brunette and a couple more of these and most infamously, the last contradiction, which I won't give away at this point.

All in all the pros largly outweigh the cons for this game. Yes there is stuff I expect to be made better in a hopefully comming sequel, but nothing that diminishes the experience of this game. It's a niché game and if you aren't into this, it's certainly not for you, but it's one of these projects where the lacking budget had to be compensated with even more passion for the project and it shows. I had about 10 hours of fun out of this 10 bucks game. I was uncertain about the purchase at first, because it looks like a game that really easily could have failed at so many points. Luckily it didn't and has been one of the best games of the year for me this far.

18067835.review:
I decided to buy the game after seeing the first two episodes of Jesse Cox & Dodger's playthrough of it, and it's an interesting game if perhaps leaving a lot of decision making out of the equation at times (such as non-interactive cutscenes that could have been timed puzzles/QTEs) and you can't accuse/arrest the wrong person, which I add only for completion as that may or may not be important to you as a player.

I appreciate the HD video, but at times not the acting which can range from being (unintentionally?) comical (especially the player character Inspector Jenks, who also perhaps got his dress sense cues from McCloud rather than Morse, which I find to be diverting) and then the acting being ineffectua throughl to playing the scenes straight. The story is okay, but could have been solved almost immediately with the all-important clue being blatantly obvious and yet the option to compare and contrast the statements given yielded no results.  Not until the final in-game hour anyway.

Then there are the elements of a paranormal/horror plot, which sadly was only touched upon and could have made this much more of a game. More than likely the budget constraints put paid to developing that plot, but at least there were little touches in the form of short scenes informing the player of potential events (one I recall being optional, that being the scene in the Reading Room where you're told to go away because "we're about to start a session").

As it stands, I achieved a 96% completion rate by the end of the game. This says to me that there is a way to solve another murder mystery that crops up, but there isn't any warning box/prompt before selecting the option that ends the game.

You cannot fail to get the murderer of the student that Inspector Jenks is investigating the death of, which for me makes the whole experience feel more like a guided tour that you unlock pieces of if you compare the right choices, but that's it. If Contradiction had much more of a budget? Then we could have had a potential Tex Murphy-esque game to play, but right now I can only recommend this to those who don't want to wait for the aforementioned (or any other) Let's Play to be completed or as a party game given that £6.99 is a fair enough price and I got some enjoyment out of it with about 9 hours of play.

All said and done though, there is potential here and I would like to see the developer take another stab at making a detective adventure game.

ADDITIONAL: This, as per the game's Steam store page, is perhaps best played with two or more people as opposed to solo like I did. In that case, I'd say it would play out like a Cluedo-esque murder mystery evening. Approaching Contradiction in this manner would, in my view, override any qualms about the acting and improve the experience overall.

There are some glitches in the form of typos ("North [i]Lane[/i]" instead of "North [i]Road[/i]" when outside the pub) and also in the conversation with Rebecca (her name is sometimes spelled as "Rbecca" and a summary statement of hers that should start with "Usually" has been misspelled as "Ususally", I've preserved the casing for the developer to quickly get to the problem); Steam integration isn't perfect (the Steam overlay and the taking of screenshots isn't possible at this time); when you get to the end of the credits, the "resume" button is available and Jenks acts as though the conversation with the person-in-question ended normally, however the final end credit text is still overlaid on the screen and prevents access to the game's UI (ALT+F4 to the rescue at that point).  Given the developer is [b]very[/b] quick at updating (again, as per the game's Steam store page), I expect all these will be fixed soon enough.

I vaguely recall other typos being present, but I can't recall them right now. To the developer, be assured I mean no disrespect and I have added all this to help you/yourselves in refining your game. :)

Furthermore, I've tidied up my own review for the purposes of clarity. :)

18067184.review:
I had high hopes for this game but unfortunately, despite a shiny exterior, it left me frustrated and bored.  I'll start with the bad and then skip to the good stuff:

1. I quickly tired of circling around and around and around and around asking a handful of characters one or two questions at a time.  I appreciate that the makers *tried* to make it less repetitive by letting us skip around on the map but it was still a couple steps each time - e.g. to get from Simon's to Atlas, you could skip all the way across the map, but then you had to click to get into the grounds, click to get into the entryway, click to get into the next room (forget what it's called), then click to get into Ryan's office.  Every time you wanted to visit.  It just got VERY boring going James-Rebecca-Simon/Emma-Ryan-Ryan-Simon/Emma-Rebecca/James, with the occasional search the woods & call the chief thrown in for, uh... variety?

2. Semi-related to the above, one's pace in the game felt extremely restricted.  I couldn't decide I wanted to ask about "such and such", I had to wait for the game to let me.  I couldn't decide "I want to go further this way", I had to wait for the game to let me.  What was really frustrating was when I looked up the solution and a major clue - as I see someone else in another negative review has already mentioned - shows up almost immediately, and you *can't ask about it*.  I mean it's so bloody obvious that I wasted a lot of time in the beginning trying to *find* a way to ask about it because it seemed impossible that an actual inspector wouldn't take one look at that clue and say "... hey, waitaminute."  I eventually gave up, but throughout the game I felt like the questioning method functioned the way it did just to slow you down and increase the gametime (e.g. you have to find something *one* character has contradicted themselves on, you can't say "hang on, so and so said this about you and that contradicts what you said" - again, what kind of lousy, lousy detective would you have to be...?), and that, well, kind of reinforces that feeling.

Things I did love:

1. The live video idea is a lot of fun and I admired it even as I grew more and more bored with the actual story.  I would like to see this done again, just with a less repetitive, restrictive game behind it.  I especially like the guy playing Jenks (he's very clearly enjoying the hell out of himself) but of all the characters I saw, they were all doing a good job at the acting - which you can't always depend on in smaller games.

2. I really love the system where you can ask for hints or outright 'cheats' without any real punishment (except a 'count' of cheats if you use those).  I've always felt that story-based games might as well let people who aren't as good of players enjoy the game by giving them a helping hand - it's a lot less intrusive to the story to be able to click on a quick 'hint' icon and get a nudge in the right direction than to alt-tab out, go search for a walkthrough, try and find the point you need without spoiling yourself for the rest of the game, alt-tab back in and continue.

3. Despite my complaint above, I do like *some* of how questioning was set up - i.e. you had a list of things you wanted to ask about, it let you know if you'd already asked them and kept a record of their responses, and you could review people's responses by person or by item.  At its heart, that's a nice design.

Contradiction was a really interesting game. It definitely had that old school point and click vibe going on, but mostly I was reminded of Phoenix Wright. The investigation segments, and of course the interviews were a lot like cross examining a witness, listening to their statements and presenting them with evidence to the contrary. The story is fascinating. There's so much going on in that small town, this game barely scratches the surface. The acting is pretty good. Paul Rand is spot-on as a cold, methodical character. Inspector Jenks is a clever guy. Everyone settles into their role well, giving the game a good feel.

The soundtrack was good. It was never too invasive, and during some of the interview segments it really served to puncutate statements well. Visually, it's all live action. Some people might gripe that later on in the game as it gets close to midnight, it's really not as dark as it should be outside, but I would argue that what they chose to do for those times is better because you can actually see what's going on, something that I imagine would have been much harder had they filmed at night.

I'd like to see this game get a sequel. There's just so much more to touch on with Atlas, and the Rands. I hope it gets the funding it needs.

18049629.review:
Contradiction is essentially a FMV (Full-Motion Video) crime novel with point&click elements. I'm not gonna lie, at first I expected a disaster because the premise reminded me a lot of the FMV fad in the 80's and 90's, where you could get these "interactive movies" that had little prompts pop up on the screen sometimes and you could use the remote to choose what will happen. Haven't heard about those? No wonder, the fad never really caught on, and for good reason: IT WAS HORRIBLE. The story was almost always stupid as hell, the acting was atrocious and the production value usually rivaled a ground school drama play. But it wasn't always just movies, FMV was mixed into video games at the time, which made it even worse. The corny acting and pixelated, low-res video was jarring against the blocky 2D (or faux-3D) graphics of the era. In short, technology just wasn't there yet. Fast-forward 20 years, and we get Contradiction. I'll be honest, I didn't expect much, but the premise of seeing an FMV disaster after so many years just made me itch for nostalgia. It was surprisingly cheap, so I bought it for sh!ts and giggles. Turns out, I was wrong on so many levels. 

Apparently, technology advanced far enough to make FMV a pretty damn viable form of storytelling. Contradiction looks very good! High definition video, pretty locations with nice sets and I really liked the little cutscenes of transitioning between shots/scenes. Most of the locations have different views depending on where we arrive from, it's a nice little touch that adds a lot to the immersion I think. The technical aspect is also nice, really good editing, shot composition and angles, it's all unexpectedly high quality work for a pretty low-budget production. But, not matter how pretty the window-dressing is, what makes or breaks a medium like this, is the acting and the story. 

The acting is...okay. Which in itself is far better than any FMV thing I've seen back in the day. The actors' performances range from "pretty good" to "don't quit your dayjob". I really liked Paul, Emma and Rebecca was okay, the rest of the cast is kinda forgettable. Except for one guy, Inspector Jenks, who was pretty much a disaster. This is particularly bad, since he is the protagonist, and we have to watch him all the time! His performance is truly cringe-worthy, the guy dreadfully overacts every single line, so he comes off more like a circus clown instead of a police inspector. It really grates on you, it's nails-on-chalkboard level at some parts, so the game becomes more of an endurance test instead of a detective story. (I would criticize Ryan's performance too, but since that character was designed to be a pompous, annoying jerk, I can only say: mission friggin accomplished!)

As for the story: it's better than I expected. It has a few twists and turns, but nothing spectacular. There is more mystery and intensity in an episode of Murder She Wrote, but Contradiction essentially being an amateur garage project, you can't really expect Sherlock-level storytelling, can you? It starts out really strong and keeps the interest up with new reveals and builds momentum constantly, but...there is one huge problem: the ending. I won't spoil anything, but this was without doubt one of the worst, flimsiest endings I've seen in a long while. The story was doing a great job of building up to a potentially grand finale, and at the very end it just goes and throws all that away in favor of a shoddy cop-out. I don't get it, if it's supposed to be sequel-bait or something like that, but it really overshadowed the whole experience for me...

For gameplay, well, there isn't much to tell. It's a sort of "point&click for dummies". The game mainly consists of interrogating people around town about facts or things you've found, and finding contradictions in their answers (hence the title). At first, it's pretty straightforward, but as the story unfolds, your list of clues and answers grows exponentially, to the point you'll be strained to sift through everything when looking for contradictions. Some of them are quite hard to get, so sometimes it devolves into flat out guesswork or the good 'ol "rub everything on everything until something works" method puzzle solving. Thankfully, the game is pretty generous about handing out tips, and there is even a cheat system, when activated, it outright tells you what you should do next...you know, in case you wanna rob yourself of actually playing the game.

Despite all the criticism I leveled at Contradiction, it was truly a nice surprise. It's an FMV video game that DOESN'T SUCK, in fact, it's pretty decent for what it is. It's surprisingly cheap and has plenty of content. It's an enjoyable detective story with a few good twists, and if you can excuse the tedious endgame and the terrible finale, it's a really nice experience! I'll be getting the sequel, if there's ever gonna be one. I really recommend this game if you wanna try something unique, or if you wanna finally wash off that awful taste those old and horrible FMV games left you with all those years ago :)

18016572.review:
I was very impressed with this game. If you like mystery TV shows or movies, you will absolutely love this game.

I usually have problems with adventure point-and-click games, I want to like them, but after an hour I usually just stop caring about the story, I end up skipping over all the dialog, I get frustrated with the pointless inventory puzzles, and next thing you know I give up and delete the game. Contradiction didn't have any of these problems and is one of the only adventure games I have ever completely finished. The story was captivating. By using real actors (only two of which had talent, but the rest were decent enough) and very high-quality video, the game made the story feel real and compelling. Inventory puzzles are downplayed (almost non-existent) and are replaced instead by dialog puzzles. Basically, to win the game, you need to interview the towns people, carefully listen to and understand everything that everyone is saying. By cross-interwiewing multiple people, contradictions in their stories emerge and by identifying these contradictions, you unlock new clues, new suspects, and new bits of the story. Despite the fact that that this game feels a lot like a British mystery TV mini-series, the interactivity is still quite high as it is up to you to figure things out. The puzzles are all logical but often not immediatley obvious, making this a satisfying and well-balanced game. I highly recommend this game and I hope that there will be a sequel!

If you like mystery games or if you like FMV's, I'd recommend Contradiction. I really want to see/play a sequel.

17869328.review:
I would absolutely recommend this to any fan of FMV games, or even point-and-click adventure games. 

First, in terms of presentation, this game rocks high res video that looks great. I played it on my 55 inch Sony using my "Steambox" living room PC and the game looked like a movie. 

As to the acting, I found the characters to be top-notch and each portrayed a distinct personality. I found them all interesting and compelling. Some of them had me fooled and at times I would go back and forth as to who was the murderer. 

The narrative itself was engaging and drew me into the story's web of characters and contradictions. I kept wanting to play more and more to learn about Atlus and the mysterious circumstances of Kate Vine's death. There wasn't really a dull moment. However, there are some red herrings scattered about and some loose ends that don't get tied up by the end. I found these issues to be a double edged sword. On one hand, they leave you wanting more but on the other, it seems that the writers just didn't know where else to go or didn't have the resources to flesh out certain plot points. 

Finally, the contradictions: the game is based around finding the contradictions among the witnesses. The system works, for the most part, and really shines when various contradictions jump at you and you have an "Ah-ha!" moment. Some contradictions, however, were tenuous at best. In fact, I think some could be argued not to be contradictions at all, yet the game will not progress unless they are pointed out. I regrettably had to look at a walkthrough after getting stumped two times. I hated the fact that I couldn't find the remaining contradiction those times. When I learned what it was that I missed, I found myself rolling my eyes because the contradiction was a little too convoluted to have spotted and wasn't really intuitive. I guess that's the point--contradictions aren't always easy to spot. But this is a game and shouldn't be too taxing!

I really recommend this game and hope there's a sequel.

17844820.review:
Contradiction the All-Video Murder Mystery Adventure is a video game tells a story that you play as inspector Jenks to investigate a bright PHD student named Kate Vine who drowned in a lake at the midnight in a small village called Edenton in England. 

The police force committed it as suicide case, but there are unusual questionable facts lying beneath it.  And you’re the one who is willing to unveil the truth, and bring the justice to itself.

The game itself may look like very "simple" designed and uninteresting. However, the magic trick is: it turns the very simplest system into a quite brilliant and incredibly addicting experience to really play with. You need to think really hard as a detective in order to find the proofs against dishonest interviewees, and to read their answers again and again to solve the puzzle and uncover the truth. 

They introduced a “Contradition System” to match 2 different answers from the same interviewee to reveal whether he/she is lying.  And the successful results  will make your progress go further.

The gameplay is very addicting (might result you can’t stop saying: “Yes! I did it!”). And yet, the price is highly competitive.

Personally, I think the price is fair, far beyond lots of AAA title games that sell twice expensive as this game is, with very forgettable storyline that only worth 1 playing through.

Contradiction is different, for its unique way of unfolding the crime mystery and the ultimate experience that precisely delivers to its audience. It’s certainly one of the fewest games that will make you remember it once for a while.  It is also one of the fewest games that I can seriously recommend and commented as “worth every penny you’ve just spent”.

I write this review mainly because I saw none of my friends have already own this game, and would like to contribute a bit to the community. If you’d interested into crime puzzle solving games and would like to get yourself involved in a decent story, this is a gem for you.

It might be a bit silly to say so, since I am from England, and I’m often supportive to the video-game industry from homeland, because we want to see more people get involved in it and make the industry has a better future tomorrow. But even without this factor, I would still write this review simply for its magnificent content. 

I’ve completed this game twice so far, the 1st time for my own play-through, and the 2nd time to show it to a friend. While showing to him, I couldn’t finish the 1st chapter before he stopped me from playing and purchased it to enjoy it himself.

Also from the high percentage of the positive feedbacks you can also tell I am not lying.

Scarlet's Score: 8.5/10

17637888.review:
Contradiction: Spot the Liar is a love letter to Agatha Christie and other murder mysteries of its genre. Everything is saturated with style and charm, including the main character. Your job is to guide our detective as he interviews and gathers clues in this seemingly dickensian like village. Of course not everything is at it appears and it up to you to unravel the mystery. Being a FMV(Full-Motion Video) game, Contradiction is completely based off its acting. Which it does exquisitely. The mechanics of the game while very simple, are complimented by the clever writing and eerie atmosphere. As hours go by in the game, more of the story is slowly revealed to you and the plot thickens. The contradiction system in the game has you matching statements and clues, trying to catch suspects in a lie. This isn't easy in the least but there are helpful hint systems in place if you do get stuck. While many will compare this with Her Story, this is a completely different experience. You are far more involved and progress is completely based on your keen senses of listening and deduction. There are times that Contradiction can feel a little cheesy but that all plays into the genre of the game. So get your thinking cap on, its time to solve some delicious murder!!

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/YLxD7ZGppJM
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

17637444.review: A very charming detective game. It's like playing a BBC murder mystery.

17633556.review:
FMV games are an unknown territory for me as a genre, especially since my younger self did not have access to them during the phase of its fad-like popularity. Looking at previous titles however makes me wonder if it truly was ever popular, as many FMV titles seemed to be all about the technology and visual wow factor rather than the gameplay or story-telling aspects. Contradiction must be familiar with this trend as it shirks the all style, shallow substance method, and instead brings an engaging story with a varied, likable cast who’s performances only add to the experience as you progress along the game... Even if most of said performances are outright the most bizarre, silly examples of acting I’ve ever seen. (It’s a good thing, really.)

Contradiction is set entirely within and around the limits of the sleepy British village of Edenton, and has the player character, Inspector Jenks, investigating the apparent suicide of a resident. There’s a pseudo time limit to complete the case, but each passing hour acts like a chapter, rather than pressure to hustle you along. Being an adventure game, hopping around the different areas will reveal potential clues to pick up, events revealing new characters, or more information on your current suspects once your leads have run dry. Jenks’ journal at first has only a handful of clues and subjects, but getting your gumshoe on will eventually have a plethora of possible lines of questioning (and a few red herrings, to be expected) to use on people of interest. Most of your time will be spent interviewing the various Edenton residents with said collection of clues, and unlocking more subjects in the process. This is where Contradiction’s gameplay lies, as you might expect in a game based on police investigation, people end up lying or trying to mislead you, and Jenks must use their testimony against them by taking two statements to reveal a titular contradiction, and break the witness’ lie to get the truth - Or more fibbing. Rinse and repeat until the game is over. While this sounds like it would become mighty old in a mighty hurry, the actors and their performances is what keeps the game engaging right to the closing credits... Not because of sheer brilliance that should be reserved for Broadway, but because of the sheer campy, humorous way in which things take place.

I wonder if the director is secretly a mad genius, since the acting can get so silly at times yet remain so believable that it’s both comical and interesting how characters won’t react or call out each others quirks, save for moments of intense emotion. I will confess my expertise on live action acting is severely lacking in order for me to truly explain performances, but look up some videos and you’ll begin to understand what I mean. The way Simon (Magnus Sinding) seems to act sketchy and suspicious after nearly every question he answers, the way Rebecca (Melanie Gray) hardly budges in her seat and speaks like she is in ownership of an evil spy empire, how Ryan (John Guilor) cannot help but speak and gesture like he is always trying to impress, and his posh-ness makes it impossible not to giggle at him constantly. And of course there’s Jenks (Rupert Booth), who’s wild eyes, head bobs and expressions make me wonder if it’s a police tactic to seem a bit weird in order to lower the guard of witnesses. I am certain that if the actors played the script straight and with the severity that the story had, this would be a much tamer if not duller experience. The campy acting may not be for everyone, but I can only applaud the actors and director for allowing the goofiness to run rampant and free, entertaining the player more for it.

After the praises I have previously sung, my complaints against Contradiction are quite minor, and are generally tied to the menus. At some point, you will end up with a lot of clues and subjects to sift through, which can be an annoyance when looking for two specific statements to use as contradiction fodder. You’re given a master list of testimony to thumb through everyone’s answers regarding a certain clue which is nice and all, but the game follows a very tight script on what is and is not a contradiction, and the script doesn’t budge for lesser lies. Things that should feel contradictory are ignored, as the game only wants the big, apparent lies to be revealed to keep the intrigue and story going. Still, it’s quite satisfying when Jenks finds a contradiction, as he goes from generally friendly and approachable to snarky, sarcastic and borderline demeaning once he catches someone in a lie, and watching the witness squirm is only icing on that cake.

I like Contradiction a whole bunch. The acting is wonderfully nutty, the story is dark yet becomes very engaging as more is revealed regarding the secrets of Atlas and the skeletons in everyone’s closets, and one can see their way to the end in about five or six hours. I can give it a hearty recommendation for anyone looking for a story driven adventure game, but those who want a seriously written script may want to look elsewhere.

17529109.review:
This will be my first review and, although I don't feel I have anything to contribute that hasn't already been contributed, after finishing it I felt compelled, for the first time, to add to the list of positive reviews for this game, if nothing else at least to support the effort that was put into it.

Really the best I can offer is to regurgitate what has already been said: the acting is wonderful, in a slightly tongue-in-cheek, campy but very self-aware way.  It made me chuckle out loud more than a few times, particularly the protagonist.  However, this is certainly not to say it's goofy or a parody of mysteries.  Think not so much Inspector Clouseau or Ace Ventura so much as maybe Dr. House.  Having said that, don't confuse this for a spoof of any sort.  There were actually a good number of tense moments, and, whether by the drama, mystery or comedy of it, I was enraptured by the game throughout my entire experience.

The choices feel somewhat constricting at first, as your map, cast of characters and actions are quite small, but as the game progresses the first two grow somewhat and the latter exponentially.  As stated before, there were many a time during the course of the game that I sat there, befuddled, trying to put the pieces together and not realizing I had spent half an hour or so doing so.  I absolutely loved the ability of the game to keep the pacing nice and light but also engaging and entertaining.

I'll sum this up by saying this was an immensely pleasant surprise, especially considering it was done off of Kickstarter (which seems to have a reputation for producing big expectations and equally big let downs).  I actually went into this experience expecting to be let down (disclaimer: hadn't been a big fan of FMV games) and pretty much having my socks knocked off.

If I had to criticize about this game at all, it would be the following:

-A few times I wasn't able to actually select two options to see if they were contradictions.  I would have to exit the screen and re-enter it to do so.  This, to my awareness, is the only bug in the game.
-It would have been fun to be able to interact with the environment in a little more detail, rather than just having a magnifying glass pop up that leads me directly to an important clue.
-It may have been more enjoyable to be able to choose some of the questions while interrogating suspects, at least some of the follow up questions.

Please bear in mind absolutely none of those "faults" detracted from the game at all.  There was absolutely no point where I felt disappointed nor did any of them detract from the immersion.  This is to say, even if the next game contained the very same flaws, I would still play it without complaint.

In terms of value, I would say if you are either a fan of FMV style games, murder mysteries, or (even better), both, you absolutely must play this game.  It is worth every penny of it's $10 price tag, possibly more.

If not, I would still recommend it, but may be better to wait until its on sale.

For those who have played it and loved the experience, please comment.  We need to support more efforts like this, and I am frankly on pins and needles waiting for the sequel (which I will absolutely pay full price for, no hesitation).

17475948.review:
I really enjoyed this game, although it doesn't have all that much to it in theory, it was definitely gripping, and for the most part well pitched in terms of difficulty. I think the biggest weaknesses were the sheer amount of back and forth; a staple of the genre, but seemed odd here, that people were happy for you to keep dropping in at any time of the evening and act like nothing had happened? I understand this will be required to a certain extent, and appreciate that the developers didn't have much to play with, but it just seemed a little odd.

The other is that sometimes the summaries of statements made by the characters seemed too similar. There was one particular point where I ended up using the "cheat" function because I was stumped, only to discover I had basically found the contradiction, I just hadn't combined the particular statements the game had expected. Though for the most part this wasn't a problem, and the amount of red herring statements was great actually, did give it some depth and difficulty, as well as fleshing out the characters.

The characters were pretty decent too, and the acting was actually really good, very cleverly done that it was hammed up the TINIEST bit, which lulled you into the tone and made it all much easier to take in. 

The other main problem I had is that the final deduction you have to make to complete the game is reliant on you picking up on something you see only once (as far as I could tell) right at the beginning of the game. Now, to me, it stuck out like a sore thumb and I wanted to be able to follow up on it far sooner, so it was frustrating that it ended up being brought into it as the solution right at the end... however, if I hadn't noticed it then I would have been tearing my hair out trying to figure out what the game was getting at. This wouldn't have been so much of a problem if it was a mid-game puzzle, but as it was literally the final player action it left me underwhelmed.

The ending itself I liked though, although it left a lot of loose ends (which is explicitly acknowledged in the dialogue) it seemed believeable enough in the context of everything else, and the detective/police procedural TV shows that the game is obviously inspired by.

I also loved the music and actually found the keyboard control scheme pretty good, once I'd gotten used to its quirks. The cinematography was great too, lovely colour grading on the day-for-night footage. 

I do hope that the game is a success and continues to get great reviews, because I would love to see what the team behind this could do with a bit more scope and budget. Something with more varied locations, and perhaps even multiple cases? Maybe this isn't viable, but I would be more than happy to pay £30 for a sequel with 20-30hrs content spread over four cases with subtle links, like the Ace Attourney games. But even if that doesn't come to fruition, I immensely enjoyed my 6 hours with Contradiction, great value at £6.99 for the effort that's gone into the production.

17416504.review:
I tend to dislike most FMV games. I loved this one.

This is a nice FMV detective game with lots of charismatic characters and surprisingly engaging story. It's just enough hammy to be unforgettably charming and just enough serious to be actually interesting. It has quite simple and no fail-state design with very stylish presentation and not too much unskippable repeating imagery and very simplistic, but interesting gameplay focused on interviewing people and crossreferencing the things you are being told. There's just enough interaction and thinking to spot the contradictions and just enough entertaining watching parts with dialogue for the game to not get boring in the 3-5 hours it lasts.

It does have some issues - the controls for the game are surprisingly clunky and do not use mouse at all for one. A rather strange choice for the clearly point-and-click-perfect game, although, this may have been intended for touch controls, hence the werid limitation. The story focuses a lot on the bigger plot for most of the game, which doesn't actually get resolved by the end, with only the initial whodunit potential murder being solved, while everything else left for the openly hinted potential continuation. And the game doesn't really have enough contradiction gameplay happening overall - there's tons of facts you can gather, but most reveals happen in quick succession due to one-two new items or encounters, and then don't happen at all no matter how much you talk to different characters about different things. Game being linear and having encounters you need to get around town to progress the story (most of which just happen, you don't expect them to) also doesn't help the situation. All these things are not deal breakers, but certainly aren't good.

Overall, this game was very fun to play and I'd love to see more of these characters.

17408799.review: Absolutely fantastic game. I think this is my first review on Steam, but I couldn't let this pass without helping to spread the word. This is a FMV game that reminds a lot of Phoenix Wright in some ways. You find evidence, question suspects or witnesses and then point out their contradictions to reveal more of the story. It took me about eight hours to complete and for $10 this is an absolute steal. Charming performances and an engaging plot keep you glued to your seat to the very end. I hope to see more Inspector Jenks in the future!

Despite its shoestring budget and small-town setting, Contradiction might actually be the most authentic detective game I've ever played. Ask the right questions, listen carefully to the answers and, as the title suggests, spot the liars.

If you can get past a less-than-elegant UI, there's an engrossing detective mystery to be found here. I didn't back this game on Kickstarter, but I'll certainly be backing a sequel (if we're lucky enough to get one!)

But what got me was using the video to create the 'still' directional screens to show you where to go - added a terrific environmental quality when they could have just used a still image.
