17342355.review:
The original makers of FMV games had valid excuses for releasing terrible products--the video game industry was small, the medium was in its infancy, and the technology of the time severely limited what was possible.

Contradiction makes the mistake of thinking that being terrible was not a result of the circumstances early FMV games were developed in, but an integral part of the genre. It seems to have been developed by somebody with only the most basic understanding of what video games even are, and no understanding of what makes them fun. The technical and design issues alone are numerous and baffling. Sometimes you can use the mouse, sometimes only the keyboard. Controls can only be configured by going to the menu and setting them all up in a row, and can't be set individually. There are inscrutable menu options you can't use. When navigating around town, forward becomes back and back becomes forward, based on whatever room you were in previously, but with no change in perspective to indicate it. A single button is shared for both "inventory" and "use". 

Hear me out: I'm not complaining because I went to a silent movie and there was no sound. I'm complaining because I went to a silent movie and the director thought it would only be an authentic 1920s experience if he also gave me polio.

17290231.review:
TL;DR: Buy this excellent detective adventure game so that we can have more!

Full motion video (FMV) game, huh? That's a blast from the past, this one funded by a kickstarter of mere 4000 £. There were many FMV games in the 90s though I only remember playing Terra Nova and Command & Conquer franchise with their acted interludes. One problem with them was the huge space and computing power requirements of video and it still looked pretty bad. Large-volume hard discs, speedy downloads and technological advances in computation make those problems go away and you are left with problems of writing, acting, shooting and editing. This being a game, the gameplay is also important. So how're those things holding up for Contradiction?

In the game you are a police investigator. Remember all those detective stories they show reruns of in the afternoons? This is like a single, long episode of that, with [i]you[/i] doing the actual deducing and detective work. Well, you embodying the detective of stereotypical looks, Mr. Jenks. He has been sent to check this little Twin Peaksy town somewhere in England (I presume), because someone there has died under suspicious circumstances involving a suicide claim, a creepy business school and alcohol.

Our protagonist seems to be a tad old-fashioned, as he goes around asking questions and generally snooping around the town. The main game mechanism is to review the statements people give you and then call any contradictions you might find in their answers. Now let me say it: this is the coolest aspect of the game! We had tremendous amount of fun and frustration alike trying to spot the one or two contradictions in the rather large amount of statements. Some of them are dead obvious, while others are sneaky as a still animal in a forest: hiding in plain sight but hidden by the vegetation. Sometimes you even have to listen their statements again to get that piece of missing information.

Speaking of forest again, this broke us to a small inside joke that I'll give out here as a tip: if you don't know what to do, go to the woods because random shit happens in the woods and sometimes that's the only way to go forward. This is because to ask questions you got to have questions and you could find additional evidence in all kinds of places. In addition to exploration the progression sometimes involves minor puzzle solving like using items in correct places but nothing fancier than that.

Story is all paced through one busy evening, during which you meet the quirky locals: various students, misfits and businessmen and -women. Everyone seems to know more than they are letting out. Acting is nice despite the actors being fairly unknown. Editing has been done very well, movement between places by video feels fluid and quite natural. I am not totally sure if Mr. Jenks' actor was taking it seriously though as his actor could be described as rather "expressive": he was making surprised and curious faces all the time, which was frankly pretty hilarious and actually fits the quirky detective-type.

There are four minor flaws I must bring to attention. The most serious one is perhaps the user interface. To be honest it isn't that bad once you get used to it, but when you start playing it can be confusing. Walking around map and asking questions is easy enough (just using arrow keys and Enter), but there are three special buttons that are at default mapped to 'A' (menu key), 'D' and 'S'. Especially the menu key is weird, as 'Esc' would be the logical one. For all I know these issues could and hopefully will be addressed in the future. For example, when we played it there was no mouse support yet but it's being implemented bit by bit as you read. 

The other minor qualm is the lack of Steam Overlay (so you can't take screenshots in the regular Steam-fashion). Also for some reason the unlocked contradictions and event videos have been hidden in the main menu instead of, for example, a log book or similar that would feel more logical or authentic. Finally, in the outdoor areas there were occasional green screens, a flicker of sorts, like the video was "cut" and suddenly restarted. This was a minor annoyance but might be an issue of editing or perhaps my rig.

Now, an observant reader will have noticed me referring to "us" multiple times. We would play this with my wife every evening for several days and she would anxiously wait for me from work so that we could continue the game, unusual as normally she'd just play or watch whatever: I deduce she really enjoyed it. It took us 18 hours to finish the whole story (which is actually just a few hours long) and we enjoyed it thoroughly, only having a couple of frustrating moments when we were stuck at some part of the story.

Contradiction was a very nice experience and it stayed exciting throughout. We bought it at full price of 10 euros, which in my opinion was cheap for this game: I would have happily paid at least 15 or 20 euros for this. Here's for hoping it succeeds and gets a sequel!

17238487.review:
Excellent murder mystery game, which would be amazing even without the FMV. The contradiction system works superbly 90% of the time, the characters are deep and varied, and new locations open up all the time.

Some will say that the game doesn't hand out enough clues. I'll say this is patently false. On top of the hint system, players can call the Chief, and even get flat-out cheats to help them along when needed. The ever-increasing amount of conversation points also means that the amount of answers to verify grows as well -- but that just means you can't be expected to simply throw statements at one another hoping they will stick. One has to fully remember everything to get around in Contradiction.

The most disheartening thing I have seen regarding this game is the Rock Paper Shotgun review for it. By saying the game should directly tell the players when new events are available at locations, when contradictions are left to be made -- and with whom -- the author only put his inability to appreciate freedom on display. TellTale's The Walking Dead this is not. This is very much a game, and not an interactive story. The only valid point that review brought forth is the game's technical shortcomings; it is true that the lack of resolution options is jarring, and the general UI and presentation is odd at first. But not only is it absolutely not a deal breaker, I feel like it kind of gave the game a very distinct, simple vibe. It was never distracting or frustrating. It took me a couple of minutes to get used to it, then I never gave it a thought again.

Really, for all fans of classic, hardcore adventure games, looking for a modern take (in terms of presentation) on the classic genre, Contradiction is a gift from the Gods. Do not hesitate. Do not watch trailers. Do not try to know anything about it, except that it is a great, great game. Just dive in, headfirst. You'll thank me!

17238036.review:
I can easily say this is the most immersive, rewarding, and satisfying game I've played in recent memory. This is what the FMV games of old always aspired to be but could never actually quite achieve.

Contradiction is a fittingly theatrical experience that plays just like an interactive movie. You play as Inspector Jenks, who is merely a polite and humble police officer going about his job. Little else is shown about Jenks, except for occasionally emphasized spades of moral fortitude and righteous indignation, and helpful hints and speculations in the form of brief inner monologues. His more hollowed out vagueness serves as an appropriate vessel for the player to experience the story in, where the progress of the plot hinges on their every move, while managing to avoid coming off cliche or one-dimensional.

Jenks is investigating the death of a young woman named Kate Vine who was found in a lake in the woods, and has less than an entire day to solve the mystery (fortunately, the game does not progress in real time or possess a time limit, or else this would be much more difficult). His suspects and witnesses include a well-rounded cast of characters each with their own quirks and individuality, each of whom are equally amusing and interesting. 

Contradiction is a thoroughly cerebral experience, as it requires you to constantly remain engaged in every detail you come across, similar to how classic Sierra Adventure games encourage players to explore every proverbial nook and cranny. The game doesn't hold your hand when you feel sure enough to try to figure things out on your own, but will give you just enough information to get back on track when you're stuck. You progress by investigating numerous places and seeking out evidence, as well as interviewing suspects and witnesses and checking the evidence against them, as well as their responses to that evidence, and whether or not their stories add up.

Using only filmed footage and photographs in place of computer generated graphics, it works remarkably well with presenting a gorgeous environment and sets, along with aesthetically pleasant costume designs. Even more impressively so given that it was all shot on a low budget, funnily enough reminiscent of the kind of thing you might see on BBC.

The acting may not exactly be Oscar worthy, but is still quite well done. Overall, the game's cinematic presence is easy to appreciate. With just the right balance between a plucky Sherlock mystery and a seedy film noir, it establishes a darkly playful tone, feeling right at home with themes such as the occult and Satanic forces, along with a balanced critique of Objectivism not unlike the first BioShock (major plot points even revolve around an institution called Atlas being run by a father and son team named the Rands; at one point, the phrase "greed is good" is quoted).

For $9.99, Contradiction is worth the price. The overall length of the game itself may not be everyone's cup of tea, but I believe that it ultimately depends on how quickly the player can figure out what's going on and whether or not they ever want to rely on any hints or cheats. I could also see replay value in trying it again after some time, like The Wolf Among Us, and it would be a delight to share with friends and watching them try to unravel the mystery. The game even ends with the tentative teasing of a sequel, left on such an open ended note that it just begs to be made. This would be an absolute steal on sale, and a solid investment at full price. I thoroughly enjoyed myself, and I think anyone who likes a good story and a chance to challenge their minds could appreciate it similarly.

17232657.review:
THE GOOD:
-This is a very clever story that manages to introduce a lot of plot points and red herrings that keep you guessing. 
-The characters are authentic and fully developed. The relationships between the characters are intricate and well developed
-The acting and video is very good.  
-The story and characters are sophisticated enough that it allows for future games
-There are a lot of non verbal clues - everything in the visual background of the story is relevant - excellent attention to detail


THE BAD
-The user interface is terrible.  It works just enough that you can play the game
-You can only ask characters about their own statements - you can't ask them about the statements of others. This means that a lot of obvious clues could not be acted upon - simply because they had been said by another character in the game
- there is a glaring visual clue toward the beginning of the game that hints at who the killer could be.  It was frustrating to see this clue and not be able to act upon it.

PLAY THE GAME?
My assessment is that enduring the poor interface, and lack of sophistication in gameplay options, is worth it to experience this story and solve the puzzle.

FOR THE FUTURE
It would be fantastic if the game creators could improve their user interface, and also open up the ways that players can interact with the game. Also, whilst there were a respectable number of scene locations, it would be great if there were more.

I look forward to playing future games in this franchise.

17215769.review:
And the award for "All The Heart In The World" goes to, Contradiction - Spot The Liar! 

If trying to solve a murder in a quaint little village where things are probably just a little more than they seem and everybody's probably got their own little secrets seems like the kinda trip for you, then by all means, grab this game.  The characters have charm for days, and despite the game's limitations, it takes a very simple concept and a decently plotted murder mystery and makes it something special and most importantly entertaining.  

The main mechanics of the game are investigating the area and interviewing each character multiple times and using their statements on the evidence provided to point out contradictions in their stories. That's really it. It's a more streamlined Phoenix Wright and the contradictions are clever enough to make you have to stop, think, and re-examine each statement to find inconsistencies. If you can't figure them out, there's no real penalty or fail state, so there's no real big deal if you end up stumped, and the game has a pretty good hint system to help out.  

Unless it just isn't your thing, it's really hard to not admire this silly little "from out of nowhere" game.  The intrigue of the murder mystery and the acting sell it and its solid set of investigative mechanics make it a solid package that overcomes its minor production flaws.

17212878.review:
Fantastic little mystery title. You play as Jenks, a detective sent to a small town to investigate the death of a young student in a small town that's a little strange. The game has clear influences like Twin Peaks and the Wicker Man, but manages to carve out its' own identity. You'll be going around largely to talk to the cast of about 7ish people, and finding their stories when it comes to pieces of evidence and various other things. There are some light "adventure game" puzzles to solve with inventory items but they are fairly simplistic. The meat of the game lies in the dialogue system, as you hear their tales and catch them in their lies, spotting the titular contradicitons. It is somehwat like Phoenix Wright in that way.

Jenks is a very fun lead character. At first he seemed a bit over the top but I soon got into his zest for needling suspects for answers. For the most part the cast does well outside him too, particularly the imposing actor playing Paul. My only complaint would be the PC controls just aren't that great. The default keybinds are a little goofy and while you can rebind them, for some reason the game would forget them everytime I closed the game. You can't use the mouse for much more than clicking locations too.

Easily worth the asking price, and would love a sequel.

This is obviously not some AAA game, so people with high-brow expectations should avoid this game. Those who like to have a fun time and enjoy these type of games should dive in and give this game a shot. Took about six hours for me to complete.

17185041.review:
This Game is completely great, I fully support the comeback of FMV games. 

The HD video + pro actors/directors/production make this a joy to play.  That is despite the fact that the game technology feels like it was developed entirely in "Free DVD Maker"

All the great FMV games of the past are memorable because of fun performances and interesting characters.  Some of the genre's best were Spycraft, Titanic, the Elk Moon Murder, and Gabriel Knight II.   The mechanics of those games were complex compared to this game.  They all had varying puzzles relating to dialogue, inventory, and environment.   But the fun thing about them was the same as Contradiction- for each little puzzle you solve, you are rewarded with an entertaining new video segment.

Contradiction's simplistic single mechanic (give interviews to find new information, progress by discovering contradictions), puts less of a barrier between you and the next video reward.  It does a great job of keeping the plot moving. 

The director of the game has you watching the faces of each character intently, with close ups on the eyes, and body language cues.  It draws you in.

17183477.review:
9.5/10; An incredible journey, TOP notch whodunnit/adventure thriller game.

I finished it in 2 days, with non-stop 3.5 hour playfests.

INCREDIBLE work. The acting is SUPERB, rivalling a solid BBC whodunnit. Rupert Booth as Jenks was excellent, oozing charm and wit. (And THE CAMP. Oh my lord, the CAMP. When Jenks turns to each suspect in turn and flourishes his hand into the "devil sign" asking people if they know "WHAT THIS MEANS", in ever more over the top ways, I near fell over laughing.) Paul Darrow as Paul was incredible as well, with his tongue flicks and delightful inflections at the end of select, tasty words. The rest of the cast was excellent as well! (Shout out to James, that ol' rogue. What a character he was.)

The writing was top notch, with believable dialogue and realistic fast paced storyline. Solid mystery whodunnit with multiple believable suspects, and an overarching mysterious setting.

The actual main/inventive game mechanic of "Contradiction", of catching the statements that don't line up - to piece together the mystery, is unlike anything I've played in this genre. Quite fun, challenging, and enjoyable. Also, very much enjoyed how the map/world unfolded as you progressed through the game, each area unlocking as the night progressed.

The score was tremendous, weaving in an out mid-FMV scene, and as the mystery started unfolding. VERY seamless.

The only 2 minor gripes I had were, A) the control scheme at default on PC was a bit wonky, compared to the standard for this genre, but the keys are all customizable, so it's fine. Wish there was some actual use for the mouse as input though. Would have loved a bit more challenge looking for the clues.
B) At times the audio seemed inconsistent and muffled. Different interrogation locations, had a different tone to their recording. After a little while I got used to it, but for a game with as EXTREMELY high production values as this, I just felt it to be a bit jarring.

Still, if you have ever felt the joy or love of a good whodunnit, in ANY form, be it BBC dramas or video games like the Sherlock Holmes or "The Raven" series, you will CERTAINLY enjoy this. You will be wrapped up in the story, obsessively trying to find the culprit and come to the ending, and enjoying it all the while.

Also, check this link (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OzQFPkAerfw) out at 7 minute mark: One of the actors, Paul Guilor (played Ryan) explained that he thought it was important to ham the acting up and advised Rupert Booth (Jenks) to do so as well. Otherwise the dialogue is just "functional" technical stuff in many places. SO happy they went that direction.

A very quirky, interesting, and over all else charming modern FMV adventure game. The cast are great and their performances really make the experience fun, and they're well aware of what they're up to and are part of the jokey nature of it all.

You've got an evening to solve the mystery of a girl's apparent suicide in a small English village. You do this by wandering around talking to the various characters available to you, and picking the contradictions in their accounts, while gathering evidence where you can. It's a streamlined process, and the fact that the video is such high quality makes it all very slick - once you get used to the controls.

The couple downsides are the slightly inconsistent audio quality, and the slight drop off of the story towards the conclusion - but these are small quibbles.

Overall a very enjoyable, fun, warm adventure, and I hope to see a sequel with the same actors, even if playing different characters.

17151521.review: Very enjoyable murder mystery adventure game with high production value, good cinematography, a strong story, and genuinely excellent acting.  The game has a novel problem solving engine which involves identifying contradictions in individual character statements.  The interface was a bit unusual, and took some time to get used to, but was also weirdly satisfying once the routines sunk in.  The story is compelling and the characters have the right balance of richness dimensionality for a story of this kind.  A couple complaints would be that the storyline itself has some small internal inconsistencies, which are not identified as contradictions within the gameplay.  This proved to be mildly frustrating at times.  The other complaint would be that the process of finding contradictions only took place character-by-character and not across characters (unless it happened to come up in that context).  This made the game more manageable as a puzzler, and still satisfying.  But there were times when characters would say contradictory things with respect to each other, and there was no way to cross examine suspects and access those kind of conversation threads.  Nevertheless, I strongly recommend it for those who enjoy neat, self-contained, story-driven mystery adventure games.

17149695.review:
I'm a big fan of point and click adventure games, and I equally enjoy reading cozy murder mystery books. That said, I jumped at the chance to play through Contradiction, an adventure game with a bit of a twist on the traditional formula -- there's actually no "point and click". The character you control, Inspector Jenks, is controlled entirely via a few keyboard keys. Furthermore, the vast majority of puzzles are dialogue-driven (spotting contradictions in the statements of Edenton village's residents). There are few inventory-based puzzles, but the use of inventory items is very simplified, so just a heads up in case you were expecting more traditional adventure game elements such as combining inventory items.

This different take on adventure gaming is refreshing, and I found myself growing to like Jenks' character quite a lot, as he charmingly asks questions regarding the suspicious death of a university student, Kate Vine. Afternoon turns to evening as Jenks' investigation progresses, and I loved how the atmosphere got a bit more suspenseful as time went on. It's the "little things" that demonstrated so much attention to detail that impressed me -- for example, as Jenks walks past a bush, its leaves rustle in the wind, showing us that as night approaches, things are getting a bit more eery. The camera-work in this adventure game is excellent, as is the music soundtrack. The acting overall isn't bad, and I was very happy with the game interface. I particularly enjoyed being able to fast-travel to hotspots within the village via the map (the "d" key by default), as well as the handy built-in hint system, accessed via "a". The hint system gives the player a gentle nudge in the right direction without any spoilers, and it was a very cool thing to see.

While I could go on about the many things I enjoyed about Contradiction, I want to stress that I don't think the actual storyline was of a very high standard. I've written a bit more about my opinion on the storyline at the end of the review, underneath a MINOR SPOILER warning.

[b]TLDR; I recommend this game, but with reservations.[/b] The actual dialogue-driven puzzle-solving is excellent, as is the general atmosphere (to include cinematography and music). However, I think the storyline gets more and more ridiculous as Jenks' evening progresses, to the point where there really is no cohesion in storytelling (in my opinion).

[b]MINOR SPOILER REGARDING THE INVESTIGATION SUBJECT MATTER BELOW:[/b]

As Jenks' delves deeper into Kate's mysterious death, he stumbles upon the subject matters of hallucinogens, paganism, business ethics, mind control, AND satanism. I felt like in the later stages of the game, writer Tim Follin just threw in whatever seemed "taboo" into the plot, to the point where the story becomes a bit of a disjointed mess.

17146518.review: A delightful throwback to FMV adventure games, with some trademark british camp. Thoroughly enjoyable and lighthearted despite the serious topic of, you know, murder. Other than some bad interface and control issues I have no problem recommending this game, as long as you know what you're getting in to.

17141754.review:
"If I did this, would it mean anything to you? \m/̷  "
Hopefully, it means a sequel!

Maybe murder mysteries with some dark twists are a guilty pleasure of mine, but this will probably be my favorite game under $10 for 2015.  I do enjoy adventure games and the nostalgia of FMV, so I'm a little biased.  I thought the dialogue got the job done, and the acting (ranging from campy to outright ridiculous \m/̷  ) certainly sold it to me.  There isn't much in terms of gameplay beyond cycling through dialogue regarding evidence and notes you happen upon in your adventuring while weighing potential contradictions, but I think the minimalism of this approach works in the game's favor.  It's refreshing to enjoy an FMV game that isn't too cumbersome about gameplay for this price! While I was a little mixed about the ending, I'm okay with it being an issue of time and budget on the developer's end, I still think the overall package presented of Contradiction is awesome and I'm definitely left wanting for a sequel.  

By the way (this is a bit of a tangent), if people liked the darker undertones of this and was looking for something even more graphic and unsettling while being open to the prospect of digging up a visual novel, Kara no Shoujo is probably my all time favorite among murder mysteries across gaming media.  Higurashi is also up there if you're big on a heavy read, and that is on Steam! I was sort of expecting some super dark twists out of Contradiction considering the age gate, but it doesn't quite get there. For those familiar with FMV games of yore, it is certainly no Phantasmagoria in graphic content; Contradiction is quite tame! Still, it did do an excellent job in satiating my FMV murder mystery hunger.  Speaking of FMV murder myster hunger with respect to Contradiction, however, I'll certainly be hungry for a sequel! 

\m/̷

17103906.review:
I really enjoyed this game, it's maybe my favourite adventure game since Monkey Island 2. It has an interesting mechanic, a great story, great characters and manages to pull off FMV fluidly, which is something I've never seen happen.

Most FMV games have that moment wherein the animation cycles, this might have that but it would be in environments as opposed to a person gesturing, it bypasses this by only showing you FMV when you ask a question.

So all in all this is the most natural FMV game I've ever played, and one of the least frustrating adventure games, due to it's non reliance on deadends.

17097469.review:
Contradiction is a live-action FMV Murder-Mystery game. You play as Inspector Jenks, a British Policeman who goes to investigate the death of a girl named Katie in a small outskirt village. Her death was investigated and called a suicide, but there was morphine in her blood at her time of death and her driver's license was pinned to a tree in the forest away from the scene of her death, leading our character to suspect there's more involved in this case which he takes personal interest in. His work quickly leads him to find there is indeed something going on in this town...

So, like many FMV games, this game does have an edge of B-charm, laugh-out-loud moments, a lot of this comes from some of the acting and facial expressions the actors can have in specific scenes. But that's not to say this is a so-bad-it's-good type of game, in fact the opposite, it actually got kind of gripping as it developed and in contrast some moments were acted out rather well. It's got a multi-layered mystery that gets deeper and deeper as the night goes on, and is actually surprisingly interesting.

Gameplay is rather basic. You walk around a town and look for clues hidden about, and people to interview. When you interview people, you take out clues, both physical and conversation topics you earn from talking to others, and watch FMV scenes as they interact. When the scene is done, your character has taken 'notes' to the key points of the discussion. You then can take the key notes from that discussion, and every other discussion you've had with that character, and try and spot any 'contradictions' the character may have said. If you find a contradicting point, it triggers another scene, which either will lead to you having to do further digging or creates a new conversation topic you can raise up to others. Other conversation topics can be found around as objects or weird things in town that strike up a good conversation topic, and some rare objects found can be used to explore deeper certain areas in the village.

The game has a solid cast of something like 10 main characters, and is backed by some rather good-quality video for the backgrounds, FMV scenes, etc., and an actually pretty wonderful soundtrack. Music added a lot to specific scenes, and there were a few moments without music where you can hear the atmosphere sounds and drone noises that made some scenes legitimately creepy. On that, while the game is down-toned most of the time, there's the odd scene that plays every once in a while that can catch you off-guard, something that's just kind of creepy, or unexpected, shocking in some cases. I won't spoil anything with that, but the game has a few sudden scenes that happen as you investigate that might catch you off-guard.

It's got a few minor flaws. There are a few times where something the character said was obviously a lie or a contradiction to something you already knew, but because you didn't have the 'conversation topic' piece, you couldn't accuse them of this. A few contradictions (or what seem like contradictions) the game doesn't think quite are. Also the game, while it does have an ending and wraps up the case, proposes more questions, especially near the very end, and has several loose plot threads. They seem to be a sequel hook, and past the game credits a message pops-up confirms this saying  "Thanks For Playing!", they'd like to make a sequel, but the only way to do so is for the game to do well-enough, and they appreciate reviews/videos/the like on their project.

So that raises the question, "Is it worth it?" To which I say, for me, absolutely so. I liked it, I enjoyed it. There were a few moments I got stumped on what to do (get too stuck and you can use a cheat system to tell you what to do next, a feature I never used, or call your chief for a vague general hint) and as you collect more clues you're given maybe too many conversation points to look over, but I actually ended up enjoying the mystery that unveiled in the game, the loose plot threads interest me to see continued, and the story had some fun twists and turns, was sometimes unintentionally amusing, but other times more consciously so, and was gripping at times. Worth it if an FMV Murder-Mystery sounds up your alley, and want something between hammy entertainment and something more gripping and interesting. Hope to see this world revisited in the future.

17093465.review:
Contradiction is an FMV detective game built around the idea of calling people out on contradictory statements.  You can only ever catch them on things they have said, not with evidence or statements from others.

The story revolves around a bit of a jolly weirdo detective who has been sent in to do a last minute re-investigation of a case that had been ruled a suicide.  He only has until the end of the day to work out what really happened, so he's going to be bothering the people of this small town continuously for the rest of the night.

As for the actual game:
The gameplay is about 80% talking, 10% "finding" items, and 10% running into people in the woods.  The acting ranges from "pretty hammy" to "extremely hammy", but I would rate that as a good thing, personally.  The interface isn't the best and the controls take some getting used to (don't even try to set up a controller on PC, it's essentially keyboard-only at the time of this writing), but once you stop hitting Escape hoping for a menu, it all works out.

The game is about 7-8 hours long, depending on how much time you spend thinking about what people have said, but does have a built-in hint and cheat system if you just want to move on.  I genuinely enjoyed it and hope they can find a way to making a sequel.  FMV may have made a massive mess of things in the 90s, but games like these can still have merit.

Well done; clear must have if you are into this genre!

17069515.review:
Pretty solid FMV game.  You basically interview a few different people about a murder.  As you interview them you discover more information.  The goal of the game is to catch people in lies, which then advances the game's progress and reveals more clues.  Eventually you solve the case.  

Early on the game is a bit of a slow burner and finding contradictions can be a bit tedious.  But as more characters and information becomes available, the game hits it's stride.  

Unfortunately there are are few instances where you will spot an obvious contradiction but the game won't recognize it.  Additionally, you'll become stuck at some points because the only way to progress is to go to some secluded spot on the map that you've already visited and would have no reason to visit again.  Fortunately there are hints and even cheats that you can access if you become stuck but this takes away from the immersion.  

The acting is good in most cases, although the main actor Inspector Jenks seems to "over act" much of the time.  For example... he'll be interviewing a witness and pull out a simple driver's license and say, "What do you know about.... THIS!" and hold the driver's license up as if it's a smoking gun of evidence, then the witness will dully say, "Um, I don't know anything about that, why would I?"  So there seems to be a dissonance in the acting and in the overall "mood" of the conversation, although Jenks' wonky personality does lend some color to the conversation as well.  

Anyhow, definitely worth $10 if you enjoy this sort of game and I look forward to the sequel.

17068564.review:
Oh was this an experience to play. It was incredible and I was hooked from the start. Not many games can have me playing for 3 hours running and have me feeling like i've only been playing for about half an hour. 

I feel like there isn't a whole lot I can say about this game without spoiling the story to readers so i'm going to structure this review into a few smaller sections explaining the main premise of the game and linking in my opinions/experience. 

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Contradiction is an FMV style game. I'll admit though I have never before played an FMV game. I wasn't around during the FMV craze that I heard about. So I am not sure what typical gameplay is like in them type of games. But I can explain how gameplay functions in Contradiction. 

You play as a detective. You are investigating the death of a character named Kate Vine. You do this by exploring the small village and finding the clues along the way. All areas that you explore are real areas and nothing is animated. The clues that you find can be used to interogate other characters that you meet accross the way. After asking all the questions to people your goal is to spot who is lieing. You have to put two responses together that disagree with each other and then interogate the person more about this Contradiction.

The game is an investigatory experience. It could be compared to the likes of L.A NOIRE or Sherlock Holmes. But Contradiction decides to strip it's core mechanics down to the basics. They decide to focus on the questioning mechanic. The responses are well thought out and it is very enjoyable to listen to what the characters have to say. You often find yourself linking replies that you got right at the start of the game to ones that were said very late in the game. This means you need to have a good memory or else you could find yourself having to look through pages of replies. Although boy is it satisfying when you finally find a contradiction amongst all of the replies. 

[b]The UI[/b]
Now this game is controlled entirely with the keyboard. The UI is key to making sure the experience is fun. It does this well to an extent. The initial controls the game gives you are horrible. You probably want to rebind them to more appropriate keys as soon as you start playing. Although even navigating the controls screen isn't great. There is no way that I could see to just rebind one single key. You have to go through the entire list and rebind each key instead of just picking one. What I would like to see is the introduction of mouse control, even if it was just across the main menu. It would definitely make the experience a bit better. 

Then you have the map. Initially it is kinda confusing to use. You have 2 choices of how to explore. You can use the map and go to a location straight away using that. But you can only use the keyboard to control it again. Originally I didn't realize you could use the map for movement because I was trying to use the mouse to click on the location. But once you realize that you can then it is a much better form of movement. The second way of navigation is through the arrow keys. You get given a choice of places to go to next from your current location. The problem with this is that the game seems to confusingly decide to change orientation. This means you can't just spam up for example to keep going in that direction. You need to keep an eye on what direction orientation the world has randomly decided to go to. This factor confused me for quite a while and made me go in the wrong direction numerous times. But I did get used to it in the end. 

[b]The Characters[/b]
So each character is played by a real life person including the person you play as. The character development throughout the game is great. Your really do get to know the characters which is key in an investigatory game where your main focus is to spot the criminal. Some of the acting is vastly exagorated, especially Jenks(Your own character). But this is OK I think because it makes sure you don't miss anything but sometimes it is a little bit cringeworthy. 

Some characters in contradiction I felt were amazing actors and definitely gave their characters a personalilty. To name a few the characters of Ryan, James and Simon were played excelently and I want to take the time to praise their actors. Obviously the rest of the other actors were also great as well. But there were some moments were I felt the acting was kinda bad. I have to wonder if it was the bad dialog that the script writers had given them that made these moments cringeworthy. But the majority of the dialog and acting was amazing and I definitely enjoyed it. 

[b]Summary[/b]
So would I recommend Contradiction. YES, YES, Oh boy yes. It was an incredible experience the likes of which I personally havn't seen before. If you love detective games this is definitely the game for you. It sees the detective experience from a different perspective that isn't usually focused on in games. The game ends gearing up for a sequel. But they need peoples support on this game if they are to make another game. I really hope this game succeeds because I would love to play another game of this and experience some more backstory behind the characters. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone. Especially at the very reasonable price point of £6.99. It is a bargain for how much fun you get out of it. It took me 8 hours to complete which is well worth the price.

[b]TheIronicGamers rating system[/b]
[list][*] Don't ever buy this game. 
[*]Maybe consider it on a sale. 
[*]An average game.
[*]A good game that should definitely be considered.
[*][b][u]A must play![/u][/b]
[/list]

Disclaimer: I was given a early press key by the developer to make this review.

17062017.review:
Contradiction is a murder/mystery game in the vein of "The Wicker Man", where you need to find who or what killed Kate Vine, a student enrolled in a mysterious school that may or may not partake in devil worshipping. Detective Jenks needs to interrogate the different people who knew Kate and find out what they know about her death, and call them out on their lies.

I was impressed with the good production values of this FMV game, it reminded me of Gabriel Knight, or the Tex Murphy series. The acting can get a bit hammy, but mostly it's pretty good (Paul Darrow is excellent) and the detective is reminiscent of Hercule Poirot (which is always fun). The one downside is the ending, which I found underwhelming, but otherwise I like the story and the characters.

I recommend it to anyone who likes adventure games in which you have to look for clues and contradictions, this game is quite entertaining (would be nice to have a sequel!)

17043139.review:
Personal Rating: 9/10

Games with FMV (Full Motion Video) are very rare nowadays and had their peak during the 90s when 3D graphics weren't as elaborate as they are today. But they have a certain charm to them, just like watching an 'interactive movie' as such games are often described. You don't get that alot of that feeling with the artifical rendered characters and scenery anymore. With that said, being an adventure-enthusiast, it's quite a treat to see 'Contradiction' has found it's way onto the steam store.

What is the game about? You play as a scotland yard officer investigating a supposed suicide in a small village in england. Many facts of the initial investigation didn't quite fit into the whole picture, that's the reason the player has until 12pm to find any evidence that proves that the victim did not kill itself, but that other circumstances where the cause of death. The game progresses one hour at a time, effectively dividing the game into several "chapters".

What is the gameplay like? You navigate about the village through your cursor keys, and all the interactions with characters and the general shots of the locations are actually filmed by a film crew and actors. If you are of a somewhat older generation you can perfectly compare it to games like 'Gabriel Knight 2', 'Ripper' or the 'Phantasmagoria' series. A big part during your investigation includes interviewing several suspects and otherwise involved people in the case. This is the main component of the game, as you have to find contradictions to the statements a person has made throughout the game after you asked them about different topics. In general, whenever you found a contradiction you'll get new clues regarding your case or you get people to confess something to you that they have been hiding from youn earlier. Finding those contradictions basically moves you onto the next chapters of the game and is a meassure of progress so to speak. This goes on until you finished the game, and only occasionally you have to use 'items' in certain locations, so there is no complex inventory management or combining of objects of any kind.

Noteworhty things:
- The FMV is high quality and the actors are not as cheesy at you would expect them to be. Each actor has quite a unique personality to them and although it is understandable that they could not hire top stars from hollywood, the actors they have chosen do a good job in general.
- The game becomes harder as you progress, since you have more and more topics and statements to speak about with each character you meet with every chapter you advance. This can get quite frustrating after some time but it actually helps to give you a more lasting experience. You have to pay very very good attention to everything everyone says.
- There is no replayability, at least I don't think so.
- A few contradicitons (about two or three) are quite tricky and can give you quite a headache since the important scenes for them can not be replayed anymore. You have to pay very close attention to what you see and hear as mentioned above.
- The controls are quite awkward at first, but you get used to them quite quickly. Menu navigation is the most confusing part when you begin playing.
- Everyone who has ever played FMV games knows that e.g. transitions between locations can be quite annoying if there are video sequences playing and you have to travel back and forth all the time. This game actually fascinated me in the way how smooth and well done such intermediate shots are integrated. I never felt that any cutscene, as short as they might have been, was annoying me at any time. Especially the intro/outro scenes of an interview.

Overall I'd recommend the game to anyone who likes adventure games, and for anyone that wants to play a good FMV this game is honestly a must. Very well done, good puzzles (in the sense of contradictions to be found) and a good amount of game-time for the asked price and considering the amount of work behind movie based games. Anyone not interested in adventure games may like the game if they are into TV crime series. Otherwise you probably won't enjoy it.

I'd certainly like to see more!

17033960.review:
What a great wee gem of a game. The original generation of FMVs are a bit before my time, but I understand that the tech often didn't live up to the ambition. Well, that one's more area where grasp has now caught up to vision. The video works beautifully with well-chosen angles and smooth movement between shots. The characters are well-cast and well-rounded - it feels like an interactive BBC drama - and the contradiction game play works really well. The setting feels genuinely eerie and tense without being heavy-handed, and the ominous atmosphere only built as the sun went down (lovely touch, by the way). It's challenging enough to cause some head-scratching without becoming completely frustrating (see the Steam walkthrough if you need it - the cheats function doesn't appear to work). The game's plot kep me guessing, tying the main investigation up at the end while creating an intriguing world that I hope will be built upon in further installments.

There are a couple of things Pneuma could do to improve. Auto-playing the prologue video when the game starts would help set the scene for the player. As it is currently, you just land in front of the pub feeling a little confused. A run through of the controls at the start would also benefit the game. I was told to use the 'investigation' and the 'inventory' buttons by text boxes, however, there had been no explanation what these were ('s' and 'enter'). That said, there are control instructions on the Menu screen so it's easy enough to figure out. Going back to the Prologue Video, there's a fair bit of unnecessary exposition. In the next game I'd cut this down to scene-setting only and let the game do the rest of the work (which it does, very well). Last point, a couple of the scenes where Jenks attempts to assert his authority felt a little silly. A bit more research into police descalation techniques would help remedy this. 

All of the above are just suggested improvements and don't detract from the fact that I enjoyed playing this game a lot. So much so, I completed it in a single sitting (lovely way to spend Sunday). I look forward to returning to the world of Contradiction and finding out more about the clandestine workings of the Atlas Institute.

17030093.review:
I just stumbled upon the game’s store page a few days ago and it piqued my interest. Apparently it was a Kickstarter game that somehow passed by my radar and it’s headed by Tim Follin, the composer for games like Plok and New Zealand Story. It’s actually been out on iOS for a couple of months as well but I didn’t know that either. After having completed Her Story when it came out and loving it I was up for another FMV detective game and Contradiction didn’t disappoint. 

Unlike Her Story which took its own unique approach, Contradiction is very much like a traditional 90’s FMV adventure game only upgraded to the HD age. The primary gameplay is finding evidence and then using that evidence to find contradictions between a person’s statements, it’s a bit like Phoenix Wright in execution. The game is never truly obtuse either, I beat the game with no hints. It’s clear that it was meant for mobile first because you only use the keyboard and not the mouse, and it’s a bit clunky at first, but you get used to it fairly quick. The game is pretty low budget and it shows in that there’s not many varied locations and the like but they also worked really well within in these constraints because its real quality, the FMV is very clear, its shot well, and the game is really atmospheric. The acting is quite solid and the protagonist, Inspector Jenks, is a ham but in a likable way. The mystery is entertaining too, though it’s not really complex and there’s never any real “Holy sh*t” moments or the like, but it will definitely keep you engaged.  Overall Contradiction is a very solid game and if you’re in the market for some new school FMV adventure games Contradiction is definitely worth your time.

17026479.review:
The CD-ROM era both birthed and killed the Full Motion Video game. While still in its crib, a generation-long curse was laid upon the genre, dooming all creations branded with the FMV tag to receive nothing but scorn and contempt in every village around the world. And to be honest, the reputation was wholly deserved.

Decades later, hard drive space is now cheap and the codecs plentiful. The creators also seem wiser this time around, focusing on small and intimate, non-branching storylines and cutting the flashy sizzle reel tricks and animations altogether.

Contradiction is, like other recent FMV games such as Her Story and Tesla Effect, a detective mystery: A girl has been found dead in a small rural British town. You play as Inspector Jenks who's been sent to investigate, mostly interviewing the residents about the incident and doing some minor inventory-based sleuthing.

Chats with people open up more points of discussion, and the idea is to find contradictions in the statements of the suspects. This is easier said than done, since the conversations always bring up dozens of possible subjects and pinpointing the slips of the tongue requires attention and thought. Just randomly trying things will get you nowhere.

I was surprised at how engrossed in the game I got. The characters are intriguing and I have no major problems with the acting (Jenks himself can get a bit over the top on occasion, though). The setting and the plot are also atmospheric, with a lot of hints towards something truly sinister. The music properly sets the mood, and the village itself is visually a rather charmingly beautiful little slice of English countryside.

Pacing around the town can get slightly frustrating if you get stuck, but the game has its own elegantly integrated hint system so you're never truly lost. The game is definitely no walk in the park either, so expect your little grey cells to get an outing they probably deserve in this day and age.

The only downside of Contradiction is that you can sometimes see a few corners cut where budget limitations apparently came into play, however, cheapo after effects are blessedly kept to a minimum. Biggest bummer is that some of the major story strands are never brought into conclusion after the case is cracked, but are left to be resolved in a potential sequel.

Anyhow, this is FMV gaming done right. I finished the game in one nine-hour sitting and had fun the whole time. That's more than I can say for most games, FMV or not.

My first FMV game and I can safely say I'm enjoying it. Obviously at the time of writing this I've only just started playing, but so far the game itself seems solid. The acting is decent, although it can be "funny" at times (I'm not sure if I was meant to laugh at the acting), and the audio quality of the voices in some rooms can be muffled. 17017169.review:
Full motion video was quite the rage for a brief time in the mid 90's. Outside of Tex Murphy though few developers got it right. Contradiction brings back everything that was good about FMV gaming while avoiding most if not all of its negatives. For a low budget game this has very good acting and a fairly polished and easy to use interface. There is just something very appealing about getting to play the detective and this story has a lot of interesting clues and sub plots that keep you driving to a solution. The basic gameplay premise works very well. Collect clues, interview subjects and spot contradictions in their testimony. This is much more challenging than you would think as you end up with a large amount of testimony from several suspects throughout the 7 to 8 hour experience and finding the contradictions as you get towards the end can be very challenging. You also end up with a large number of red herrings that can distract you from what is important in the information you uncover. There are a couple of hint systems available in the game, but it's very satisfying to work through the testimony on your own to find the solution.

Pros:
HD quality video and solid acting
Smooth interface that is easy to navigate once you get the key commands down.
Backtracking is helped by map that allows you to quickly return to locations
Very interesting mystery that keeps you pushing towards the solution

Cons:
Audio is a bit over compressed causing it to be tinny. Hopefully this is fixed in a later update.
Story ends with many of the subplots unresolved, but open to a possible sequel. 
Controller support broken on Windows currently. 

You will have to backtrack and speak to suspects over and over as you unlock more clues. This part does have some of the downsides of old 90’s games, but I enjoyed Inspector Jenks so much I didn’t mind and was willing to overlook this. Also, over the course of the many in game hours of interviews the suspects will mostly be in the same places. Drinks will stay the same level and suspects will stare into the same fireplaces. This can take you a bit out of the experience, but I’m sure all the dialog was recorded at the same time and this was necessary for the game design.

Overall this is one of the best FMV and Mystery titles ever made and is quite the achievement on the very small budget the game was made with. I can only hope the game does well enough to make a sequel possible. Game is well worth the asking price.

I was one of the original Kickstarter backers for this game, as I loved the idea and premise.  Have to say, I wasn't disappointed!  For the low price you get 5-6 hours of good solid adventuring, which will test your cognative skills.  Although spotting most of the contradictions are fairly straightforward, one or two will get your brain in gear.  The FMV sequences are done very well, and the acting is a high standard.

16994040.review:
Contradiction is a rather unique game that uses full-motion-video to tell an intriguing murder mystery story, where you play the detective and have to not only spot the other characters lying, but actually catch them at it with their own words. The game gets off to a slow start as you rapidly figure out the interface and game conventions, but the initial world to explore is quite small with only a couple of characters which the game slowly widens and adds to as you call out the characters on their lies.

The writing and acting are superb, which really helps bring you into the story, and the sense of achievement when you spot the contradictions is great because the script is intelligent and doesn't dumb things down. The quaint British village setting and the cult/occult storyline make you think of classic British TV.

Only real criticism so far is that sometimes the audio for the actors speaking is a touch distorted. This isn't enough to detract from the gameplay and more of the pointer to the producers so that when they make their next game (yes - this is more than good enough to warrant a number of sequels) they're able to improve on this aspect. The in-game music fits the setting perfectly and has just the right amount of creepiness, adding much to the atmosphere!

16992805.review:
This is a really fun FMV murder-mystery, made all the more impressive because it's largely a one-man show - aside from the actors, from what I understand, Tim Follin (who made the music for games like Ecco The Dolphin and Lemmings, and later became a Director of Photography, working mostly in TV) edited, scored, and coded the entire thing despite never having previously released a game on his own. 

Tim's background in video work is obvious. He knows how to frame shots, and in almost all of the "idle" screens I've seen, there's something moving without being distracting. This is notable because I haven't seen any compression artifacts, the video is always crisp and sharp whether there's movement or not. Everything looks fantastic. The dialogue is a bit tinny on occasion, but never during suspect interviews, and it's not even close to being distracting or inaudible. The game had a very small budget, and that's really the only time it shows, yet it's still not enough to be considered a detriment. His background in music also shines through, and I hope the soundtrack will be offered as DLC.

I've played for about an hour and a half and according to the story's deadline - you have 7 hours to investigate, with time advancing an hour with each pre-defined major breakthrough - I've only advanced 2 of those 7 hours. The other 2 reviews up right now have 4.3 and 7.3 hours clocked, and based on that and my own personal rate of advancement, those two numbers seem like a fair estimated range of total time for a single playthrough.

The fullscreen option wasn't evident to me at first, but it works great and seamlessly (just press F). Gamepads are supported and don't quite feel right, but I'd prefer a mouse and keyboard for this type of game anyway and it is tagged as having only partial controller support, so it's fine. Also impressive is that this has cloud support, a nice bit of effort, and something games like Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition don't have.

Also of note: The hint system of calling back to police headquarters using a phone booth is great. I've been going through the game pretty quickly, but I'd love to play again later and hear all the hints for places where I wasn't stuck.

If you at all like FMV games, this won't disappoint. I'm not done with it yet, but having a ton of fun, and unless there's a sudden and drastic change in game mechanics or story, I would strongly recommend it to anybody interested.

16992787.review:
Haven't finished it yet, but so far I love it.

Excellent production value, interesting story, characters, great music, an all around very fun experience.
It's exhilarating every time I discover a new contradiction. I actually yell out "YES" when it happens. Truly rewarding and nice classic detective game. 

I bought this and Her Story, and while Her Story was half the price, I feel Contradiction is much better, and is actually worth the money I paid for it. 

Word of advice: Familiarize yourself with the controls in Options before starting a new game, and watch the prologue or else you'll be confused.

16992627.review:
Me: "Hey, it's an adventure game. I have a bit of time, and it's not that expensive. I'd like a quick bit of fun."

*four hours later*

Me: "...Shit this is a lot better than I thought it was going to be. I thought this was going to be cheesy or really simple but it's not."

This game has impressed me. If they can keep up the quality writing, acting, and footage into future games, I'll buy them in a hearbeat.

This was fun and of a surprisingly high quality. I crave more.

10/10. I don't have any sarcastic joke things to say about the number or my recommendation.

It took me a little more than 10.5 hours to play through the game 1.5 times (the menu controls confused me at first and I accidentally saved over my original playthrough, forcing me to restart).
I'd say you can expect to take you 6-8 hours from beginning to end.

16985066.review:
[b]Rise and Fall[/b]

If you're old enough to have been gaming in the 90's you might remember the emergence (and sad demise) of the FMV sub genre.
Games like Gabriel Knight, Phantasmagoria and the Tex Murphy titles started to embrace Full Motion Video footage.
Initially it was viewed as a novelty, real actors playing out the narrative in all the interlaced video glory the 90's could muster.
FMV seemed liked a perfect fit for cut scenes and narrative heavy titles and I loved it!
Even some real "Hollywood" actors were seduced by the rise of the interactive movie, with the likes of Mark "Skywalker" Hamil heading up the Wing Commander games and Christopher "Pulp Fiction" Walken starring in the 1996 FMV thriller "Ripper"


[b]RIP FMV[/b]

Unfortunately, my love for all things FMV wasn't shared by my peers,  I was in the minority and the FMV trend had almost died away completely by the end of the 90's.
This was partly due to the technological limitations of the time.
The video was often interlaced or blocky, the frame rates were poor and the amount of space required by the footage used up a huge amount of CD-Rom storage, the game Ripper I mentioned earlier was spread across 6 CD's!

Many FMV games also suffered from cheesy writing and equally bad acting.
"Phoned in" performances were the norm and as such a stigma began to emerge in the media around the whole "interactive movie" genre.
This stigma probably had as much to do with the death of the genre as the technical limitations of the 90's, but whatever the reason, the interactive movie died, I mourned its passing and moved on, but now I've discovered a game which has rekindled my interest, a new, modern FMV experience in all its interactive movie gaming glory.


[b]The Stage[/b]

Contradiction: Spot the Liar! to give it its full (and unnecessarily long title) is a "whodunnit" detective adventure set in the sleepy little English village of Edenton.

Edenton isn't just a stage for the players either, its a character in its own right.
From the village pub to the surrounding woodland, all the locations are beautifully realised and tie together to create a charming and peaceful setting, you'll even see the odd Union Jack fluttering in the breeze.
This rural tranquillity gives Edenton a charm of its own, it feels like a real location that you'd find if you drove out  into the green and pleasant land that is the English countryside.
It's this tranquil charm which makes the recent events in Edenton all the more shocking.

There's been a suspicious death in the village, a young woman, Kate Vine, has drowned but was it suicide? a terrible accident? or something more sinister?
You've got one night to find out, let the investigations begin!


[b]The Players[/b]

You play as Detective Inspector Jenks, an interestingly likeable character with a compelling interview technique which is sure to make you smile, he's also somewhat of a kleptomaniac and has the added side effect of making me want to start wearing a hat.

As you explore the village you'll come across some equally interesting locals, friends and acquaintances of Kate's all getting on with their lives, each with their own personalities, view of events and secrets to hide.
I can't overstate how well written these characters are, without exception everyone you come across feels like a fleshed out and fully realised person, from the landlady at the village pub to the father and son team who run "Atlas" an exclusive business training course which seems to be popular with the local students, they're all engaging and make each interview a pleasure to play through.


[b]One Week Later...[/b]

Jenks arrives in the village of Edenton one week after Kate Vines death, it's a Friday evening, the locals are going about their business and it's your job to snoop through their things and interview them regarding the death.

Everything in this game is presented through video footage, from the navigation of the village through to the interviews themselves, but more on that later.

Movement around the village is a simple, go  left, go right affair, each location has its own video loop, there are no static screens here, Edenton is a living, breathing village.
Stand by the lakeside and waves will ripple in the light whilst branches move and creak  in the wind, the level of immersion this creates is undeniably impressive.


[b]The Questions[/b]

You'll find yourself searching through locations, finding clues and interviewing the locals.
These interviews are the meat of the game, initially you'll only have a couple of "conversation pieces"  to enquire about, the dead girl, Kate Vine and her driving license which was discovered some distance away from her body.
Questioning the residents of Edenton quickly opens up your investigative  options as you uncover more information about events leading up to Kate's death and "acquire" items to ask about from your inevitable snooping.


[b]The Play[/b]

It's not just a case of ask everyone about everything you discover either, that's just part of it.
You actually need to listen to what people say,

Who's lying?
Who's telling the truth?

It's listening out for contradictions in characters answers that will help reveal this information.


[b]The Lies[/b]

The actual mechanic of spotting these contradictions is well implemented too.
As you question a person, notes of their relevant answers are recorded in your journal.
You can go through these notes and if you spot two that contradict each other you can question the person further regarding the holes in their story.

Why did they lie?
What are they hiding?


[b]The Lost[/b]

This game is by no means easy either, you're not going to breeze straight through the story without actually thinking about what people have told you and going through your notes.
Having said that, there is a hint system if you find yourself stuck at a dead end.
The hints are given by going to the phone box in the village (Jenks is an old school kind of guy and doesn't seem to have a mobile) and calling the police chief who will offer an insight to help get you back on track.
If these hints aren't enough there's always the old faithful option of just plain cheating too, but try and avoid it if you can, the satisfaction of catching someone in a lie is what this game is all about.


[b]I Spy[/b]

One thing I wasn't keen on with this game was the snooping investigation mechanic.
When you reach a scene with something interesting for you to discover a giant magnifying glass icon appears in the bottom right corner of the screen.
Click on it and Jenks will investigate whatever it is that he has spotted at that location.
It works fine but I would have enjoyed a little more subtlety here.

This mechanic is likely a throwback to the titles mobile gaming routes but as a PC gamer the ability to scan your mouse over a location to discover something for yourself would have been more rewarding.

I'm just being picky though, this didn't tarnish my enjoyment of the game,  it's a just a change that would have added something to what otherwise was an excellent experience.


[b]HDTV[/b]

Visually this game is hard to fault with high quality full motion video throughout.
This is an FMV title with the production values of a primetime TV show.
From the camera angles to the sets themselves, everything works to draw you into what feels like a real place populated by real people.
The sound is equally impressive, with an excellently appropriate musical score to accompany the ambient sounds found at each location.
The voice recording itself is generally of a high quality, occasionally you'll... [snip]

16982369.review:
I didn't set out with particular high hopes for a £6.99 'mystery solving FMV game' (I'm a big fan of Tex & Tesla Effect Mind!). However, I've just caught myself two hours in and realised what a great time I'm having.

The acting is hit and miss. However, the 'miss' acting ends up being pretty funny, "THE LAAAAANDLADY", and doesn't detract from the game at all. In fact, it probably adds to it, as I don't get the feeling it's a game that takes itself 'too' seriously.

I had to use cheats a couple of times, but that was purely due to my personal impatience rather than it being un-obvious, as when the cheat told me what to do, I slapped my forehead.

Great game, I hope there's more FMV games of this type in the future, £6.99 well spent.
